DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Notice of Intention to Withdraw Notice of Motion

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to standing order 109A I give notice that, at the giving of notices on the next day of sitting, I shall withdraw Business of the Senate notices of motion Nos 5 and 6 standing in my name for six sitting days hence for disallowance of certain Migration Regulations. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a short description of our scrutiny and the Committee's brief correspondence with Ministers.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-

1. Statutory Rules 1988 No. 313 set the levels of certain fees for permanent entry visas to Australia. The fee for persons already in Australia was $300. The fee for overseas business applicants who were in Australian business partnerships or joint enterprises, or who were intending to invest at least $500,000 in Australia was $1,000. While that fee was obviously a small proportion of such a business applicant's assets, the Committee felt that, on the grounds of principle, it should seek an explanation for the discrepancy between the levels of the two fees. Regulations may only set a fee at a level designed to recoup the cost of administration. Thus, the fee must be a fee for services rendered or to be rendered and not amount to tax of any kind. The Committee asked the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, the Honourable Clyde Holding, MP, to explain the reasons for the discrepancy in the levels of the two fees.

The Minister was good enough to explain that the $1,000 fee in fact amounted to a closer approximation of the real full cost of processing a business visa application at an overseas post, not taking into account the Central Office costs. Business migrants would obviously have a greater capacity to pay this more realistic fee for service. The Committee accepted this explanation.

2. Statutory Rules 1988 No. 314 repealed an earlier regulation that set a maximum limit to the fee that could be charged by a migration agent. The fee was $2 and obviously outdated. The Committee asked the Minister why the concept of a ceiling had been abandoned. The Explanatory Statement did not explain this. The Minister indicated that as a matter of policy the Government had decided to remove the regulatory control over the fee. It was difficult to police charges imposed by registered migration agents and inappropriate for Government to be attempting to regulate the market offering these services which should preferably be self-regulating, particularly in the light of the recent establishment of the Australian Migration Consultants Association.

The Committee, in accepting the Minister's explanation, considered that all of this very significant information regarding both sets of regulations should properly have appeared, in the first instance, in the explanatory statement that accompanied the regulations to Parliament. The Minister noted this suggestion for future reference.
22 February 1988
The Hon. Clyde Holding, M.P.
Minister for Immigration,
Local Government and Ethnic Affairs
Parliament House
CANBERRA A.C.T. 2600
Dear Minister,

At its meeting on 18 February 1988 the Committee considered Migration Regulations (Amendments)(being Statutory Rules 1987 Nos. 313 and 314, tabled in the Senate on 17 February 1988). The Committee seeks your comments and advice on the question of certain fees.

In Statutory Rules 1987 No. 313 regulation 4 amends regulation 29AB to provide that a fee of $1,000 will be charged to applicants for non-citizen conditional or permanent entry visas who, either have entered into business or joint venture partnerships, or intend to bring into Australia at least $500,000 of capital for the purposes of a business enterprise. This business visa fee appears to be at least 3 times as high as other visa fees. The reasons for the differences are not set out in the explanatory statement.

As you know the courts have over many years held that a power to fix fees may not be exercised in such a way as to impose a tax. Thus in Matthews v Chicory Marketing Board (Vict.) [1937-1938] 60 C.L.R. 263, Latham C.J. referring to a particular levy said at, page 276, that it was plainly a tax because-
It is a compulsory exaction of money by a public authority for public purposes, enforceable by law and is not a payment for services rendered.
In Marsh v Shire of Serpentine Jarrahdale [1966] 120 C.L.R. 572, Barwick C.J., at page 581, said of a particular Act that it

. . . does contemplate that the Board may, to some extent, recoup itself for its administrative effort in considering the application and physically issuing the licence. [In this case] the fee bears no relation to the cost of administering a licensing system. It is evidently not a charge fixed as a reasonable fee for the issue of licences. Whilst that consideration may not always be decisive, in my opinion, the statute in this case authorised no more than fees which fall within this description. The instant fee certainly does not.

In the light of these considerations the Committee would welcome your assistance in explaining the reasons for the imposition of the $1,000 fee as a cost recovery measure for services rendered to business visa applicants. Where large fee increases occur or where significant differences arise between fees for services that appear to be comparable in terms of administration costs, the Committee has found it very helpful for the explanatory statement accompanying the regulations to explain this. Such explanations can allay any concerns that fees had been set at relatively inappropriate levels. The Committee respectfully suggests that relevant future explanatory statements might address these points.

Secondly, in Statutory Rules 1987 No. 314 regulation 7 repeals regulation 29 of the Principal regulations which had imposed a maximum of $2 on the fee that a migration agent might charge for services. Such a ceiling is now, of course, absurdly low. However, the general practice of providing for a reasonable maximum fee for services rendered is often followed in delegated legislation. As the explanatory statement does not explain why the maximum fee prescription has been repealed, it would be very helpful if you would provide the Committee with some background information and the reasons for this initiative.
Your cooperation with each of the matters raised by the Committee would be much appreciated.
Your sincerely,
Bob Collins
Chairman

Senator Bob Collins

Regulations and Ordinances

CANBERRA A.C.T. 2600
Dear Bob
Thank you for your letter of 22 February 1988 seeking advice about the basis for charging a $1 000 fee for migrants seeking entry to Australia under the Business Migration Program (BMP).
The fee represents the approximate cost of processing an application at an overseas post. This does not take into account costs incurred in Central or Regional Offices of the Department.

You have pointed out that it is a significantly higher amount than that charged for other migration categories. The reason for this is that it represents a closer approximation of the full cost of processing than the charge for all other categories. It is considered that business migrants may have a greater capacity to pay for the cost of processing than other migrants and it is not unreasonable to recover this cost through a more realistic charge.

Your letter also raised the question of the maximum fee which can be charged by a migration agent. The $2 fee was clearly unrealistic and outdated; however the decision to remove it also involved a matter of principle. Apart from the difficulty of policing all charges imposed by registered agents, I consider it inappropriate for a Government agency to be attempting to regulate the market. It would be preferable for this industry, like many others, to be self-regulating and it is likely that the recently formed Australian Migration Consultants Association may play a role in this area in the future.
I have noted your suggestion that any future explanatory statements might address the kind of points you have raised.
Yours sincerely
(Clyde Holding)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make some comments about this motion which has been moved by the Australian Democrats without any warning to the Opposition. There seems to be some confusion in the Government ranks as to whether they were warned but I take it from what was said across the table by Senator Cook that there is some arrangement between the Government and the Democrats to enable this to happen.

SPEECH.PARA: There have been meetings between the Government, the Democrats and the Opposition over the last week relating to the program which the Government has established for the rest of this session. I simply wish to make the point when we are dealing with a motion to bring on this matter, which will, of course, take a great deal of debate, that, as has been discussed at those meetings, there is a quite impossible program facing the Senate at this time. I do not have that program before me at the moment but it is a quite extraordinary legislative load, bearing in mind that it will include in the last two weeks legislation which will flow from the May statement. Ministers have indicated that the May statement may well contain matters of very considerable substance. Clearly, legislation which may go to matters of tariffs, for example, or matters of taxation is not legislation that can be dealt with as a matter of form and simply coughed through the Senate as though it were of no account.

Probably of even greater significance is the fact that we are facing the prospect of legislation to bring on constitutional changes and referenda later this year. We have a rather farcical situation. It has been indicated by the Government that, having spent a great deal of money-millions of dollars-on establishing a Constitutional Commission, it is going to introduce into the Parliament proposals for constitutional change before it has the final report of the Constitutional Commission. That is a point worth making, because it discloses the blatantly political nature of the exercise the Government has undertaken with respect to constitutional change.

What has been telegraphed by Ministers is that at the heart of the changes which are proposed to the Constitution are changes which will go to the role and function of this chamber. I mention that in the context of this debate because, quite clearly, it would be improper for measures of that sort to be brought before the Senate and not subjected to the most careful scrutiny and the fullest possible opportunity for debate. I have raised with the Australian Democrats the question of whether they will again join with the Government to gag debate in the context of these constitutional changes. I am pleased to say that I have received some reassurances from them in that regard. But the point is that the Senate faces a substantial legislative program which I have already indicated to the Government is not, with the best will in the world, capable of being met, even without the propositions that will flow from the May statement and from the constitutional proposals which, we are told, will be unveiled to a breathless Australian public on 10 May.

When one looks at what the Government has in mind for those periods all one can say is that the likelihood is that the Senate will not, in any orderly way, be able to deal with the legislative burden the Government is proposing to put before it. It is in that context that the Opposition wishes to register the strongest possible protest to the Government about the arrangement it has made with the Senate to divert the Senate this morning into a debate on chemical pesticides. I put to the Government that it would be sensible, in terms of our achieving the Government's program, not to pursue this course of action. But, if it does pursue this course of action, we would expect to debate in a proper way in the Senate today the motion which the Democrats are now putting forward.

I do not know whether the Government has been talking to primary industry. I suppose that it might have been. Perhaps, on the other hand, it is too busy sorting out its troubles in the right wing factions of the Australian Labor Party in New South Wales to worry about what the agricultural industries of Australia think. But if the Government thinks that pulling this stunt is seen as being vaguely in the interests of the agricultural and export industries of this country, it is going around with its ears closed. This is a particularly foolish exercise on the part of the Australian Democrats. What is extraordinary is that they should have the collaboration of the Government in this exercise. I will not deal with the issues which are raised by this substantive motion at any length because this is not the appropriate debate in which to do it.
Honourable senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I hear the caterwauling of the Australian Democrats as I speak. All I can say is that a party which requires only 6 or 7 per cent of the vote to get the representation it has here can afford to laugh at the interests of Australian primary producers. The Democrats can afford to do so because all they are seeking is some tiny corner of the vote to enable them to continue their operations in this chamber. They have no operations anywhere else. They have no prospect of taking part in the government of this country. They are engaged in a cynical exercise which bears no relation to the national interest.

SPEECH.PARA: As far as the Opposition is concerned, the only point in prolonging this debate is to give the Government some chance to reconsider the particularly foolish stance that it has adopted with respect to this arrangement with the Australian Democrats. We oppose very clearly and very forcefully the proposal to bring on this matter for debate. We believe that it shows either that the Government has no real interest in its own program or that it has no sense. The running of the Senate chamber often indicates that the Government has very little sense. I am sorry that the Manager of Government Business in the Senate, Senator Gareth Evans, is not present. Over recent months he has shown some realism in the handling of this place and in meeting the requirements of the Government's program. It is quite clear that Ministers who are present at the moment are acting in complete ignorance of that interest.

In our view, this motion should be defeated and we should return to the program that is before us. As it is, we will spend the rest of today debating matters which have nothing to do with the Government's legislative program. That is not something that has been brought about by the Opposition; it has been brought about by the Government allowing the tail of this chamber to wag the dog. I believe that the Government should reconsider what it is doing and enable us to return to the business which we are paid to consider in this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Amendment Bill 1987 seeks to make some finetuning amendments to the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977. The second reading speech of the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans), which has been tabled previously, suggests that the Act, which came into operation on 1 October 1980, codified and modernised the ancient prerogative writ remedies under which the lawfulness of government decision-making could be challenged. That is certainly true, and it is fair to say that at that time there was a very substantial measure of agreement that there was a need for an overhaul of the existing structures. Certainly, there were very many complexities and uncertainties and, I think, in many ways the administrative law regime that we now have streamlines the procedures.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill seeks to limit in several fairly important ways the rights of persons seeking judicial review. It is certainly the view of the Opposition that it is yet another attempt to undermine and emasculate the administrative law regime that has been in place for quite some years now. The great reforms of the 1970s led to the establishment of not only the Administrative Appeals Tribunal but also the Commonwealth Ombudsman, the Freedom of Information Act and, certainly, the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act. They were all designed to ensure that ordinary citizens would not be overborne by government decision-making and that they would be entitled to reasons for decisions and entitled to review on points of law the decisions made by otherwise unimpeachable public servants.

The reality is that the Government has seized on a frustration engendered by one particular instance and has then attempted to introduce some so-called remedies and efficiencies into the system. But the end result is that the cure is much worse than the complaint. The present law allows people to go to the Federal Court of Australia to review a range of decisions made by administrative tribunals. It is sometimes the case that people seek to make interlocutory applications to contest rulings on technical or procedural and jurisdictional matters in the course of the hearing.

The one case that is endlessly cited as an example of an abuse of process is the application for a third television licence in the State of Western Australia, where some 16 separate applications were made to the Federal Court over a period of 12 to 18 months. It was said that that thereby caused a delay in the granting of the licence of about some 12 months. However, the reality is that, of those applications, some six were successful. There was no attempt on the part of the respondent to proceed in any way that was improper, nor indeed was it considered by the court that any of those applications constituted an abuse of process or that they were in any way frivolous, vexatious or oppressive.

Indeed, not all the applications to the Court were made pursuant to the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act. The result of those applications was to streamline in many ways the administrative process of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal and to correct some weaknesses and deficiencies in its procedures. It is quite clear that that was a one-off situation, where all the parties to the application regarded the cost as being of no concern. It is not often that one gets litigation where litigants on both sides can afford to take that approach. The matter has now been resolved. The circumstances are unlikely to recur and, in any event-this perhaps is a very important consideration-none of the current arrangements, nor indeed the proposed arrangements, would deprive applicants of their rights to go to the High Court of Australia, under its original jurisdiction, or to the Federal Court, under the Judiciary Act, in order to review these decisions. What the Government is really seeking to do is to use that one example, which I would suggest is a flawed instance, to justify very serious limitations being placed on the rights of individuals to make applications during the currency of a hearing. It is not uncommon that people feel the need to get clarification of preliminary rulings. One would have thought that it is a proper procedure that should be applied in this jurisdiction.

If the Government were really concerned that there were certain areas where there should not be applications of any sort during the currency of a hearing it could have provided that there should be no appeals on broadcasting, trade practices, migration or taxation matters and it could similarly have put a limitation on applications during the currency of those hearings. But it has not sought to do that. It has introduced a very messy and uncertain form of reverse onus so that a person must now prove that there are not alternative statutory remedies available from tribunals or authorities or that the interests of justice require the granting of the application. That does not rule out common law remedies or other applications. As I have already indicated, the Bill introduces a whole new set of complexities and uncertainties. It requires the establishment by the applicant of that effective reverse onus of proof. It will therefore penalise small and impecunious litigants who will be intimidated on the question of costs because they will be liable for costs unless they win the ultimate hearing, not just win on the preliminary point, because they will be bearing their own costs.

It is our strong view that if the Government had been seriously concerned about the question of delay being used as a tactic it could have confined its concerns to that area and put an onus of proof on a respondent to demonstrate that the application was made solely or primarily for the purposes of delay. But it has not done that; it has introduced this new regime which in many ways will simply make matters much more complicated. The onus being on the applicant regardless of the respondent's views removes an element of flexibility because it means that the respondent cannot make a sensible judgment about whether there is merit in the application or whether it is designed simply for tactical purposes. It would require the applicant to rebut that suggestion; so this would have to be faced up to in every instance. Of course, in many instances that could well be a very unnecessary and burdensome obligation. One could envisage that even in those Broadcasting Tribunal hearings manifest deficiencies were apparent to both sides but that the Tribunal was reluctant to make a ruling and was prepared to concede jurisdiction to the Federal Court. Even in an instance such as that, this legislation would require that the applicant before the court would face this very difficult burden of proof.

It is the view of the Opposition that this legislation does not achieve any useful purpose. It also is intended to avoid overlapping remedies and, again, to require an applicant to demonstrate that there are not alternative remedies available beyond review under the Act. That again is a difficult and uncertain area. It will not reduce any abusive use of the Act. It is likely to discriminate against those who can least afford to take their chances in a court of law. It certainly would not have deterred any of the applications to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal hearings. That simply would have been grist to the mill for them and they would have had no problems in retaining highly qualified and expensive senior counsel and, in effect, upping the ante. I would have thought that would be the last thing the Government would have contemplated occurring in that instance.

It may be that it was intended that there should be a discouragement of resort to the Federal Court in the first instance, but that assumes that administrative remedies are cheaper than Federal Court hearings and I would question that assumption. The cost of traversing this additional step would certainly fall on applicants irrespective of the merits and that is a very serious vice. Finally, the omnibus requirement that an applicant demonstrate that it is in the interest of justice that he be allowed to proceed with the application for interlocutory review is yet another minefield for the unwary. It certainly makes it very difficult to predict the outcome and the best advice that would probably be offered in that situation by responsible legal advisers is that one simply cannot tell: it depends a bit on the judge; it is a matter of discretion; there is always a risk involved and the applicant will be up for the costs in any event. In such a situation one can well understand that an applicant will be deterred. It is another instance of the onus being on the wrong foot.

We say that this legislation is unnecessary. The introduction of a de facto leave requirement will simply aggravate the situation. It will allow departments and agencies to run up costs in arid jurisdiction challenges. It will introduce uncertainty and complexities. It will not deter corporations; it may well deter ordinary citizens. The operation of the current administrative law structure under this Act is working satisfactorily. There was an earlier suggestion that perhaps in the area of committal proceedings there could be some attempts at delay but the onus, if there must be one, should be very much on the Government to demonstrate that there was a series of inequities and injustices rather than simply to point to one isolated and exceptional piece of commercial litigation in which the parties were well able to look after themselves, in which all sides understood the rules of the game and in which the ultimate outcome may well have been to the benefit of future litigants because it clarified a number of the procedural complexities and difficulties that might otherwise have needed to be resolved by other less pecunious applicants.

For those reasons the Opposition opposes the legislation. In doing that we very much support the report of the Senate Select Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. We do not resile from the fact that prior to the Committee's investigation some of these difficulties were not apparent. It is a good example of the usefulness of the Senate inquiry system. We had a number of very helpful submissions which demonstrated a number of the matters that I have touched on today. Having had mature consideration of the implications of the Bill, it is our view that it must be rejected.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Amendment Bill 1987 has had a fairly long history. The Government has not moved in any way-certainly not by way of suggested amendments circulated in this place-to meet the propositions we raised last time. Our objections, therefore, still stand.

SPEECH.PARA: It is obvious that this Bill goes significantly further than the recommendations of the Administrative Review Council in its review of this Act. One of the Review Council's conclusions was that it was neither desirable nor appropriate to introduce a requirement of leave in the Act. The Bill, as currently drafted, threatens to introduce such a de facto requirement of leave. We believe that it is easily demonstrable that the Bill's provisions will operate in practice to add to the expense of proceedings. I quote from a submission by the Administrative Law Committee of the Law Institute of Victoria which I think puts this very clearly. It quotes from the second reading speech made by the then Attorney-General in 1977 on the introduction of the parent Act:

The present law relating to the review by the courts of administrative decisions is in a most unsatisfactory state . . . The law in this area is clearly in need of reform-indeed, it could be said to be mediaeval-and simplification to be put into statutory form. What the present Bill-
that is, the parent Act which this Bill seeks to amend-

seeks to do is to establish a single simple form of proceedings in the Federal Court of Australia for judicial review of Commonwealth administrative actions as an alternative to the present cumbersome and technical procedures for review by way of prerogative writ, or the present actions for a declaration or injunction.
That is the end of the quotation from the original second reading speech made in 1977. The submission goes on:
The Committee strenuously opposes the proposed amendments as a step back towards the `cumbersome' and `mediaeval' procedures which the Act was designed to remedy.
The alternative remedies of prerogative writ and action for declaration are entrenched-
as Senator Alston has already said-

in the Constitution. It is not within the Parliament's power to affect the citizen's rights with regard to those remedies. Therefore, the proposed amendments may cause actions, which can presently be taken under the Act, to be brought under the Constitution. Such relief, being `cumbersome and technical', is more time consuming and involves greater expense.
Accordingly, the Bill is likely to be counterproductive. It will result in an increase in costs and delays . . .

That point has been made in a number of other submissions. The Government-certainly last time-did not seek to meet the situation that people will still wish to press their rights and, in doing so, will take avenues available to them. If we cut off this avenue, another avenue is available. It is certainly more costly and more cumbersome and is possibly available only to the rich and powerful in this society. The Labor Party seems to be interested in looking after the rich and powerful, which is possibly one of the reasons this Bill is before us.

Many other people in the community, the ordinary citizens who do not have access to vast amounts of wealth, are the ones who are normally affected by administrative decisions. The statistics show that currently the overwhelming majority of litigants seeking to challenge the legality of the Commonwealth's administrative decisions use the Act in preference to the writ or the other methods available to them. If that is the case, and the overwhelming majority of litigants use the Act, one must ask why we are seeking to implement a method which could have the result of moving people into the other area, which we were seeking to avoid by passage of the Act in the first place. Undoubtedly, the essence of this Bill is to erect additional procedural hurdles. To put those hurdles in the way of people seeking judicial review of some action, I would have thought, is the antithesis of the Act.

A number of other items have been raised time and again. The Government has not sought in any way to deal with them. For example, what type of guidance is to be offered with regard to concepts such as the interests of justice and interference with the due and orderly conduct of proceedings, et cetera? Certainly, many submissions to the Committee made it clear that it is preferable to identify various circumstances in which courts may traditionally refuse relief in the exercise of residual discretion.

It is obvious that the measures in this Bill are designed to discourage the disruption of administrative proceedings. That, after all, is what the Minister said in his second reading speech. However, in the attempt to move against so-called disruptions of administrative proceedings, we are faced with the question of whether rights which should be available to citizens to undertake actions which are not prohibitively expensive are also being taken away. These measures go beyond the recommendations of the Administrative Review Council, without any argument being raised as to why. It is important that, having established the Administrative Review Council, we take some cognisance of it. The Government is perfectly entitled either to take or reject any recommendations from such a council. But in doing so it should try to meet the Council's propositions and say why it wishes to go beyond them, as in this case. I am not criticising the Government for having gone beyond the recommendations of the Council. It is just that a detailed reason as to why it has gone beyond the recommendations of the Council has not been given. We may hear it later in this debate.

The Democrats' feeling is that the Bill creates an unreasonable and inappropriate balance in the respective positions of private individuals-ordinary citizens-and the Government and that, by raising these additional procedural barriers, the Government is disadvantaging significantly the individual citizen, whereas the intended compensation on the other side, as, I think, Senator Alston has already said, leans on a small number of propositions. I suppose that bad examples always end up making bad law. That is probably the situation here. Undoubtedly, there will be occasions when, on the face of it, there will seem to be attempts to disrupt administrative procedures. But under those circumstances one will have to ask whether those administrative procedures are such as to raise the ire of a substantial number of citizens. If they are, it may very well be that the administrative decisions ought to be changed, rather than the law governing the rights of citizens to object to them.

Why is it that every time we have a substantial body of public opinion concerned about some type of administrative action, public opinion must be wrong and administrative action right? Politicians have to take note of public opinion. I think it would be worth while on occasions for the bureaucracy also to listen to the public. If a substantial number of people seek to intervene, as is the case in the example that the Government has trotted out with regard to broadcasting, I believe that some attention ought to be paid to that. Attention has been paid to it; changes have and are being made; some of which, of course, my Party is totally opposed to. Nevertheless, I believe that we should not jump to the conclusion that the people who are wrong are members of the public, the people who are right are the bureaucrats, and that what we have to do is actually to put members of the public in their place. I think that that is what this Bill attempts to do. It is unacceptable. I hope that if the Government wishes to proceed down this track after the defeat of this Bill it will listen much more carefully to the Review Council's recommendations and conform more closely to those types of recommendations, rather than seek to take away the legitimate rights of citizens to seek review of administrative action.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish briefly to add my support to the position of the Opposition in this matter-that is, to oppose the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Amendment Bill. It is yet another demonstration of the effective role that the committee system of the Senate can play. I was pleased to be part of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs which examined in depth the provisions contained in this amendment Bill. I came to the conclusion that the arguments that have been put forward by the Government to justify the amendments are not valid; in fact, the amendments would relieve the citizen of certain of the citizen's discretions in applying for administrative review and that is not in the best interests of the community at large.

SPEECH.PARA: I guess there is a lesson for us in that whenever the Government starts a second reading speech to a Bill with words to the effect that `this Bill simply applies some finetuning' we should be put on guard. This instance is such an occasion. The Bill, at first glance, can appear to be somewhat innocuous and to have certain merit. When it is suggested to us that there is an abuse by those who are aggrieved in seeking to take advantage of the various options at the same time, one has an immediate sentiment in support of the Bill. But on careful analysis that argument is found not to be so.

I am pleased to stand here as someone who is proud of the contribution that the coalition made when in government to develop what I think is the most comprehensive and effective administrative review mechanism that exists anywhere in the English-speaking world. It is a mechanism that has a number of arms to it, Madam Acting Deputy President, as you would know. There is the opportunity for someone to look for review from the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, which was set up in 1975 and is empowered to review decisions on their merits and to substitute its decisions for those of the original decision-makers. That is what we would regard as the most simple and hopefully the least cost-incurring method of seeking review. There is the mechanism set up by legislation for a person to have the opportunity to go to the Ombudsman and allow him to investigate on behalf of an individual what the individual regards as administrative abuse. Alternatively, in the more complicated circumstances, there is the opportunity under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act to seek judicial review.

As I said, it is my opinion and the opinion of the Opposition that this group of Acts and tribunals gives citizens in this country the best opportunity possible to question and seek review of the very many administrative decisions that are taken by government that affect their lives. We need only reflect very briefly upon the enormous range of matters that affect us in our daily lives upon which governments make administrative decisions. One can think of matters that occur every day in the migration field, in taxation, Customs, social security, prosecution decisions, extradition proceedings, and so on. There is a myriad of occasions in which governments affect the lives of the citizen. It has certainly not been easy in the past for the citizen to question and to seek review of those administrative decisions when the citizen has regarded them as not being well-founded. The machinery that has been set up-somewhat complex but nevertheless comprehensive-gives the citizen that opportunity.

The Government is seeking, by this Bill, to introduce a hurdle to applicants who are seeking such review. I draw your attention, Madam Acting Deputy President, to section 10 of the existing Act which provides that the court may, in its discretion, refuse to grant an application for review made under section 5, 6 or 7 of the AD(JR) Act where an applicant has sought review by the court or by another court otherwise than under the Act. In the case of an applicant before the tribunal and seeking an action before another court, the court already has the discretion not to grant the application for review. That is existing law. This Bill seeks to go one step further by providing an onus upon the applicant in circumstances that seem to us to be unwarranted. It will require the court to refuse applications made under section 5, 6 or 7 of the AD(JR) Act where the applicant has an alternative right to seek review unless the interests of justice required that it should not refuse the application. In other words, the onus has been switched to the applicant. The court shall refuse the application unless the applicant can prove certain things.

As I said at the beginning of my speech, this change was put to the Senate as being warranted because of certain alleged abuses. When one looks at the report of the Administrative Review Council and the investigation by the Senate Standing Committee, one finds that the suggestions of alleged abuses do not stand examination. The Senate Standing Committee concluded that it had no reason to doubt the Administrative Review Council's conclusion that the allegations about the level of abuse of AD(JR) Act applications is exaggerated. The report of the Committee states:
In the Committee's view, there is no evidence to suggest that the AD(JR) Act has attracted `abusive' litigation in a manner which distinguishes it from any other legal process.

I say again that under the existing Act the court already has a discretion to refuse an application if it sees abuses occurring. So why introduce a new onus upon the applicant? The Standing Committee went on to say:

The Committee is of the view that enactment of the proposed amendments will not decrease the costs of reviewing administrative action. The proposed amendments will not affect the availability of common law procedures (such as prerogative writs) which are, in many cases, more expensive than applications under the AD(JR) Act.

The Committee, seeking to be constructive as it always does, nevertheless recognised that there may well be need for some further legislative formulation of the court's discretion and specifically stated that it was prepared to accept that this should occur where applicants possessed adequate alternative remedies. The Committee said that it would support such codification provided, however, that the onus was not switched. That appears as conclusion 5.7 of the Committee's report, which reads:
Accordingly, the Committee would have no objection to the enactment of proposed paragraphs 10 (2) (c) and 10 (2) (d) if the onus were to be placed upon the respondent-not upon the applicant.

I would have thought that that should have been a sufficient lead for this Government to recognise that if it switched the onus it had the support of the Senate's own Committee which examined the matter and it would, therefore, be likely to gain support for the legislative formulation of the court's discretion of which it was speaking. But this Government has not been prepared to do that. It is seeking to pursue the Bill in the original form despite the advice that has been given to it by the Senate's own Committee. It is not surprising, therefore, that the Opposition will support the Committee, oppose the Bill and ensure that this added hurdle for applicants seeking administrative review is not introduced.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Amendment Bill, which the Opposition is opposing, because I think I owe the Senate some explanation of my own position with respect to it. Those clauses propose that, where any applicant to the Federal Court of Australia under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act lodges an application for review under that Act, and where provision is made by any law other than the Act-for example, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act-under which the applicant is already entitled to seek a review of that decision otherwise than by a court, the Federal Court shall refuse to grant the application unless it is satisfied that it is in the interests of justice for it to be granted. In other words, as Senator Hill and Senator Alston have pointed out, the onus of proof under this Act in respect of any such application which argues for the prior intervention of the Federal Court before those other avenues of review have been explored or exhausted would be shifted from the respondent, where it would normally be, to the applicant.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, of which I am a member, reported on this and other aspects of the Bill on 29 October last. With me dissenting, the Committee unanimously recommended-I refer to paragraph 5.8 of the report of the Committee-that this particular provision of the Bill should not be enacted. There is, I think, general agreement that the arguments in this matter are rather finely balanced. Those who may be listening to this debate may be having some difficulty in finding quite where the balance sometimes lies in them. Chapter 4 of the Committee's report, wherein this particular matter is examined, runs to 69 paragraphs. I hope that it will not be thought to be any reflection upon either the Committee or, still less, its extremely competent staff if I say that the argumentation in those paragraphs is not merely long drawn out but exceedingly finely spun in places. Not being myself a lawyer, I expressed my dissent from the Committee's conclusion on this matter in only two very meagre paragraphs. They are at page 47 of the Committee's report, paragraphs J.S.2. and J.S.3. Perhaps I should read them into the record. They are very brief. In that dissent, I stated:
in whatever form the proposed amendments to Section 10 of the Act are expressed, if the Federal Court is given power to refuse an application, or is directed conditionally to refuse an application-
which is what the Bill is proposing-

in cases where the applicant is entitled to seek review by another tribunal, authority or person, the reality is that the court will generally refuse the application unless the applicant persuades it not to do so.
I went on to say in the next paragraph:
For my part, therefore, I see no significant basis for objection to the amendments to sub-section 10 (2) of the Act-
that is of the principal Act-
that are included in Clause 2 of the Bill. To object to those amendments seems to me to be straining at gnats while letting through the camels.

Nevertheless, as I say, and as I think one or two earlier speakers may have said, the arguments, either way, are rather finely balanced. When this Bill originally passed through the House of Representatives on 26 February last year and again when it passed though that House-the Parliament having meanwhile been dissolved for the general election-in October last year, the Opposition did not oppose the Bill, including not opposing this provision thereof. I suppose that is perhaps the best evidence that can be quoted of the fine balance of argument on this matter, given the Opposition's more recent decision now to propose the Bill's amendment in this particular.

My original reasons for taking the other view-that is, for lending my support in the Committee to the view originally taken by the Opposition to support the Bill-were set out in the course of my remarks on 29 October last year when speaking to the tabling of the Committee report by the then Chairman of the Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, Senator Bolkus. In passing, I should like to congratulate Senator Barney Cooney on now succeeding to the chairmanship of the Committee following Senator Bolkus's translation-I will not say elevation-to the ministerial ranks of the Government. As I say, my reasons for taking a position in the Committee which was originally in line with the formally considered view, and indeed formerly considered view, of the Opposition but which, because of subsequent formal processes in the shadow Cabinet and the joint party room, is now at variance with the present position of the Opposition are already contained in the Hansard of 29 October last year. I shall not weary the Senate by repeating those reasons now. I simply want to say that in these changed circumstances-and particularly given the fine balance of argumentation in the matter on one side or the other in any case-I shall be adhering to the rules of the game and supporting my Opposition colleagues in any division which there may be on this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to oppose the second reading of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Amendment Bill to amend the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act, an Act which has become popularly known-if `popular' is the right word to use in this context-as the AD(JR) Act. Senator Stone has already observed that people listening to this debate this morning may be somewhat mystified by the technicalities of the subject.

SPEECH.PARA: I thought I might just say a few words in opening to explain why these matters are very far from technical matters. This Act and associated Acts, and the amendments that are now proposed by the Government, go to the heart of the rights of citizens against the bureaucracy and against Ministers. The package of legislation which is brought into consideration by these amendments is of enormous importance to Australians. The Senate should be taking this matter very seriously, yet I have noticed that the only speakers in this debate are from this side of the chamber. Not one Australian Labor Party senator has risen to support the Bill. I feel a little sorry for the Minister at the table, the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, who no doubt will have that obligation to speak at the conclusion of the debate. It is extraordinary that the Government supporters are not debating the merits of the Government's proposal.

I am very pleased by the fact that the Opposition has decided to oppose the whole of this Bill and not just to seek to amend it. I believe this Bill does call for some broad judgment about where Parliament should be going in respect of this process of administrative review. Although I concede that there are some arguments in favour of some amendments to this Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act, I do not believe that this Bill is a satisfactory one or that it provides satisfactory amendments. That is why I am opposing it and why the Opposition is opposing it.

I return to the importance of this legislation for all Australians. Over the last 20 years or so there has been an ever-growing concern about the accountability of government. I have not found any diminishment of that concern, and I have been in politics over that 20 or more years period. Indeed, I would say that the concern about government-indeed, a cynicism about government-is more widespread today and felt more strongly by Australian citizens than it was 20 years ago. The reason is basically the ever-growing size of government over those 20 years and the perceived inability of the Parliament itself to control the executive government. We do our best in the Senate at Question Time, through Senate committee exercises, in debates and so forth. Indeed, this chamber has got a more effective record of putting some brakes on government, to make it more accountable, to limit it to some extent, than any other parliamentary chamber in Australia. We should not underestimate the achievements in parliamentary control of the Executive, particularly in the Senate. Nevertheless, the vast size of government and the impact of government on the lives of every person at some stage are of continuing worry. Even if it is decided that the size of government can be reduced-and it ought to be significantly reduced, in my view-I fear the end result will still be the existence of a leviathan and a very widespread impact on individuals.

This Act deals with the decisions that are made by which individuals are aggrieved. We are not talking here about governments bringing in Budgets generally, or implementing economic policies or matters of that kind; we are talking about the impact of government decisions and the application of government policies and legislation on an individual. Those are decisions which, until recent years, did not provide individuals with an adequate opportunity to challenge them. Individuals can litigate in courts if they are aggrieved by attitudes and decisions of other individuals. When it comes to decisions by a government, until recent years-indeed, until the work of the Fraser Government-there were completely inadequate remedies available to citizens in respect of those decisions of government.

The response of the Fraser Government-and my colleague Senator Hill has already mentioned this-was very impressive. I do not want to give a lecture on the general reforms that were introduced by the Fraser Government. However, I must mention them by name. There was the establishment of the Commonwealth Ombudsman in 1976; there was the establishment of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, which gave a right of appeal against the large and, over the years, growing numbers of decisions by Ministers, government or bureaucrats; and there was the Freedom of Information Act, which was brought into effect by the Fraser Government in 1982 and which had a long period of passage through this Parliament, perhaps longer than really necessary and certainly longer than I desired. That could have been in place earlier than it was. Nevertheless, it was finally put in place. In particular, there was the Act we are now discussing, the AD(JR) Act. That was brought into effect in 1980, although it had been passed by this Parliament several years earlier. This Act provides a general legal remedy, a judicial remedy, on the ground that decisions are in one way or another, as spelt out in that Act, contrary to law. The role of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal is in respect of decisions made on the merits-or maladministration, in the case of the Ombudsman. That is a very valuable right of appeal and it is a growing jurisdiction.

This particular Act provides people with a judicial remedy. In other words, under this Act they can allege in the Federal Court that the decision is wrong in law. Prior to that Act being passed there was no adequate general remedy of that kind available to the citizen. So this Act is an enormous advance in expanding the rights of the individual, in the same way as the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and the Freedom of Information Act have been enormous advances in the rights of the individual to get information from government, to really find out what is happening, in the case of freedom of information, and, in the case of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, to actually have reversed by that Tribunal decisions made on the merits. The Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act, which the Government now seeks to amend and whose effect the Government now seeks to reduce, has another important feature, namely, that citizens can demand reasons for decisions by bureaucrats. They were not too keen on giving reasons for decisions until this requirement was put in. They are not too keen on it now. Nevertheless, in this Act there is a legal right to have decisions included.

I hope that the Senate, when it votes on this legislation, will be fully aware as to its great importance-its great importance as part of a package of new, expanded and effective rights that were provided to Australian citizens over the years of the Fraser Government. By contrast, the present Government, the Hawke Labor Government, has been endeavouring to whittle away as much as it possibly can the rights of individuals that have been so carefully put together in the package I have referred to. The Fraser Government attempted in that package to allay the growing concerns about the lack of accountability of government. I am sure that people will be even more concerned when they know the attitude of the Hawke Government to these rights and the attitude of Ministers such as Senator Walsh, whose views on this whole subject are set out very clearly in the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. Senator Walsh, in his role as Minister for Finance, has been doing his level best to reduce the effectiveness of these remedies. He is quoted in the report as being very critical of the process of administrative review.

Senator Walsh has also been very critical of the use of the Freedom of Information Act. A number of Government Ministers have been very critical of the use of that Act. The Government's attempts to whittle down the effectiveness of that Act have taken the form of increasing fees. It is now becoming a very expensive procedure to get the information the right to which the freedom of information legislation gives people. This Government has been trying to whittle down access to that information.

This certainly underlines the wisdom of the remarks of Senator Evans, the first Attorney-General in the Hawke Government, who said that he realised that, unless he got some decent freedom of information legislation on the books early in the life of the Government, there would be no hope of ever doing it once Ministers settled in and decided that they preferred to keep information to themselves and their bureaucrats rather than making it available to people. That was a very prescient remark by Senator Evans about the attitude of this Government to freedom of information. The Government has totally reversed the attitude that it took to freedom of information when it was in opposition. Those opposite complained in opposition that the freedom of information legislation was not good enough; but, as I said, they are now busily trying to make it as ineffective as they possibly can by the imposition of outlandish fees, general obstruction and claiming exemption as often as they possibly can.

The Government has also tried to choke off administrative appeals by imposing a fee of $200 for the review of decisions. The administrative appeals system is supposed to provide a cheap and ready remedy of a semi-judicial but not technical kind-an informal remedy under the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The Government is trying to choke that system off as much as it possibly can. Now in this legislation it is trying to whittle down the rights that have been accorded to people to have adequate judicial review of administrative decisions.

I congratulate the Senate Committee on its most important consideration of this legislation. It is very much on the basis of the findings of that Committee, rather than its recommendations, that the Opposition has now decided to oppose this Bill lock, stock and barrel and not simply to try to amend it. We will, no doubt, hear the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) trying to defend this Bill, saying that it will not have the effect that I claim it will have, that it deals with some abuses of the system that allegedly have been discovered and that it should be supported. I would like to quote the findings of the Senate Committee about these matters. The Senate Committee says, on page 45 of its report:

The Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Amendment Bill will, if enacted, substantially change the nature of the AD (JR) Act-so much so, that the proposed amendments have been described as being contrary to the original purposes of the . . . Act. . . . the Bill will undermine the simple codification of remedies which has characterised the `new' administrative law system.

That is a pretty worrying conclusion for the Committee to have come to. The Committee also finds, in paragraph 5.3, that it has no reason to doubt the conclusion of the Administrative Review Council that the allegations about the abuse of the AD (JR) Act are exaggerated. The Committee says:
. . . there is no evidence to suggest that the AD (JR) Act has attracted `abusive' litigation in a manner which distinguishes it from any other legal process.
I wonder what the Minister will have to say about the so-called abuses, in the light of that finding of the Committee.

The Committee says that, in its view, these proposed amendments will not decrease the cost of reviewing administrative action. That was another claim of the Government. Perhaps the Minister will tell us, in the light of that finding of the Committee, what the Government's views now are. Despite the fact that the Committee was prepared to acknowledge that there may be some need for reform of the court's discretion under the Act, those findings are totally devastating and totally reject the Government's case for bringing in these amendments. They simply make clear what I have said all along: the Government is simply determined slowly to whittle away the effectiveness of this legislation.

The Government does not have the courage to come in here and say, `All those reforms of the administrative law, all the increased rights that were given to Australian citizens by the Fraser Government in its package of legislation, are poppycock. People do not need these rights. We are going to repeal all this legislation'. It knows that these rights are very important to people. It knows that the people would react very unfavourably if it acted along those lines. So it is following the lines that its own former Attorney-General forecast: it will slowly whittle these rights away. That is what this Government is about, and this Bill is just another step in that direction.

The Government says, `We are not repealing the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act; we are just trying to amend it to reverse some abuses that have been identified'. I have said that the abuses have not been identified by independent bodies such as the Senate Committee; nor were they identified to any great extent by the Administrative Review Council, which has found that the claims of abuses were all exaggerated. The Administrative Review Council is the Government's own independent body, established to monitor the whole process of administrative review. The Government's own advisory body does not support the case that the Government is now trying to make with these amendments.

As I have said, there may be some justified complaints about some decisions that have been made. People may have made applications to the courts under this Act when they should not have done so. Certain judges may have been too lenient in some cases and perhaps should have been tougher with litigants and knocked their applications back. Those sorts of mistakes are made at times in the judicial system. But this is a relatively new Act. It came into operation only in 1980. It has not yet had eight years of operation. The courts themselves, I am quite satisfied, will in due course iron out the problems that have cropped up from time to time, although not to any great extent.

There are very clear discretionary powers under the Act by which the judges can limit and deal with frivolous, vexatious or unjustified use of the Act. They are already there. Maybe these provisions have not always been properly interpreted or used by judges, but for the Parliament now to be coming in in this heavy-handed way with these amendments proposed here, which will put the burden of proof on an applicant to show that the interests of justice require the court to deal with his or her case, is totally wrong and it will, as the Senate Committee has found, make substantial changes to the whole system. This system is of enormous benefit to Australian citizens. It should not be whittled down in this way and this Parliament should not now be giving signals to the courts that it is dissatisfied with the way the system is working. By and large the system, for a new system, is working particularly well. It perhaps needs a little more time to settle down and ultimately after proper and full consideration some changes may need to be made. That is common. But at this stage this is certainly not the way to be doing it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I support the motion for the second reading of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Amendment Bill, introduced by the Government in order to undertake some small reform of the administrative review structure which, as Senator Durack has quite rightly pointed out, has operated and been built up in Australia over the last several years. It is a cause for great pride, and it is admired throughout the world as a very systematic and adequate attempt by our democracy to deal with the impact of the many decisions made by government which affect citizens in so many areas of their lives. But to portray this particular proposal, as Senator Durack and some other members of the Opposition have done, as some assault on that system that has been built up over the last decade or so is to overstate the case completely. Senator Durack says that the Government is sending some sort of signal to the judges that it is dissatisfied with what they are doing, but let me remind Senator Durack that the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs quotes on page 37 of its report a letter from the Chief Justice of the Federal Court of Australia, dated 5 August 1987-no doubt he is speaking on behalf of the judges of the Federal Court-saying:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the amendments proposed to be made by the Bill would be likely to be of assistance in weeding out, early, matters which should not have been . . . [taken] to the Federal Court.

So really the Government, conscious of this particular problem facing the Federal Court, it being confronted with applications which are made, in terms of the Chief Justice, too early, has tried to provide some sort of assistance not by ensuring that a person, an Australian citizen, is deprived of the right to go to the Federal Court to seek to ensure that the action taken by government and having an impact on his or her life is indeed in accordance with law, but merely by deferring that approach to the Federal Court until some other remedies, some other administrative law procedures, are fully used and exhausted.

So it cannot be emphasised too much that all we are trying to do is simply to ensure that this whole package is seen by citizens and their legal advisers as a package with a certain sequence which it is appropriate to use. No particular remedy is being denied to anyone by this proposal; it is merely being said that in the ordinary case a person ought to exhaust his or her remedies before, say, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal or some other tribunal before going to the Federal Court on a matter of law, a matter of jurisdiction or whatever.

Of course it also needs to be emphasised that the Federal Court may, despite the fact that those other remedies have not been exhausted, allow the applicant to have his or her day before the Federal Court. We are not imposing an absolute rule. If the Federal Court thinks that the interests of justice require that the matter be dealt with immediately, that can be done. All we are saying is that the applicant ought to be made to show to the Court that the interests of justice do so require. So I think we need to get things in perspective, and to reiterate what I think was a reasonable point made by the Opposition-namely, that we have a very extensive package of ways by which a citizen is protected against being subjected to administrative decisions which are either unmeritorious in regard to the actual decision making on the substance of the case or are made without due regard to the legal parameters which ought to be observed-it is a package, a system, and it ought to be seen as such. It is with the view that it is an overall package that this proposal has been put before the chamber.

I think Senator Macklin in the course of the debate asked me to deal with why the Bill goes somewhat further than the changes recommended by the Administrative Review Council. As I recall, the Administrative Review Council recommendation was that the Court ought to have the discretion to refuse an application in certain specified circumstances, unless it is in the interests of justice not to do so. We take a slightly stronger view, that if there is an alternative to court action it should be taken. But, as I say, we really do not make it an absolute rule, and if the interests of justice require that the matter be dealt with by the FederalCourt--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a wonder the matter does not have to be proved beyond a reasonable doubt. That is your next step.
—The honourable senator knows that it is not beyond a reasonable doubt.
—I am saying it is a wonder you have not done that.

—We have not because we are not trying to destabilise the system in the way that Senator Durack wishes to suggest. But we do believe that, having established a system of administrative review which does provide a comprehensive review of administrative action, recourse to the processes of judicial review could be deferred in certain situations.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that refusal by the Federal Court under this proposal can occur only where there is an alternative avenue of appeal. That has to be emphasised. As I say, there is no absolute exclusion of the right to have a matter dealt with by the Federal Court. The Federal Court itself sees merit in this proposal and, as Senator Stone pointed out, so did the Opposition when its spokesman, Mr Spender, supported the Bill some time ago in the House of Representatives. I do not deny that a Senate committee can, in its more leisurely procedures, perhaps come to another conclusion but it cannot be said, particularly in light of Senator Stone's dissent from the Senate Committee's report, that there is really anything untoward in the Government pressing its Bill in the chamber this afternoon.

I wish to emphasise, finally, that it is not the intention of this legislation to deprive litigants of their rights but, as the Government said in originally responding to the Committee's report, to strike an appropriate balance between the need to ensure efficient and economic use of administrative review processes and the rights of citizens to have access to the judicial review of administrative action where in the opinion of the Court the interests of justice so require. That is what we have attempted to do. We have struck the balance in a particular way which has not found favour with the Senate Committee and it has not found favour, apparently now, with the coalition parties and the Australian Democrats. In that situation the Government really wants a hasty dispatch of this matter, so I think at this stage the best thing to do is to have the question put.
Question put:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.
