SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Ministers of State Amendment Bill 1988 provides that Ministers of State should receive the same increases in remuneration as members of parliament as determined by the Remuneration Tribunal in its most recent determination. The Bill is not unusual in that the Australian Constitution does not permit ministerial salaries to be dealt with in the same way as the salaries of members of parliament but requires funds to be specifically determined by a legislative Act of this Parliament, and that is why the Bill is before us today.

SPEECH.PARA: It follows the recommendations made with respect to members generally for a 3.8 per cent increase to take effect from 1 July 1987 as a first step towards resolution of the agreed anomaly which the Tribunal found has existed since 1984. In that sense the legislation is uncontentious except to the extent that members of the public might think that members of parliament and Ministers alike should not receive any money, let alone an increase.

However, there is an additional element. The Government, in its recent ministerial changes, increased the maximum number of Ministers from 27 to 30. Therefore, part of the funds being appropriated is affected by that increase in the size of the Ministry as determined by the Government. The Opposition did not support the increase in the size of the Ministry, and consistent with our view that there is already an excessively burdensome cost of government in this country we have argued in favour of smaller ministries. In one of the rare divisions between the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia the Liberal Party argued against an increase in the size of Parliament on the basis that the whole structure of government was extremely expensive. We were additionally concerned that the increase in the ordinary representation of senators for each State from 10 to 12 made it very unlikely that either of the major parties would hold a majority in the Senate except under quite extraordinary political circumstances. Of course, that is totally incidental to this legislation.

The concerns of the Opposition with the enlarged Ministry related not merely to the added cost of salaries, which are dealt with here and are not large in terms of the total outlays of the Government-I think the additional appropriations amount to something like $65,000-but also to the additional costs that would flow through to the new Parliament House as a result of the need to revise accommodation. I think some $1.5m in additional cost was incurred in making changes to accommodate the new Ministers.

In what I think will be a very brief debate on a Bill which in its essence is not particularly contentious, I just remind the Senate of our objection to seeing the size of the Ministry increase substantially just to meet the problems that the Government has with respect to keeping its factions in good order. We have seen some rather extraordinary changes being made. I am sure you, Mr Acting Deputy President, would recall the events that I want to remind the Senate of. Elections in the Caucus had to be reconsidered because it was thought that the right balance between factions and between men and women had not been achieved. There was a lot of jockeying around: Senator Bolkus was in the Ministry and then out of it, and Senator Reynolds was brought in as one of the necessary changes to ensure that the Labor Party had that vital requirement of four ministries being held by women.

It is very interesting to look back over those few months and remember what was said by the Labor Party and by Mr Hawke about how essential it was to have four women in the Ministry, and to see we are now back to three again. With the departure of Senator Ryan, for some reason the urgent necessity to have that additional woman seems to have evaporated. Of course, Senator Tate was not in the Ministry and then suddenly was there. I remind the Senate of these matters not to be unpleasant in any sense but simply to indicate that there is a great deal of cynicism on this side of the chamber about the reasons why the increase in the size of the Ministry was effected by the Government. We believe that the way in which these new ministries was handled is a pretty clear indication that it had a lot more to do with the internal smooth running of the Labor Party than it had to do with the smooth running of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —That translates into better government.

—I hear an interjection from Senator Collins that this translates into better government, and I suppose there is some truth in that: keeping the factions quiet may well be an important element of ensuring good government. All I can say is that I very much doubt that there is electoral support for increasing the costs and burdens of government for that reason.

SPEECH.PARA: In that context, I simply remind the Senate that that is one of the reasons why this Government is taking successive political blows from the electorate-and there have been too many of them now for the Government to feel that it is just a matter of bad luck on a particular day. That is the response that the Government has had: again it lost ground in the most recent by-election in Queensland; it lost ground severely in two by-elections in South Australia; and Labor lost government in New South Wales.

TALK.START.PARA: —One point one preferred in Queensland.

—Senator Ray conveniently picks up the independent as being part of the Labor vote. All that I would say is that even in the circumstance where there was some very difficult internal differences within the National Party, the Labor Party certainly did not pick up any ground. So, I do not think there is anything that the Labor Party could be cheered about. The serious point that I wish to make in the context of electoral reversals in Western Australia, South Australia, New South Wales, and the two lots in Queensland, is that in my view there is a significant difficulty for the Labor Party in looking after its own, in being seen to look after its own, and in not being seen to be looking after its constituency. This legislation, which in part requires additional expenditure for additional ministerial positions which meet the internal requirements of the Labor Party, has nothing to do with the public perception of what is required for good government in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: I have said before in this Senate that I have a high respect for Senator McMullan, a very fine Western Australian now here representing the Australian Capital Territory (ACT). One might say, `What has he really got to do with the ACT?'. Senator Richardson came from a position in the Labor Party bureaucracy in New South Wales-and from the way that they have behaved over the past week I would have to say we would welcome them as members of the Liberal Party bureaucracy, as they are doing so much good for us-and translated to the Party bureaucracy of this Senate, as did Senator Schacht, Senator Beahan and Senator Aulich. I would only say that that, and the fact that 27 trade union representatives have found themselves a comfortable home in this Parliament, is all part of a pattern against which the people of Australia are revolting.

The Liberal Party does not propose to vote against this legislation, to prevent Ministers being paid, because quite clearly, since they hold these ministerial offices and run the great risk of being dismissed from them for failure to administer well, they should at least get the danger money that the ministerial salary involves. So, there is no intention on our part to vote against this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are being sanctimonious.

—When I hear a Labor senator saying that it is sanctimonious to raise these issues, I can only say that that in turn reflects the lack of contact that Labor Party members of parliament now have with the Australian community. I have absolutely no doubt that there is very great sympathy in the Australian community for the views that I have just expressed in this place. The Labor Party will not have the support of the community where it is seen to be looking after its own instead of looking after the needs of the constituency that elected it. I think that this legislation is merely one further indication of the fact that Labor members may not have made Australia a very good place for many Australians but they have certainly made Australia a very good place for themselves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In summing up the debate I make the following points: The point has been made about the size of the Ministry quite properly here because, in fact, the Ministers of State Bill allocates the additional expenditure, not just the adjustment for a national wage case. I do not think any of us here would dispute that this Bill is correct and proper in regard to the national wage case. It is a penalty put in the Constitution by our forefathers to give Oppositions a free kick once a year-and sometimes twice a year, depending on the wage rises.

SPEECH.PARA: I point out that in 1971 the coalition Government had 27 Ministers and six Assistant Ministers, which was 17.8 per cent of the Parliament. Indeed, in 1982 the Ministry comprised 15.3 per cent of the Parliament, while in 1988 the figure is 13.4 per cent. Senator Chaney says that the only reason for the expansion of the Ministry from 27 to 30 was a purely factional thing. I deny that. It may have had a role in the decisions to want to accommodate the degree of talent that we have on this side of the Parliament, but I point out that one of the very strong arguments that I advanced for expanding the size of the Ministry concerned the position in this chamber. From 1983 to 1987 we had six Ministers in this chamber. As to such things as chamber duty, the point was that five were members of the Cabinet and more often than not when Cabinet was sitting we had one Minister remaining in this chamber to carry the whole work load.

Also, by spreading the load of representing Ministers in another place we have afforded the Opposition the opportunity-not always taken up-to have questions answered rather than put on notice. I will not say that we are totally blameless in this regard of putting some questions on notice. Nevertheless, the new arrangement has had that effect. We do, of course, make the link-although it is not an absolute link-that the reforms we brought about in 1987 mean a reduction in the average staff level of 3,000, with savings of $105m. Compared to the cost of the extra Ministers, that has at least allowed the public to get well and truly out in front in terms of financial savings.

Senator Chaney said that Caucus held an election and then had to change the position. That is not quite true. Caucus held an election and determined the result. It was not changed. Changes in preselection of who would run for the Ministry may have been altered by other directives from on high, but certainly Caucus did not reverse its decision. This raises the question of which is the healthier process: is it a more healthy process to have members of parliament elect the Ministry or is it better just to have one leader select the Ministry? Which system is better? I maintain that our system is better, for on the side of politics of those opposite it is almost like a papal infallibility; they elect a leader and then that person has all power to allocate positions. It is not a proposal that we on our side accept. Warts and all, we prefer our system of public head butting, factional manoeuvring, et cetera, but to leave the basic decision to members of the Caucus. The difficulty with the Liberal system is that it leads to sycophancy. It leads to patronage far more than even on the Labor side.

We see the results in this Senate. There are at least two people sitting on the back bench who should be sitting on the front bench. Michael Baume, a very capable senator whom I quite often argue and disagree with, was thrown to the Peacock wolves. When the sled was too heavy and the Peacock wolves were chasing Mr Howard in 1987, Michael Baume was thrown over the side to feed them.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the kiss of death.

—He was brought into this chamber as shadow Minister for health and asked to sell an impossibility in the time period he had. He did not succeed in selling it but otherwise his performance in this place I have always found has been relatively high. I fight like cats and dogs with him but I am very pleased he is not sitting on the front bench. Another couple of people sitting on the back bench I think should obviously be on the front bench. I would not be so crass as to name who should disappear from the front bench to the back bench. I am not going to, as Senator Chaney said, put the kiss of death on their future promotion in the Liberal Party. I think that would be most unfair.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chaney for the second time has referred to Senator McMullan. He asked what right he has to be in this chamber. Senator McMullan has lived in the Australian Capital Territory since 1981. Prior to that he lived in Senator Chaney's State and probably the jealousy factor comes in and Senator Chaney wants to knife an old boy from his State-probably because he came out and endorsed Senator Chaney against Allan Rocher and helped cruel Senator Chaney's chances for preselection. Senator Reid, who again is a competent senator, had South Australia as her place of origin, as we all know.

TALK.START.PARA: —Crystal Brook.

—Crystal Brook, I am informed. That has not impaired her performance in this chamber. I suppose there is the irony of whether party officials should be debarred from entering this chamber, whether it is just a pay-off. Senator Chaney would be aware that Senator McMullan had to face a rank and file preselection in the Australian Capital Territory against a local and he was chosen by the Labor Party locally. This raises a chicken and egg argument. Do people become party officials because they are talented or do they get into Parliament just because they are party officials? I tend to rely on the former.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, it is not as though the Liberal Party of Australia has never sent public officials here. When I was first elected to this chamber Sir John Carrick was the Leader of the Government. I think he was one of the finest representatives of the Liberal Party ever to be in this chamber. I have said that to him and I believe it. He was party secretary from 1949 to 1971. Did that inhibit his performance in this chamber? Did he represent the electors of New South Wales well? Of course he did. We have Mr Jim Carlton, another former secretary of the New South Wales Liberal Party. Apart from his numeracy, I assume he has adequately represented the people in his electorate relatively well.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Gary Neat?

—As Senator Maguire has pointed out, Gary Neat ran as a candidate. Quite often party officials will serve. Just because they become party officials does not mean that ipso facto they are divorced from the community, are not active in the community and are not good representatives. Various presidents of the Liberal Party have been elected to this Parliament-Senator Alston, Mr Peacock; need I go on. Mr Alston had to have four or five goes at winning preselection. It is not an easy task. But I assume he did not miss out on the first few occasions simply because he had been party president.
—John Elliott is on his way.

—We might have more Liberal Party officials here, the apparatchiks as Senator Chaney likes to refer to them. In my State there has been such a succession of failures in the position of State director or State secretary that no-one has been promoted to the Senate or the House of Representatives.
—Senator Hill is here, too.

—I think Senator Hill achieved his greatness after he came here. He was South Australian president and campaign director against the Bannon Government, which has seen the largest Labor majority in South Australian history. However, we will trade most of these points across the chamber. I believe that the expansion of the Ministry from 27 to 30 is justifiable on grounds other than factional convenience. I believe the task in government becomes harder and harder as the Federal responsibilities and areas that it gets into are wider. I think a team of 30 is not unreasonable. In proportion to the responsibility of State Ministers or those in any other country, I think it weighs up relatively well.

SPEECH.PARA: I might say that the figure of 30 will probably be inviolable in future for anyone who is thinking of a future expansion. There are 30 suites in the executive wing of the new Parliament House. There is no room for any more. I would suggest that more than anything else will predetermine not only that there will be no more increases in the Ministry; it will be very difficult, I would suggest, to have an increase in the size of Parliament simply because we have built an expensive building that is supposed to last for 200 years and there is not room for any more there. I know that the Liberal Party opposed the expansion in 1983. It was not an unreasonable expansion compared with State parliaments. There had not been an expansion of Federal Parliament since 1949. One of Senator Chaney's last points was that that expansion meant that no party could get a majority in this chamber. That may be true. I am not sure that under the previous system anyone was likely to.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would require unusual or extraordinary circumstances.

—The perverse thing is that the real chance for someone to get a majority here is in a double dissolution rather than in separate Senate elections. However, in general, having answered those points, I think the Bill should have a relatively speedy passage. I thank Senator Chaney for his contribution.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations to comments yesterday by the Minister for the Arts and Territories, Mr Punch, in which, referring to employers and unions involved in the Quadrant building dispute, he said:

QUESTION.PARA: Both ought to come to their senses, stop this petty squabbling, childish fighting, sit around the table, work out their differences, get on with the industry in Canberra.

I ask: How can the Government possibly bracket both parties to this dispute in the way that he did, bearing in mind the total condemnation of union behaviour by Commissioner Baird of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission? Is the Minister aware that the Commissioner has said, `There is almost no credibility with the undertakings by the union'? Is he aware that Commissioner Baird has also said, `It has gone beyond the normal industrial relationship' and that he has `leaned over backwards to ensure that the union's position was put'? In view of Commissioner Baird's condemnation of union conduct in this dispute, after which he directed that all bans be lifted, why does Mr Punch seek to apportion equal responsibility for the events on the Quadrant site to the employer and the employees? Does the Minister agree that it is uncontestable, from Commissioner Baird's findings, that the unions will have no part of the round table approach suggested by Mr Punch and that the Minister's comments yesterday are both meaningless and misleading? Will the Government indicate its support for resolute action against this disgraceful use of standover tactics by rogue elements of the trade union movement?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not see great value in being judgmental and allocating blame by percentages, or anything like that, to particular parties in industrial disputes. Probably Mr Punch, in saying what he did, had much the same sort of view. I only have to remind Senator Chaney that earlier this week he asked me questions about this issue in which he repeated allegations of criminality against certain people and then said, `What is the Government doing about that?'. I think in yesterday's answer I indicated to Senator Chaney that if criminal matters are involved, the appropriate people to make allegations of criminality are those who are the victims of them, and to the police. As long ago as 30 March Government spokesmen were advising the Master Builders Association to do that, and it did not do it.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not know what Mr Punch meant by saying that both parties ought to come to their senses, but if that is the situation which the employers are alleging, they should take the appropriate action in relation to the allegations of criminality and do what has been suggested to them, rather than refer the matter back to this Government, whose functions is not to be a universal pimp in respect of allegations of criminality. In spite of that, the Government has taken the action which I referred to yesterday.

I am not here to argue any brief for the unions involved. The conduct which has been publicised and referred to in Senator Chaney's questions is disgraceful conduct and is not conduct one would expect in the normal concourse of an industrial relationship. I am not able to interpret Minister Punch's mind any further than that other than to say that he is indicating his view that both parties have some responsibilities in this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. My supplementary question relates to the inconsistency in the Minister's reply. He started by saying that there is no value in being judgmental in these matters and then went on to concede that what had been drawn to his attention appeared to be disgraceful conduct. I ask the Minister: Has he or any other Minister in the Government examined the record of the hearings before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, to which I referred in my question, a record which shows quite clearly disgraceful conduct on behalf of a series of trade unions and a lack of capacity by the parties to deal with this matter in the way that Minister Punch is now recommending? Has any Minister examined this matter and considered whether appropriate remedies are available? Will the Government, in the light of this clear demonstration of disgraceful conduct, stand behind the parties who are being subjected to this industrial blackmail and attack?

—I have not read the transcript of the Arbitration Commission hearing. I am sure that other Ministers have, but I have not. I will just rely on what Senator Chaney tells me is in it. On the basis of his reporting of what is in it--
—You seem vaguely amused. You should read it. It would take the smile off your face.

—Perhaps Senator Chaney should handle this dispute himself. He would fix it up overnight, as he did the Social Security Department. We all remember that one. I have not read the transcript. I rely on what Senator Chaney says about it. Having said that, I really do not have much to add to the answer which I gave before. There have been all sorts of allegations in Senator Chaney's questions and I have responded to most of them. I do not know that I can take the matter any further than that. There is a remedy available to the employers if they want to exercise it.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CUSTOMS AND IMMIGRATION OFFICIALS: TREATMENT OF INCOMING WOMEN PASSENGERS

TALK.START.PARA: —Did the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs see a report on Australian Broadcasting Corporation television last night alleging improper treatment of a young Thai woman who was stripped at Sydney Airport, searched and sent to Villawood Detention Centre? Will the Minister investigate the way in which this young woman was treated and ensure that Customs and immigration officials treat incoming women passengers with appropriate dignity and respect?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not see the television report of this incident but I have heard about it. Senator Colston raised it with me yesterday. This morning I sought information about it. I am advised that, while going through Customs at Sydney Airport, the young woman was selected for examination, which eventually involved a body search. The body search involved the removal of clothing. The body search was conducted by female Customs officers only, as is normal in the case of women and girls. During the search, correspondence was found on the young woman's person which indicated that, although she had a visitor's visa, she planned to remain permanently in Australia. This matter was referred to an immigration inspector. Following an interview by the immigration inspector, it was decided that the young woman should be refused entry. She was, therefore, detained in custody at Villawood Detention Centre pending her transfer from Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: As to whether Customs and immigration officials treat women passengers with dignity and respect, I am advised that the Australian Customs Service has instituted standard procedures designed to ensure that this occurs in these circumstances. Immigration officials also operate under guidelines designed to ensure that all individuals are treated with appropriate dignity and respect. Senator Peter Baume will recall that he raised an incident recently during the Estimates hearings. He will be pleased, I am sure, to receive some information about that matter shortly.

TALK.START.PARA: —In due course.

—In due course. I appreciate Senator Colston's concern. I am sure that all honourable senators would want to be reassured on this matter. I can assure Senator Colston that I will be continuing my discussions about this incident with my colleague Mr Holding and will advise him in due course.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer him to the reply supplied by the Minister for Industrial Relations following Senator Chaney's question on Monday of this week about the Quadrant building site in Canberra. While I welcome the decision to institute a police inquiry into allegations of criminal behaviour in that matter, to which the Minister has referred, I refer the Minister to Mr Willis's criticism of the Master Builders Association (MBA) because it had not:

QUESTION.PARA: sought to obtain a bans clause to activate the compliance provisions of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act.

I take it, incidentally, that that is what the Minister had in mind when, in response to Senator Chaney a few minutes ago, he asserted that the MBA-I think I have the quote right-`had a remedy available to it'. I ask the Minister whether he is aware that when his colleague in the other place introduced his industrial relations Bill on 14 May last year, the same Mr Willis referred to that bans clause procedure in the following words-I quote from the second reading speech:
. . . the present bans clause provisions which have long since fallen in to disrepute and are now substantially moribund.

What point would there have been in the Master Builders Association seeking to use procedures which, in the words of the Minister himself, `have long since fallen into disrepute and are now substantially moribund'? Does the Minister agree that there is an urgent need for new procedures which will permit direct reference of defiance of Commission rulings to the ordinary courts as, I note, were contained in the Bill introduced into the Senate last November by my colleague Senator Chaney?

TALK.START.PARA: —As I recall Mr Willis's answer to Senator Chaney's question, I thought the answer was that the MBA had not exhausted the processes of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. I was not aware that it specifically referred to bans clauses, but if Senator Stone says that it also refers to bans clauses I accept that. In so far as the question relates to the second reading speech on a Bill which was abandoned by the Government last year, I am not able to comment on that. I think that there are bans clauses still inserted into awards and consequences follow from breaches of those bans clauses. Whether or not it is a fair characterisation as moribund, I am not sure. It depends on the circumstances. On the question of new procedures, I do not want to prejudge anything that the Minister might introduce in the new Industrial Relations Bill which I understand is to be introduced into the Parliament shortly, but I suspect, without being able to flag in detail the contents of that Bill, that it will address some of the issues to which Senator Stone referred.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. What is the progress on the study or studies into the standardisation of the Adelaide-Melbourne railway-the only mainland capital railway line not now on a standard gauge basis-being conducted by Australian National and Victorian Rail? What are the latest cost estimates for the various options of converting the line from broad gauge to standard gauge, and what are those options?

—A preliminary evaluation and standardisation of the Adelaide to Melbourne rail link was completed in May 1983 by the Australian National Railways Commission and the Victorian State Transport Authority. This showed that the project could be economically viable under certain conditions. A further assessment of the project was required to sort out fundamental differences between the two systems on capital cost, potential markets and new traffic likely to be generated. These differences between the two systems have not yet been resolved although the assessment of options is ongoing. The overall estimated cost-the present day cost based on 1983 parameters-of standardisation of the line between Melbourne and Adelaide, including the Mount Gambier line, is $250m. Since late 1985, Australian National studies have focused on alternatives to standardisation, in particular, improvement of clearance and transit times.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations aware that it is alleged that officials of the Waterside Workers Federation in Melbourne are visiting businesses to encourage them to advertise in publications of the union, with a minimum cost of $500 per advertisement, and telling these business representatives that, if they do not place advertisements, the Waterside Workers Federation cannot guarantee that goods imported or exported by their businesses will not be substantially delayed on the docks? Have there been reports of such practices in the past? If so, can the Minister comment on how widespread this practice is in respect of other Australian ports? Is the Government prepared to do anything about it?

—This allegation was brought to my attention shortly before I came into Question Time. Knowing as I do the leadership of the Waterside Workers Federation in Melbourne, I have the gravest difficulty in believing the story. I regard the leadership in the port of Melbourne as being people of considerable integrity. I cannot answer for every waterside worker in the port of Melbourne, but I am talking about the leadership of the Waterside Workers Federation in that State.
—Or any publishing company.

—As Senator Childs appropriately interjects, sometimes organisations such as the Waterside Workers Federation, as do businesses, engage consultants or PR people to look after their journals and so on for them. There has been substantial evidence on all sides of the fence of malpractice in the hands of those sorts of people soliciting business by threat. Having made those comments, I certainly will have the matter investigated. It is something which no government could approve. In regard to the suggestion contained in the honourable senator's question that this practice might be widespread, I have no information about that at all. I think it unlikely.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer, relates to the tax treatment of capital gains made by senior executives of takeover target companies when they accept offers for shares they have acquired through special executive incentive schemes. Is it a fact that capital gains of a size which is very large by comparison to the incomes of ordinary Australian workers can be realised in this way? Is it a fact that, prior to the Government's reform of the tax system, such capital gains were taxed at rates far lower than those applied to the incomes of ordinary Australian workers? Is the Minister aware that Mr John Elliott, head of Elders IXL and President of the Liberal Party of Australia, has been calling for the abolition of capital gains taxation in Australia? What sorts of incentives would such an abolition provide to the senior executives of companies such as Elders IXL, Elders Resources, et cetera?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The second last part of the question asked whether it is a fact that Mr Elliott has been calling for the abolition of capital gains tax. I understand that that is a fact, and also that he has been calling for the abolition of the fringe benefits tax and a few other things. He wants to replace all those taxes with a tax on football tickets and meat pies that people munch in the outer at the Princes Park football ground, while he is sitting up in the Fosters box with his Vat 69, his free lunch and his free ticket to the footie.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the more substantial part of the question, yes, it is a fact that very large capital gains can be realised in the shonky way outlined in the question. Last week the Melbourne Age reported that the Chief Executive of Elders Resources-not Mr Elliott, incidentally-a Mr Lord, was the holder of 3.5 million 1c partly paid shares in that company as a result of a special executive incentive measure. According to the Age report, the 3.5 million shares were obtained by Mr Lord for an outlay of just over $35,000. He has now accepted a friendly takeover offer from New Zealand Forest Products and stands to receive $5.28m for the $35,000 outlay, which is certainly a tidy profit.

With regard to the capital gains taxation aspects, I understand that not all of the 3.5 million shares had been purchased before 15 September 1985, which I think was the operative date. Therefore, Mr Lord will have to pay capital gains tax on whatever number of shares have been purchased since then. Because of the grandfathering provisions, those which were purchased before that date will not be subject to capital gains tax. Of course, there would be no fairness in exempting that portion of the transaction upon which he is liable to pay capital gains tax from capital gains tax, as John Elliott and others would have us do, through the abolition of capital gains taxes. So there is no fairness in the abolish capital gains tax proposition. It has nothing to commend it on grounds of economic efficiency, either.

I was asked what incentives the abolition of capital gains tax would provide for senior executives of large business enterprises. There are two answers to that aspect of the question, depending on whether the takeover bids under those circumstances were friendly or unfriendly. As far as unfriendly takeover bids are concerned, it would give senior executives in inefficient, moribund companies an incentive to provide themselves with a golden parachute. They could walk away from their companies with huge tax free lump sums if their companies were the subject of successful takeover bids-which would, of course, inhibit the efficiency improving features which the takeover mechanism is claimed to have. If there were friendly takeovers, it would give senior executives an incentive to use friendly takeovers as an opportunity for lining their own pockets at the expense of the taxpayers and all the other shareholders whose interests those senior executives are supposed to protect. That is, of course, exactly what John Elliott did when he engineered the friendly takeover of Henry Jones IXL Ltd by Elders under the taxation system presided over by Mr Howard-an action which, incidentally, led to a comment in the Melbourne Age by Terry McCrann, who by no stretch of the imagination could be regarded as a friend of the present Government, the Australian Labor Party, or anything very far removed from the far right of Australian politics. Terry McCrann said of Elders takeover of Henry Jones:
Nevertheless, the fact that Elder Smith took over Henry Jones, rather than the reverse, did have some beneficial spin-offs for Mr Elliott and a number of other colleagues.
Shortly before Elder Smith unveiled its bid for Henry Jones, the leading executives in Henry Jones outlaid $19,000 in taking up 1c paid shares under an executive incentive scheme.
The Elder Smith offer delivered a clear-tax-free-profit of $4.16 million to those executives. Mr Elliott himself cleared $657,000 on a $3000 outlay.

Mr Lord is following the example that John Elliott established. He has done it partly at the expense of honest taxpayers, as did Mr Elliott, and partly at the expense of all the other shareholders in the target company whose interests he was supposed to protect. Of course, Mr Elliott would cover the revenue losses from this sort of shonky business activity, as I said before, by making people in the outer at Princes Park pay tax on their meat pies and footie tickets.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations noted today's reports that unions representing 140,000 public servants will seek an across the board pay rise of at least 6 per cent from the Federal Government? Is the Government concerned that these unions, along with those in the metal and building industries-the latter's claim was the subject of Senator Chaney's question of the Minister yesterday-are trying to stitch up pay deals in advance of consideration of new wages guidelines? Will the Government give an undertaking that it will not agree to any pay rise for its own employees before completion of the review of the wages system by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission? Will he confirm to the Senate that that review is scheduled to begin next month and that, as the Commission said in its 1987 wage case judgment, the existing principles will apply until the review is completed? In other words, will he confirm that, despite the spate of recent claims and union pressure to settle ahead of any new guidelines, claims now being pursued are subject to the existing guidelines, including the no extra claims commitment?

—The short answer to the question is yes. The claim by the Public Service unions that Senator Chapman referred to has not been considered by the Government. The answer to whether the existing guidelines apply until such time as the national wage case bench considers new guidelines is yes.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce been drawn to the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) figures released on Monday which show a significant increase in research and development being performed by business and industry? Can the Minister explain whether these are one-off increases or part of a trend. Can the Minister tell the Senate where in industry the greatest increases are occurring? What is the Government doing to improve industry's research and development performance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In some ways the question is a statistical one and in that sense boring but it does go to the heart of Australia's economic redevelopment and the new information to which Senator McMullan referred. I did not mean that Senator McMullan was boring; I meant that the answer was going to be boring. Opposition senators can nod off for a minute or two, if they like, if they are not already asleep. The new information shows that research and development expenditure in Australian business stood at just over $1,082m in 1986-87, an increase from $374m in 1981-82. That represents a real increase of 85 per cent since 1981-82. That does not mean that those figures are good enough, but the trend in respect of research and development expenditure is encouraging.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator McMullan asked where the expenditure appeared to be taking place. I make the observation that the greatest increase in research and development is occurring in the high technology and information industry areas. While research and development expenditure is increasing at an annual rate of 12 per cent for business generally, in these areas the rate is more than double that figure. These are the industries which are dominated by young, forward looking firms which do not rely on tariff protection but which see the world as their market. It is also true that these sorts of firms are providing the means of creating greater efficiency within our traditional industries. They are the providers of new systems-essentially in the services sector-relating to productivity and efficiency in manufacturing. They are also prepared to patent and register their ideas and to export new ideas and products to provide Australia with valuable export income.

I make the point more emphatically that the figures for payments and receipts for technical know-how are increasing significantly. These figures represent the money being paid and received for licensing of patents and other forms of technology transfer. The ABS figures show that we are paying more for registered knowledge and technology-40 per cent more-than we were. Importantly, they also show that over the last two years Australian firms have increased their receipts from technical know-how by 108 per cent, from $36m to $87m. The point I am simply seeking to make is that we are increasingly deriving an economic benefit from research and development investment and are progressively shifting the balance of technological know-how. This is quite apparent from the ratio of receipts to payments for technology transfer, which has gone up from 13 per cent in 1981-82 to 33 per cent in 1986-87.

In referring to private sector investment in research and development, let me again make the point that while there is a significant improvement, which I have indicated, it is not good enough. The research and development budget of the whole of the private sector in Australia is about the same as the research and development budget of a company such as Hewlett Packard in the United States-one company in the United States compared with the whole of the private sector research and development budget in Australia. Of course, there are reasons for that. In the past the incentives environment has been wrong and certainly, if the private sector is able to indulge in an overreliance on public sector research and development, it will not take the opportunities which it ought to take in respect of its own research and development. The figures are encouraging and show the right directions and steady progress, but I add the caveat that they are not yet good enough.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. Can the Minister provide any explanation for the extraordinary delay in finalising the Australian Federal Police (AFP) investigation into the Harris-Daishowa (Australia) Pty Ltd campaign donation to the Australian Labor Party, an investigation which began 2 1/2 months ago? In particular, can the Minister state whether police are still interviewing or seeking to interview anyone? —Don't try to snow us.
—I resent the interjection, `Don't try to snow us'.
—That is Jim Snow.

—I know. I do not think the honourable senator has any allegation against him or inference in that respect. The AFP conducted an investigation into a possible breach of the Commonwealth Electoral Act relating to the Harris-Daishowa donation. As honourable senators will know, and as I think this came up at the Estimates committee, that report was forwarded by way of a brief of evidence to the Director of Public Prosecutions. —I have no idea when the police will provide the further information to the DPP.

—I am not trying to interfere in the conduct of this operation by the Australian Federal Police at the further request of the Director of Public Prosecutions. The decision as to the investigation of this matter is entirely within the competence, and properly so, of the investigating officers and their superior officers in the Federal Police.

—Has the attention of the Minister representing the Treasurer been drawn to the document released on Sunday, 17 April, by the Business Council of Australia (BCA) titled Government Expenditure Control-1988-89? Does that document argue that overall macro-economic policy-making in Australia would be facilitated if State governments were to improve the accounting framework they use in presenting their own budgetary data? Does the Minister agree with the BCA on this matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have had my attention drawn to that section of the document and it does indeed argue that economic policy-making in Australia would be enhanced if the State governments were to follow the example of the Commonwealth and publish data using the type of accounting framework that is currently used by the Commonwealth. The BCA also argues that the States should follow the example set by this Government, the present Federal Government, in publishing Forward Estimates of expenditure, something which the previous Government and the previous Treasurer squibbed on doing, principally I suppose because they did not want anybody to know the sort of impending Budget deficit or blow-out in outlays that they were leaving behind them when they were ignominiously kicked out of office early in 1983.

ANSWER.PARA: I certainly agree with the conclusion of the BCA that the publication of that sort of information makes for a better informed society and is likely to lead to better outcomes, but in some respects it does not go far enough. It does not make any mention of the sort of dodgy accounting practice used by some State governments, predictably Queensland being the most spectacular example, which imposes hidden taxes on mining companies via excessive rail freights, which enables the Queensland Government to fiddle both sides of its Budget; that is, to present a misleadingly low figure on outlays and a misleadingly low figure on taxation. If the Queensland Government were to adopt the practice adopted by any set of accountants who aim to inform the public rather than misinform the public and were to levy a tax explicitly on Queensland mining companies or somewhere else, that would certainly be an improvement. The method that the Queensland Government uses to complete the mechanism to fiddle both its outlays and receipts is, of course, that the hidden tax collected from mining companies via excessive rail freights is then used to cross-subsidise the loss making sections of the Queensland railways, keeping the whole operation off-Budget when it should be on-Budget. In other States that sort of subsidisation of unprofitable railways is explicit.

The only other comment I want to make is that I hope, once again, that Senator Stone uses his influence with the Queensland National Party to ensure that the State Government in Queensland adopts a superior-both economically and morally-system of accounting. If I remember correctly, Senator Stone was not too keen on publishing Forward Estimates in 1983, so I am not so confident that he will actually use his undoubted influence on the Queensland Government to get it to behave more honestly than it has behaved in the past.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. In any taxation rate changes to be made in May or August this year, will the Government confirm that the alignment of the top personal income rate with the company tax rate will be maintained? Does the Government stand by the Treasurer's statement of 19 September 1985 when he referred to `the vital innovation of aligning the top personal income tax rate with the company tax rate'? The Treasurer went on to say:

QUESTION.PARA: In a stroke, this-
that is, the alignment of rates-
will make a whole host of tax avoidance devices futile.
If the Government lowers the company tax rate, will it lower personal tax rates simultaneously, or will it be content, in Mr Keating's words, to tolerate a fresh incentive to tax avoidance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been asked to give a guarantee that the present identity, although it is not quite an identity at the moment, between the top personal taxation rate and the company tax rate will be preserved. No, I will not give any such guarantee that that will happen, nor am I making any predictions about where the company tax rate or the top personal tax rate might finish up. However, as the Treasurer stated in 1985, if there is a very big gap between the top personal rate and the corporate rate, there is some risk that people will find ways of exploiting the system in order to evade the taxation that they ought to be paying. One thing which this Government will have to be particularly careful of is that opportunities are not opened up for such people to exploit the tax system in that way. I have no doubt that the one who would be up to his ears in exploiting any loophole that opened up would of course be the Federal President of the Liberal Party.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Senator Walsh is continually using Question Time, clearly quite irrelevant of any question he might be asked, simply to attack anybody who is in any way showing support for the Liberal Party. I do not hear him raising the affairs of the Prime Minister's rich mates. That seems to be totally beyond Senator Walsh. He is very keen on attacking anyone who is identified with the Liberal Party. I ask you, in the interests of having a sensible Question Time and one which is in some way in line with the dignity of a House of parliament, to remind the Minister that he has some responsibility to the public and not just to his squalid political party.
—There is no point of order, but I remind all honourable senators of the resolution that was passed in February about attacking members of the public during Question Time, and under privilege.

—With respect to that ruling or request, Mr Elliott has been described in the daily Press as a tax avoider of olympian proportions-`olympic stature' I think was the term used. Since he has not chosen to take any legal action pursuant to that, I presume his inaction and inertia are based on the presumption that the defence of truth and public interest would prevail.

ANSWER.PARA: Governments certainly do have to be careful, or pay heed to the danger, of loopholes or potential means of evading tax being exploited. I repeat that Mr Elliott's record clearly establishes this, as does Mr Lord's. He sets up arrangements which, firstly, diddle the shareholders in the company that he is supposed to be responsible for and, secondly, escapes paying taxes on the proceeds that he diddled from the shareholders whose interests he is supposed to be looking after. That is a question of historical fact. I have no doubt that if the opportunity arises for people such as Mr Elliott to avoid tax in the future, they will be in it up to their ears. Nor do I have any doubt that John Howard would allow them to get away with it if he was again in a position of political power.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I remind the Minister that I referred to a value put forward by the Treasurer, Mr Keating, in 1985, and I refer to the recent discussions between the Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) about tax cut-pay rise trade-offs. Is it not the case that in these past few weeks the Government has explored with the ACTU the option of making company tax cuts in May while, on account of a wage rise, leaving personal tax rates untouched?
—I have not been privy to the discussions which have taken place, but I would be surprised if that were entirely correct.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Consumer Affairs. Can the Minister inform the Senate of the latest bankruptcy statistics which were released today? What is the Government doing about the increase in consumer bankruptcies evident in recent statistics?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The bankruptcy statistics were in fact released yesterday, and they cover the period of the first quarter of 1988. They show the number of bankruptcies and administrative orders which are either voluntary or involuntary but which are both under parts IV and XI of the Bankruptcy Act.
—Have you got any scripted jokes today?

—The honourable senator is a scripted joke. The figures also cover the number of insolvencies, which include voluntary arrangements, assignments and compositions. I can understand a former partner of Patrick Partners wanting to intervene in a question on bankruptcy, but the statistics actually show that in the first three months of 1988 there were 2,136 bankruptcies compared with 1,942 in the same period of 1987, and 235 insolvencies compared with 278 in the same period. Accordingly, there is an increase of almost 11 per cent, if we extrapolate these figures to cover a full year period.

ANSWER.PARA: Arising from these statistics there are a number of points we should note. The number of business bankruptcies is in fact declining. At the same time the number of consumer, non-business related bankruptcies is increasing. There has been a fair degree of fluctuation over the last five years, but the dominant point in this quarter's figures is that the number of business bankruptcies in Australia has been steadily declining, and that decline has been emphasised in these figures. There has also been an apparent decline in the figures for Tasmania and Queensland, but I point this out with some caution because the figures for those two States are provisional and not verified. Over the last 12 months those two States have had the largest number of bankruptcies of all States.

I table three tables setting out, firstly, the number of business and non-business bankruptcies under parts IV and XI for the years 1981-82 to 1986-87; secondly, the major causes of bankruptcies in the same period; and thirdly, the number of insolvencies under part X for the same period. I point out, as I maintained earlier, that the figures show that business bankruptcies have been relatively stable over the term of the Hawke Government. The Government believes that maintaining stability in relation to bankruptcies, as opposed to the inherited rate of increase in bankruptcies, is an indication that our economic policies are starting to bite and to work.

The second part of Senator Burns's question related very much to what we are doing about bankruptcies in the non-business area. I refer the senator and the Senate to a forum that is being conducted today and tomorrow in Canberra under the auspices of the National Consumer Affairs Advisory Council. That meeting has brought together a whole range of people from financial institutions, government and consumer organisations, with the main topics of discussion being the granting and levels of credit and the general problems related to overcommitment. The Government hopes that that forum will provide an opportunity for all sectors to make an input to the policy development program. I for one am looking forward to the report from the National Consumer Affairs Advisory Council at the conclusion of the discussions.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. I draw the Minister's attention to Dr Blewett's statement, which was read out on A Current Affair on Monday evening, concerning alleged medifraud, in which he said that Dr Menon had not to date provided information to the Australian Federal Police (AFP) to substantiate his allegations of fraud. Does this statement not contradict the findings of the AFP that, although no fraud was identified, there was substantial evidence to warrant further investigations? Are such further investigations being made? Alternatively, are the police satisfied, as Dr Blewett appears to be, that the cheques were issued through computer error, which was rectified last November?

—I am not aware of the program-I believe it was A Current Affair-broadcast last Monday evening on which it was alleged that Dr Blewett, the Federal Minister for Community Services and Health, had made certain statements. I have no brief on the current state of the investigation undertaken by the AFP in relation to allegations of medifraud.
—We asked about that at the Estimates. You must have the answer.
—I will try to get an answer by the end of Question Time and, if that is not possible, I will certainly have one by tomorrow.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Perhaps the Minister in getting that answer for me would check whether the three cheques issued in February and March this year, and hence after the date on which the so-called error is supposed to have been rectified, have also been brought to the attention of the AFP.

—I will check that. The honourable senator interjected something about Estimates committees. That was before last Monday's A Current Affair program, if that is what she is talking about. Anyway, I will undertake to find out what I can about this matter.

—Has the Minister for Justice become aware of recent reports that the Secretary of the Australian Federal Police Association has expressed reservations about the operation and continuation of the National Crime Authority (NCA)? Does the Government find any merit in those reservations, and if so what?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have become aware of Press reports of certain submissions intended to be put by the Australian Federal Police Association to the parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority. Obviously I am not privy to the proceedings of that parliamentary Committee, but in so far as those Press reports indicated that the Federal Police Association was opposed to the continued existence of the National Crime Authority, the position of the Government is very clear, as is that of the Opposition. That is evidenced by the fact that a Bill has already been passed through the House of Representatives, I believe unanimously-in other words, with the concurrence of all sides of politics in that chamber-which, when it comes into this chamber, will be seen to have the effect of extending the life of the National Crime Authority beyond the sunset period set for it in the original legislation.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government remains absolutely firm in the view that the National Crime Authority should continue. In saying that, I do not in any way wish to indicate that the statutory charter given to it by this Parliament is necessarily the be all and end all and could not have some improvement made to it. In that respect the report of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority will play an important part in the further refinement of the role of the Authority within the Australian community as one of the weapons in the arsenal in the fight against organised crime.

It should be evident to all honourable senators that the National Crime Authority, in the short period of its existence, has proved its worth. Only last week there was a major drug haul, involving some $80m worth of heroin. The drugs were seized and charges were laid as a result of an NCA operation conducted in part as a result of information obtained in Hong Kong. That type of operation is good evidence that this new body within the Australian crime fighting community is extremely effective. For that reason the Australian Federal Police Association is wasting a lot of political energy in opposing the continued existence of the National Crime Authority, though its comments on any particular flaw it sees in the Authority's operations are, of course, matters for the parliamentary Joint Committee to assess. The Government looks forward to receiving the Committee's report, one hopes before the Senate debates the repeal of the National Crime Authority's sunset clause. I hope that that debate will take place in late May.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister for Resources, relates to the Government's professed concern about recent allegations concerning the end use of Australian uranium. Why has the Hawke Labor Government refused to fund fully the International Atomic Energy Agency's safeguards inspection budget for this year, funding only 65 per cent of Australia's contribution while at the same time having no difficulty in finding extra funds for other international organisations? Has the Government given consideration to an effective control on the end use of Australia's uranium which could be achieved by supplying yellowcake in the form of furnace fuel rods? This would involve Australia in the enrichment of uranium up to the 3 per cent level, and then the manufacture of metal pellets for the fabrication of the fuel rods. Any country seeking to use Australian uranium in this form as a feed stock for nuclear weapons would then be faced with taking three very expensive steps backwards through the cycle, which would add at least 25 per cent to the cost of this source of fuel and therefore make it quite uneconomic to use for weapons purposes.
—To take the last part of the question first, the Government has a clear policy on uranium, a policy that is well known in the community.
—A policy that you support unreservedly.

—Of course. Senator MacGibbon knows what that policy is-I do not have to remind him-but for the sake of the Hansard record it is that we supply uranium but insist on strict international safeguards and that that uranium goes to countries which have recognised and concluded with us a treaty to observe those safeguards. Those safeguards do not include the return of spent or waste fuel, to be deposited in Australia, or the things that Senator MacGibbon has referred to in the last half of his question. I will put that part of the question which relates to Atomic Energy Agency funding on notice and reply in due course.

—I have a supplementary question, Mr President. The Minister does not understand my question. I said nothing at all about the return of spent fuel rods; I said that the uranium could be supplied as a source of furnace fuel in the form of fuel rods rather than as yellowcake, and that that would provide an effective brake on its being used as a source of fuel for nuclear weapons in any country.

—I am pleased that Senator MacGibbon has taken the trouble to make his question clearer. In terms of that proposition, Senator MacGibbon would know that it is not the policy of the Government to do that.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, and I ask it in the context of Senator Button's known interest in and concern with the improvement in the quality of Australian industry. In view of the widely perceived need to reduce drastically emissions of ozone depleting substances, most urgently chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs), and recognising the present widespread application of these agents, particularly in the field of refrigeration and air conditioning, does the Minister consider that inevitably new technologies involving the recycling of CFCs will be rapidly developed and deployed and that these will have not only environmental benefits but also considerable economic benefits for the nation that successfully markets these recycling strategies? Is the Minister aware that Canada, Japan and possibly other nations are making a special effort to develop recycling strategies and their associated hardware? Finally, as the first country to come up with these recycling strategies is likely to make huge profits, what measures is the Minister taking to encourage Australian industry to research and develop these strategies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think everybody, particularly those in the Government, is aware of the fact that many countries are taking steps to preserve the earth's ozone layer through restrictions on the emission of chlorofluorocarbons.
—What was that again?

—I said chlorofluorocarbons. Is that all right? I can manage such words but I have difficulty with names like the honourable senator's. In some cases this work is being undertaken by recycling techniques or the more efficient application of current procedures, but the major effort is being directed to the development of environmentally safe alternative chemicals. I am advised that considerable progress on these alternatives has already been made. For example, at least two large international companies believe that they will have a safe alternative product on the market within five years. There is also a multi-company international consortium researching new products. So the matter is being considered by companies at an international level.

ANSWER.PARA: I am advised that recycling is not always suitable. The Australian chlorofluorocarbons manufacturing industry is small by world standards. The Government's present research and development assistance schemes, including tax concessions and the grants for industry research and development schemes, are available to that industry if it is keen to take up the opportunities provided by those schemes. I remind the honourable senator that many of the companies operating here are subsidiaries of multinational companies and it may be in their corporate interests, in their view, to do such work overseas. However, in view of the likely development of new and safe products, I am told that it is possible that the benefits of recycling strategies may be shortlived, that is, they may be of value for only a year or two.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Evidently the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce is not aware that the alternatives to which he refers are the CFC123 and CFC134A, both of which are thought to be substitutes because they are only partly halogenated. Is the Minister aware that some 27 per cent of the greenhouse effect during the next 50 years will be due to CFCs whether or not they are halogenated and therefore the substitutes, while they may be a short term solution to ozone depletion, are not a solution to greenhouse warming and therefore recycling is indeed the solution to both problems-that is, both ozone depletion and greenhouse warming?

—For the first time in a decade in the Senate I am starting to feel like Jim Webster, a former Minister for Science, because I have never heard of CFC123 or CFC134A. I appreciate the honourable senator's information that 27 per cent of the greenhouse effect is not capable of being dealt with by the substitutes to which he referred. I take the question on board and I will try to obtain an answer that is more learned than that which I am capable of giving.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. Recent legislation passed in this place has established the Child Support Agency and the child support scheme. When will the scheme start, what details are now in place for its implementation and what will be the advantages of the new scheme?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am in a position to inform the Senate that the Minister for Social Security, Mr Howe, today confirmed that the new child support scheme will commence operation on 1 June. The Government views the scheme as one of the most significant social reforms in the history of the Commonwealth. As honourable senators will know, the scheme will enable sole parents to have access to regular and reliable maintenance payments without fear of humiliation or violence. It is also important to note that the scheme has been introduced in a context where 70 per cent of non-custodial parents do not pay any maintenance regularly, and where this inadequacy in the current system contributes significantly to the number of children and parents in poverty.

ANSWER.PARA: I refer now to the features and objectives of the scheme. It will substantially increase the number of sole parent families receiving maintenance, it will provide an effective mechanism for the collection and enforcement of maintenance orders, and it will help to ensure that maintenance orders are received regularly. The other by-product of the scheme is that it will relieve taxpayers of a substantial burden. In relation to the mechanism of the scheme, stage 1 will see the establishment of the Child Support Agency within the Australian Taxation Office. Such an Agency will be responsible for the collection of maintenance orders and the payment of support will be through the Department of Social Security. Stage 1 of the scheme will also allow coverage to pensioners and beneficiaries, people who separate at the start of the scheme and people who have not lived together but whose children are born after 1 June. In relation to publicity for the scheme, I point out that, first, all existing sole parent pensioners will be contacted by mail as part of a comprehensive information campaign; and, secondly, a special 008 number will be set up as a hot line so that eligible people will have access to information.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister to table the document from which he was quoting.
—I will gladly do so, and I offer to give Senator Vanstone a briefing at some stage.
