DEBATE.TITLE: FRENCH COLONIALISM AND MILITARISM IN THE PACIFIC REGION

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that at 8.30 a.m. today Senators Alston and Wood each submitted letters in accordance with standing order 64 proposing matters of public importance. To decide which letter should be submitted to the Senate, I determined the matter by ballot in the presence of the Opposition Whip, Senator Wood and the Clerk of the Senate. In accordance with the result of that procedure, I now read Senator Wood's letter:

INTERJECT.PARA: Dear Mr President,
I propose that the following matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion:
The economic, cultural and environmental devastation caused by French colonialism and militarism in the Pacific region.
Yours sincerely
Robert Wood, Senator for NSW
Is the proposal supported?
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wood Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise this issue at this time because it is an important time in the Pacific. The French have recently decided to move the testing of their nuclear weapons from Mururoa to Fangataufa, a little further away from Mururoa. The reason for doing that is that Mururoa is breaking up, which we in the peace movement have been claiming for quite some time but which the French have been denying for quite some time. Also, the territorial elections in New Caledonia are being held this Sunday, 24 April, in conjunction with the first round of French presidential elections, which will see the Pons Statute, passed by the French Government last December, come into force. The Pons Statute is perceived by the Kanaks as tantamount to cultural genocide.

SPEECH.PARA: The French took possession of New Caledonia in about 1853. They took the arable land, as colonisers mostly do, and pushed the Kanaks back into the mountains, and they imposed a repressive colonial system for 100 years or so. It was a system that was only slightly liberalised following the Second World War. In 1981 we saw the election of a French socialist government, elected on the promise of giving self-determination to the Kanaks. Social and judicial reforms were introduced in late 1981. In 1984, Edgard Pisani was brought in to negotiate a transitional period of regionalisation, and elections saw Kanaks win control of three out of four regions.

However, in March 1986 the Chirac conservative Government was elected in France. The Chirac Government quickly stripped the power and reduced the funding of the regions and reversed land reforms that had seen land returned to traditional Kanak owners. Last September a referendum on independence was held. That referendum was boycotted by over 80 per cent of the Kanaks. It resulted in an overwhelming vote, by the white settlers who did vote, against independence, largely because Chirac and the French had threatened to withdraw funding to New Caledonia. It was economic blackmail: a vote for independence meant a vote for impoverishment. Not surprisingly, white settlers in New Caledonia voted for maintaining their links with France. Of those who did vote, some voted for independence who were not part of the Kanak Socialist National Liberation Front (FLNKS) and the independence movement in New Caledonia.

The Kanaks are currently fighting against the implementation of the Pons Statute, which will no doubt be ratified by the French Parliament in December. The Pons Statute, if implemented, will mean, according to the Kanaks, that Kanaks will become French citizens, whether they want to or not, and that the traditional inheritance system will be abolished, thereby destroying the clan system. Land defined as `reservation', which was previously inalienable, will be able to be transferred or sold to anyone. The Kanak culture will no longer be recognised as a cultural identity. I would agree with the Kanaks and suggest that that is tantamount to cultural genocide.

French colonialism in the Pacific has had, and continues to have, enormous implications for the region as a whole. The French treat all countries in the region with the traditional Gallic arrogance and disregard that we have come to expect. Demands have been made from all quarters for the French to cease nuclear testing and to respect the sovereignty of Pacific peoples, and they have all been studiously ignored, as the French have ignored the decisions of the International Court of Justice. The French have even been prepared to indulge in state sponsored and approved terrorism in the Pacific to achieve their aims. I do not have to remind anyone here of the bombing of the Rainbow Warrior and the consequences of that. The attitude displayed by the French in relation to the bombing of the Rainbow Warrior is graphic evidence of their arrogance and their disregard for the sovereignty of nations in the Pacific region.

The `Turenges', who are Alain Marfat and Dominique Pieur, or people involved in the bombing, were heralded as heroes in France; they were decorated. By contrast, New Zealand, where the bombing occurred, was made to pay dearly for having convicted them. I am not aware of any state having done so much for terrorists. Bans were placed on New Zealand lamb, the export of wool was seriously hampered and, finally, French pressure was exerted within the European Economic Community, which more than halved New Zealand butter exports. The treatment of New Zealand by the French backs up the claim made by President Mitterrand in 1985 that any foreign government challenging the French presence in the Pacific was to be considered as an `adversary'.

The intensely nationalistic sentiment which underlies French foreign policy in the region is killing the peoples of its territories, both culturally and physically. Whilst French colonialism may in the past have brought some economic benefit to the Pacific islanders, the price that they have paid for whatever benefit they have received has been the destruction of their ways of life and a massive pollution of their environment. French political control of French Polynesia has been maintained only by the economic dependence that has been carefully maintained by the French over the years. Exports cover about 6 per cent of foreign purchases and Paris makes up the rest. This is the price that France has been prepared to pay in order to maintain its colonies as a nuclear testing ground. The price paid by the Polynesian peoples, however, has been much higher. Whilst many were recruited from outlying areas during the early construction phase of the testing site, unemployment is now high and Polynesians have now become slum dwellers relegated to the bottom of the socioeconomic pile. Although they constitute 70 per cent of the population, they have the highest unemployment rate and today it is largely the Chinese, French and mixed race community which benefits from the French presence.

The independence movement in French Polynesia, not surprisingly, sees decolonisation as the only way out of its current situation. The impetus for the French to retain control is clearly the continuation of its nuclear testing program. I have stated all along that New Caledonia is just one example of superpower nuclear strategic interests trampling all over local self-determination, civil rights and democracy. The independence movement in New Caledonia is seen as a possible precedent for the decolonisation of other French colonies and the subsequent loss of France's force de frappe-as I understand it, meaning its ability to belt someone over the head. New Caledonia is presently gaining in strategic importance. Currently construction is under way for a new military base in Noumea Harbour to serve the growing fleet of French aircraft carriers and nuclear submarines. Already the bulk of hotel accommodation in Noumea is taken up by troops and service personnel.

The nuclear history of the Pacific is a result of its lack of independence and the greatest impediment to Pacific sovereignty is French and United States nuclear strategic interests France's nuclear presence demands colonialism. All pro-independence movements in French colonies take an anti-nuclear stance. In excess of 100 nuclear tests have been conducted at Mururoa, with devastating consequences to Pacific islanders and others in the region. The test site is honeycombed with test tunnels to the point that they threaten to collapse into each other. The latest reports of French intentions to shift the test site to Fangataufa is confirmation of the claims made over the years by opponents of French testing.

These claims are not merely academic environmental issues; they have real consequences for people's health. Recent reports indicate that Polynesians are being treated secretly for cancer which is a result of years of nuclear testing in the Pacific. We do not have proper statistics on that because the French do not collect them. What knowledge there is about medical treatment of the people of the region is suppressed. The incidence of ciguatera, a disease of tropical fish, is many times higher where nuclear tests have taken place. Reports of fish poisoning amongst indigenous peoples have been ignored by the French, as have reports of any adverse consequences of French actions.

What should be Australia's attitude towards all of this? In my view, it is vital that Australia keep the question of independence for New Caledonia on the agenda of the Decolonisation Committee at the United Nations, even if the French tell us, as the French Minister for Defence, Mr Andre Giraud, did recently, that it is none of our business and we should leave the French alone. Even Michael O'Connor, Director of the Australian Defence Association, hardly a radical body, said recently that `Australia had no option but independence for New Caledonia even if it means damaging relations with France'. He added the very obvious statement-obvious to all but the French, it seems-that colonialism was an anachronism.

The Australian Government threw out the Libyan People's Bureau because of its so-called interference in the Pacific region. If our Government is to be consistent it should close the French Embassy and all French consulates in the country since French interference in the Pacific is far worse than anything the Libyans have done or threaten to do. I might add as a sideline that the French have been assisting the Libyans in developing Libyan nuclear technology. For many years South Pacific Forum governments have backed demands for Kanak independence and denounced French nuclear testing but the message has fallen on deaf ears. Perhaps the time has finally come to adopt a stronger position as it seems the French respond only to coercion or humiliation. Perhaps it is time to start closing French embassies. The point of view I am putting is hardly radical. The Canberra Times, in its editorial of 24 February this year, stated:

One day France, notorious for grimly holding on to colonies, will have to grant New Caledonia independence and the sooner it does so the less will be the chance of a bloody civil war, such as have occurred in other former French possessions.

So the feeling that Australia should promote the cause of independence for New Caledonia is strong and growing in this country. Unfortunately, the trend between Australia and France seems to be the other way, towards growing collusion in the harassment of independence activists by Australian airport authorities. On 17 March this year Yan Celene Uregei of the FLNKS was strip searched on a stopover in Brisbane. Trade union leader Louis Uregei was meticulously searched when he entered Australia in January. There seems to be a growing policy of harassment of Kanak activists when they pass through this country. Fortunately, within France a few individuals are voicing concerns about France's policies in the Pacific. Professor Jean Chesnaux said to the Canberra Times last year that the French attitude towards New Caledonia had more to do with France maintaining its image as a medium-size global power than any real interest in the territory itself.

The response to claims from Australia that France should clean up its act, is that Australia should clean up its own backyard. I would agree with that wholeheartedly. I speak not from the point of view of someone who is being pious, noble and self-righteous about what the French are doing but as one who is conscious of our colonial history, our treatment of our indigenous people and our military strategies in the Pacific. I am one of those who are trying to encourage Australia to clean up its own backyard. I am one of those who are encouraging land rights for Aboriginal people, a fair deal for Australia's indigenous people. I am one of those who are encouraging greater responsibility in the Pacific region with regard to our trade and military intentions within the region. What I am advocating for France I advocate for the Australian Government, too-although I am not aware that the Australian Government goes around bombing peace activists in the region.
I quote from an article in the Pacific Islands Monthly entitled `History Lessons':

Even the FLNKS has entreated France to cover itself in glory, not ashes, by devising and implementing policies that reflect a true appreciation of other nations' bitter colonial heritage . . . Pacific nations, watching and hoping that the `Pacific century' will be ushered in by a gesture worthy of the republic that sent the words liberte, egalite, fraternite echoing around the world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Government has had some very visible differences of opinion with France over particular South Pacific issues in recent years, most notably New Caledonia, nuclear testing and the Treaty of Rarotonga. I will come back to each of those in turn in a moment. But we simply do not accept the language or the approach embodied in the language in Senator Wood's motion and his presentation of it here today. We have had differences. I have had some very robust conversations with French Ministers and officials in recent times on the issues to which I have referred. Events such as the bombing of the Rainbow Warrior did not do much to improve France's relations with any country in the Pacific area. But, that said, we have to acknowledge that the whole question of our relationship with France and, more particularly, the implications of the French presence in the South Pacific region are very important and pretty complex, and raise issues which cannot simply be dealt with in the very brisk, and perhaps even cavalier, way in which they were dealt with by Senator Wood.

SPEECH.PARA: There are many things to be said on the other side of the ledger. Australia does consider that France has a legitimate political, economic and cultural role to play in promoting stable development in the South Pacific and we have encouraged France to this end. Australia and France share the aim of promoting stability and a pro-Western orientation in the South Pacific. We recognise the valuable contribution that France has made in the past in the region and the constructive role it could play in the future, particularly in terms of providing development assistance and promoting balanced economic development and educational opportunities in its own territories-an area that President Mitterrand himself has acknowledged could be improved.

We are grateful for the generous and very constructive role France has played in the celebration of our Australian Bicentenary. The establishment of the La Perouse Museum and the participation of France, through the City of Versailles, in the Bicentenary celebrations here in Canberra are reflections of the long historical and cultural association that the two countries have had and the possibilities that continue to exist in abundance for that relationship to be very pleasant and constructive. We are very pleased to see, in the context of the Bicentennial visit to this country of Monsieur Giraud, the re-establishment of a ministerial visits relationship and the resumption of a full scale diplomatic relationship that had been somewhat strained in recent times. We look forward to the resumption of a healthy dialogue on the variety of issues around which we have mutual concerns.

Unquestionably, we have concerns about a number of specific issues. We have expressed concern that French policies on New Caledonia, nuclear testing and the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty, or the Treaty of Rarotonga, are contrary to the interests of the region and, in contrast to France's stated objectives, in fact risk undermining Western strategic interests in the region. I want to say now, for the record, a little about Australia's view on each of these issues.

So far as New Caledonia is concerned, the Forty-Second General Assembly of the United Nations (UN) in December 1987 adopted a resolution which was put forward by the South Pacific forum member countries, including Australia, reaffirming the colonial status of New Caledonia and calling on France to cooperate with the United Nations. Australia's position on New Caledonia is that the interests of the territory and of regional stability require a peaceful, orderly transition to genuine self-determination and to a viable, long term political status which recognises the rights of the indigenous people, safeguards the rights of all other long term residents and retains the goodwill of France and its positive involvement in the Pacific. We expect that status to take the form of multi-racial independence. The people of New Caledonia have the inalienable right to self-determination and independence, as enshrined in UN resolutions 1514 and 1541. Successive South Pacific Forums have expressed firm support for a transition to an independent New Caledonia.

Australia, in common with the other members of the South Pacific Forum, considers that a free and genuine act of self-determination in New Caledonia should be consistent with the universally accepted decolonisation practices and principles of the United Nations. We take the view, which we have expressed often enough, that the referendum held by France on 13 September last was inconsistent with that requirement. Australia supported reinscription of New Caledonia at the Forty-First General Assembly in 1986 as a means of ensuring that the territory's progress towards self-determination was regularly reviewed by the UN. Australia wishes to maintain a constructive dialogue with all parties involved in the New Caledonian issue, including the French Government.

In terms of the regional elections which are scheduled to take place in just a few days' time, on 24 April, we have noted that the FLNKS has indicated that it will conduct what is described as a `forceful' boycott of both elections and that the French Minister for Overseas Territories and Departments, Bernard Pons, has indicated that the French Government has decided to increase substantially the level of its security forces in the territory during the election period.

Against that background, we are concerned about the potential for further violence in the territory inherent in this situation, which has been explicitly foreshadowed by FLNKS spokesmen. We are concerned also about the implications of any such violence for the handling of New Caledonia by whatever administration emerges from the forthcoming French presidential elections. So we appeal to both the FLNKS and the French Government to exercise restraint.

Australian and South Pacific regional opposition to French nuclear testing in the region is firm and longstanding. The common opposition of South Pacific countries to testing in the region has been embodied in the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty, which came into force on 11 December 1986. There is no doubt that France is fully aware of Australia's very strong and continuing opposition to its testing program in the Pacific. We do not accept that French nuclear tests in the Pacific pose no long term environmental risks.

In 1983, scientists from Australia, New Zealand and Papua New Guinea visited Mururoa Atoll to investigate the effects of French testing, focusing particularly on the potential for long term environmental damage as well as possible shorter term damage. The team found that the structural integrity of part of the coral limestones forming the upper section of the atoll had been impaired. It noted that, while there was then no geological evidence of short term leakage, radioactive leakage could occur in a time period of 500 to 1,000 years. So there is concern, albeit of a long term nature, about the environmental implications of the test program.

Concern has been expressed, and was expressed again here today by Senator Wood, that French nuclear testing in the Pacific has resulted in an increased incidence of cancer in the region. In fairness, on the only available evidence to us-again, that of the 1983 mission-it was found that radiation doses to the French Polynesian population were lower than world averages, and that cancer statistics data for the region did not support the suggestion of elevated rates for cancers which might be associated with excessive exposure to radioactivity.

Notwithstanding how these environmental concerns balance out, the primary point that the Australian Government has always made, and that I make here again today, is that our opposition to French nuclear testing in the South Pacific is not based primarily on environmental concerns. We are overwhelmingly concerned about the argument that all nuclear tests by all states, in all environments, ought to be banned for all time. We have been in the very forefront of those calling in world forums and in every other possible environment for a comprehensive test ban treaty. France is the only nuclear weapons state which is testing outside a metropolitan territory, and it is doing so in a region whose peoples and governments oppose those tests. We unashamedly continue to express the very simple view-undeterred by the fact that the French describe it as a simplistic view-that, if the French tests are as environmentally safe as they claim, we see no reason why they should not be conducted in metropolitan France.

In short-I see no need on this occasion for me to make a very long speech-the Australian Government feels that a number of specific aspects of French policy towards the South Pacific, and in particular its attitude towards decolonisation in New Caledonia and nuclear issues in the region, have damaged France's relations with the independent states of the South Pacific. This has deflected attention, perhaps understandably, from the positive aspects of French presence, including substantial bilateral and multilateral development assistance. French policies in the South Pacific have undoubtedly constituted a major complication in Australia's bilateral relations with France, but one that Australia has sought to keep contained within the overall relationship, which is, of course, as it has been for many years, close, longstanding and broad-ranging. Australia is not seeking to drive France from the region. Rather, we look to France to build on the positive aspects of its presence in the South Pacific and thereby to play a more constructive regional role. We welcome, as I said at the outset, the French initiative to end the year-long freeze on ministerial contacts, and we look forward to the resumption of a constructive and mature dialogue with France on issues of mutual interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to put the Opposition's position on the matter of public importance introduced by Senator Wood in these terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The economic, and cultural and environmental devastation caused by French colonialism and militarism in the Pacific region.

The Opposition thinks that it is a matter of regret that the matter of public importance has been couched in such extreme terms, and we would not be prepared to support it in those extreme terms. By contrast, I thought that the speech of Senator Wood was constructive. Obviously, the Press clip from his speech was the call to close French missions, in the belief on his part that France will respond only to coercion or humiliation. In my experience, that is the last thing that the French respond to.

I was struck by the new attitude in this matter expressed by the Government today. The vitriolic attacks against the French, which we have so often experienced in this chamber, seem to have gone. I am not sure whether it is a reciprocal bicentennial gesture or whether there is some other motive, but it is a change to hear the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) talking in this chamber for the first time about pleasant and constructive relationships and using terminology of that nature.

TALK.START.PARA: —A change for the better?

—We on this side of the chamber welcome it. We think it is for the better. What is a matter of regret for us is that we feel that this Government has very little credibility to enter debates on the Pacific when one puts its record to the test. Certainly, when one examines that record-in many ways a record of neglect, a record that indicates an insensitivity and, at times, an ignorance of what is happening in the Pacific and of the very important changes that are occurring and continuing to occur in the evolution of the Pacific states-it does not give the Government a standing from which to debate this matter in a way that can command great respect within the region. Nevertheless, we welcome the change of attitude the Government has shown today.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition's position on these matters has been consistent. We have been critical of aspects of the French presence in the Pacific region, but I think we can fairly say that we have always tried to be constructively critical, and have also tried to act on the premise of reality. It is a reality based on the fact that France is a Pacific power. It is here in the Pacific, it has been here for a long time through its colonial interests and in other ways and it is going to stay, it has no intention of leaving. It is easy to get up in this chamber, as have Government spokesmen and others on many previous occasions, to abuse the French and tell them that this is not their region and to get out of the Pacific. But, of course, to do so changes nothing. What we have found when it has been put to the test is that the superpowers stick together. The French presence in the Pacific in effect received an implied endorsement by the United States of America when it bowed to French pressure and was not prepared to become a party to the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty.

I submit that it is much harder, but much more worthwhile, to attempt constructively to guide the French by example and by using our influence with other small Pacific states in a direction that would benefit the whole region. We agree with the Minister's statement today that France, through aid, trade, education support and in other ways, can make a worthwhile contribution to the region. The stumbling block, which we on this side of the chamber readily concede, has been its policy of nuclear testing in the Pacific. I suggest to the Senate that this policy of nuclear testing not only is related to its colonial attitudes to both French Polynesia and New Caledonia, but also is the greatest obstacle that we face looking to the decolonisation of those two territories.

The fear of the French that, by giving an inch, they will put in jeopardy their testing program, which independent territories are obviously unlikely to host, leads to such irrational behaviour as the blowing up of the Greenpeace observer vessel in a New Zealand harbour, which appalled us all. It is impossible for us to understand how a civilised nation with the record of culture and learning of France could behave in such an uncivilised way. It all relates back, I suggest, to the fanatical determination of France to develop and maintain its own nuclear deterrent so that it would never again be humiliated by an oppressor. There is an awareness that to attempt to move the program back to metropolitan France would engender great opposition and therefore put that program in jeopardy.

To the French-and I am talking of governments of all colours in France-the testing program of the Pacific therefore becomes paramount. The coalition parties are opposed to it. We argue against it in all forums. We are opposed to it not only on proliferation and environmental grounds but because of what we see as Australia's responsibility to support the small Pacific states on the issue. I suggest that we are the nearest thing they have to a major power to support them. Of course, many are geographically much closer to the testing sites than we are. If we attempt to understand how important the program is to the French, we realise how entrenched the issue is and that abuse simply will not help. That is, as I said, why I am pleased that the Government appears to have changed its approach to this issue.

The problem of getting French nuclear tests out of the Pacific will, I suggest, ultimately be resolved by arms control agreements that give the French confidence that tests are no longer necessary. I add that the fact that even the Soviets and the United States realise that an intermediate-range nuclear forces agreement that included the French nuclear forces would fail-it would not have come into being-is a further demonstration of how difficult this challenge is. In building greater confidence between members of the alliance progress can perhaps be made to influence France that an independent nuclear deterrent is unnecessary. Perhaps as Europe becomes a closer political entity there may be greater influence from the European powers that France's independent deterrent is unnecessary.

In the meantime, perhaps we should be making greater efforts in attempting to persuade France to look to alternative testing grounds. As you would know, Madam Acting Deputy President, it has been suggested from time to time that an agreement might be able to be reached with the United States for France to continue its testing in the Nevada Desert, where the tests could be more effectively monitored and not be subject to quite the same environmental dangers. Perhaps Australia could make greater efforts in this constructive direction which would be of benefit to the Pacific states.

We on this side of the chamber are concerned about what is happening on Mururoa Atoll. The locals come to this Parliament and say that portions of the island have sunk. There has been a recent inquiry which has included an underwater examination. It should have reported by now but it has not. That gives us reason for concern. We note that in Paris it has been stated that the tests will be moved to another island. Yet we learn that this has not been said in French Polynesia. All of this gives us reason for concern as to what is the geological state of the atoll and what are the risks to the environment.

We believe that it is through the medium of the environment that we are most likely to be able to influence superpower support in the form of persuasion of France either to move its testing or to desist from its testing. We would like to see the Government make greater use of this environmental tool. Perhaps if we had maintained better relations with France we could now be in a position again, through the South Pacific Forum or in some other way together with the Pacific states, to look for an opportunity to make a further geological inspection of the atoll. These are the constructive types of approaches that we think should be made to France which, although we readily admit the difficulty, would be more likely to result in some progress than policies of coercion and humiliation.

I said that this nuclear issue will be incredibly difficult to resolve. I attempted to establish the link between it and the decolonisation process in New Caledonia and French Polynesia-a link which I am sure exists. The fact that it is going to be so difficult to resolve does not absolve Australia from exercising its responsibility, which it has exercised well in the past world-wide, to allow colonised states the opportunity for self-determination. We should continue to press that issue in relation to France's colonies in the Pacific.

I experienced the vehemence of France in relation to this matter as a parliamentary adviser to the United Nations delegation in New York a couple of years ago when I supported, as a member of the Opposition, the reinscription of New Caledonia as a non-self-governing colony of France, which would have triggered the UN mechanism of acts of self-determination. I experienced the vehemence of France and its calling in of debts from countries around the world to influence those countries to vote against the motion. I also experienced how important Australia was to the small Pacific states and how much they relied upon us to take the running on this issue on their behalf.

It will be an ongoing battle. Of course, France refused to accept the resolution of the UN; rather, it moved to its own form of referendum. The form of referendum has been criticised, and fairly so, because it was so limited in its options. The options which were put were simply to stay with France or to go for independence, and were promoted on the island as with France or without France. If it was to be without France there was to be no reassurance of economic or other support for New Caledonia in the future. In those circumstances it is not surprising that 60 per cent of the community voted to remain with France and that 40 per cent boycotted the referendum.

One can go on in these debates for some time, but the approach that we have tried to take, in relation to both testing and decolonisation, is to influence France to take a course of action that will achieve both the goals we are seeking. Our opinion is that the approach that has been taken by this Government in the past has not been constructive and helpful towards that goal. It has achieved nothing worth while. We are pleased that we have witnessed today a different approach from the Government, an approach more consistent with the policies that we have adopted in the past. We hope that it might produce a more constructive result than we have experienced to date.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating a matter of public importance submitted by Senator Wood in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The economic, cultural and environmental devastation caused by French colonialism and militarism in the Pacific region.

It is a fact that France maintains colonies in the Pacific region and that it is one of the last of the European colonial powers to operate colonies anywhere in the world. The period of colonialism, however, is not finished. It is not finished in a number of ways because there are attempts by the countries that have power and influence in the world to re-establish colonialism as a mechanism of dealing with other countries.

The colonialism in which France has primarily been involved in the South Pacific region is of the old kind-that is, the view taken by the European powers that they were not only superior to people in other parts of the world but they had a God-given destiny to tell other people how to run their lives, and that those countries should be run with a view to the enhancement and development of the European powers as they existed in the last century and at the beginning of this century. Of the European powers that were heavily involved in that particular exercise in the last century, the French have seemed the least able to disentangle themselves with any dignity and with any view towards the proper development of those countries after the colonial powers left. France is also involving itself in the newer phase of colonialism; that is, economic colonialism. In the Pacific region the United States is also heavily involved in this particular method of colonialism whereby those major powers impose on other countries their views, policies and approaches. If so-called independent countries fail to observe those policies or approaches, there will be economic ramifications, sometimes of the most horrendous kind, as we have seen, for example, in a number of the Micronesian and Melanesian countries. France is involved in both those areas of colonialism.

Prior to the last election but one in metropolitan France when President Mitterrand came to power, there was a commitment, on behalf of the socialist government which came into power at that time, to independence for the French Pacific colonies. However, we have unfortunately seen so often the policies upon which socialist governments win power dissipate after the election on the grounds of scrabbling for the policies of their conservative opponents. In this particular case that most certainly occurred. The socialist Government, while in power, virtually did nothing to assist, and certainly did a great deal to hinder, the development of a truly independent nation in New Caledonia.

The very crude exercise of swamping the peoples of New Caledonia by migration from metropolitan France was one among many exercises that were engaged in during that period. France has sought to extend her militarist operations in the Pacific, most notably with regard to nuclear testing, which I will come to shortly. There are other such operations; for example, the building of large facilities in New Caledonia and the extension of the runway on Hao near Mururoa, and the like. The swing to the right in French politics and the appointment of Jacques Chirac as Prime Minister in 1986 meant that the white settlers in New Caledonia found that they had reason to hope that independence certainly would not be coming about, despite the requests and demands of the indigenous Kanaks. Regrettably, all the policies of the present French Administration with regard to New Caledonia must now be viewed in the light of the looming presidential elections.

As I have already mentioned, decolonisation has never been particularly popular in France and the method of decolonisation has been a particularly bloody one around the world. One would have hoped that those in metropolitan France would have understood something of this, but the attempt to extend themselves not only by extending, as it were, their own country but by extending their influence in the Pacific has been met with resistance from Australian governments of all political persuasions. I believe that France on its own has probably done more than any other state to damage the position of Western countries in this region.

The two issues which have united the small and not so small independent nations in the Pacific are, first, this issue of independence of French colonies and, secondly, the nuclear issue. France has been the major target of concern by Polynesian and Melanesian states in the South Pacific, with Papua New Guinea sending troops to Vanuatu and then the Government there being attacked by mainly white rebels supported by France. I think it is important for Australia, in terms of its foreign affairs stance, to look very closely at the concerns and the desires of the nations of the region in which we live. Unfortunately, I think that we have seen all too often the neo-colonial view taken by Australia, with its massive European population, that as a white nation in the region we know better. Of course, it is not crudely put in that way; it is often covered up in a whole variety of approaches. Essentially, underneath that is the type of attitude that tends to come through.

When one looks at Australia from the position of many of the independent countries in this region, one sees that they still have the feeling that Australia is merely acting at the behest of, and as a surrogate for, the European powers or the neo-colonial powers that now operate in this region, whether it be the United States or China, which recently emerged in this area, or the Soviet Union, which has displayed its attitude to operations in this region.

The second issue that has been of major concern to the new and emerging independent countries in this region is nuclear weapons testing on Murouroa Atoll. Despite the protestations of all the members of the South Pacific Forum, including Australia and New Zealand, France has continued to operate in a way which basically is at variance with all the normal and accepted modes of relationships between countries. Whereas the United Kingdom and the United States ceased their testing in the Pacific in the 1950s and 1960s, France has continued at the rate of up to 12 tests a year. When Algeria became independent-again an exercise which reflects on the method of France of disengaging itself from its colonial past-the French were unable to use the Sahara to test nuclear warheads and they moved to the Pacific. From 1966 to 1975 they conducted 42 atmospheric tests and from 1975 to 1985 they conducted 83 underground tests. Some of these tests have been absolutely massive, one in May 1985 involving a 150-kilotonne warhead.

I mentioned Algeria a moment ago. One would find it difficult in such a debate not to link the current hijack of the Kuwaiti airliner and the concern of the world for the innocent people who have been held hostage for so long. That the plane is sitting in Algeria reminds us, once again, of that institutionalised terrorism that France undertook in our region, and in fact, one of the very few examples of a country, so-called, that is interested in the promotion of any method that is available to us to combat terrorism in the world. Yet here we have a country condemned-thank God-by almost every country in the world, and certainly by all the countries in the European Parliament, for engaging in an exercise of state terrorism. Although the death toll or the potential for disaster was not comparable to the current hijack of the Kuwaiti airliner, I have no hesitation in linking the two, because they stem from the same idea, and intent, that attacks on innocent people are a method for the promotion of one's policies in some other part of the world. It is to the credit of all the other European nations that they saw fit to combine to condemn that act of state terrorism on behalf of France in our region.

I too noted the change in tone that came from Senator Evans with regard to the attitude of this country to France, no doubt as a result of the sweetening that went on with the last French visit here not so long ago. This brings to mind the very real difficulty in conducting foreign affairs, that ever-existing tension between ethics and money; the problem that one has with regard to trade and the promotion of human rights and dignity around the world. I do not pretend that it is an easy or simple matter to engage in that particular equation. But at the moment one is mindful of the fact that there are agents of the French Government simply wandering around the Pacific handing out cheques which are not connected to any particular aid project or to any type of development within the region, but are solely an attempt to curry favour within that region.

One cannot but be mindful also that in relation to Fiji a number of countries in the region, including Australia, attempted to take an in-principle stand on the destruction of the democratic institutions in that country. France was hotfooting it over there almost immediately, cheque in hand, to curry favour and buy itself in with the new dictators who had taken over in that country. Hardly a breath was taken before France was in there like a shot. In other words, the way France wants to do business in our region is not in the development of independent nations, is not with regard to the human rights that we must observe and is not in the development of a nuclear free zone, which France has failed to recognise and support, unlike so many other countries. The interests that France has in this region are purely for its own purposes in metropolitan France on the other side of the world. It has no other interest and no other reason for being in this region, and the sooner the French leave, and the sooner we are able to have more development of independent countries in this part of the world, the better this part of the world will be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to this matter of public importance raised by Senator Wood, I say first of all that I think it is rather blunt. It is rather brief considering the complex problems of the French involvement in the South Pacific. However, generally, I do not think people could disagree with the sentiments behind the raising of this matter. We may all have different emphases about it. I think the contributions so far have been quite thoughtful but I have a couple of comments to make about those contributions.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not agree with the assessment of Senator Hill that there was a dramatic change in the Australian Government's attitude towards French involvement in the South Pacific, just because Senator Evans gave a brief speech which did not contain dramatic histrionics and so on. The major content was that the commitments of the Government to the major differences of opinion with French involvement in the South Pacific are still there. I certainly support that. I have a particular interest in this area of the Pacific and I have spoken previously in the Senate about my disagreement with French involvement in it. I spoke in an adjournment debate in October last year about the restlessness and the disturbances that took place in Polynesia when a major industrial strike was broken up and put down by the heavy handed action of the French military police.

I want to make it quite clear that I believe the involvement of French colonialism in the South Pacific is the major impediment to further political development on a sound and constructive basis in our region. I do not think there is any doubt that the interest of the so-called pro-West Australia is not being enhanced by the intransigence of the French in the South Pacific. In fact I would go so far as to say that those interests that we do not agree with, such as Libya, the Soviet Union and totalitarian countries in other parts of the world, are being enhanced by the intransigence of the French towards decolonisation and their continuing involvement in nuclear testing in the South Pacific. I believe our interests, the interests of the West, would be immeasurably enhanced if the French had a proper program to move towards independence for the French colonies in the South Pacific and a commitment to wind down and end as soon as possible the French nuclear testing program.

French colonialism in this region I think has a number of features. First of all, the absurd claim that New Caledonia and Polynesia are part of France. When one talks to the French that is given as a justification for France's actions. A few weeks ago I was talking at a luncheon with some staff members who accompanied the French Defence Minister to Australia and they openly asserted that New Caledonia and Polynesia were a part of France. I said that that was like claiming that Bulgaria is a part of Australia, or Iceland is a part of Chile. It is just geographical nonsense. But they assert that and one cannot have a rational discussion because their assumption, as I say, is based on a geographical absurdity. That is the basis from which everything then flows in justification for not granting New Caledonia or Polynesia independence.

But I think the worst aspect of the French presence is France's military presence. In both French colonies there is an overwhelming military presence. In Polynesia it is a basis for France preserving and carrying out its nuclear testing program. Papeete, the capital of Tahiti in Polynesia, is in many respects a military town. People visiting there see a large number of military bases and there is a military presence everywhere. That presence is quite marked, and it is a way of ensuring that any pro-independence, anti-nuclear testing sentiment by the local people is suppressed. It is the same in New Caledonia, where several thousand soldiers are brought in whenever there is a suggestion that the FLNKS or the Kanak people are making progress towards independence. The French military police and military forces are immediately beefed up and usually carry out their task in a very provocative way.

We heard here earlier about French terrorism in the bombing of the Rainbow Warrior in Auckland Harbour in New Zealand. I abhor that but I think we would have to agree that there have been even worse atrocities, in my view, by the French military in New Caledonia in the shooting of a number of Kanak independence supporters at Hienghene on the east coast of New Caledonia. Flowing from the military presence is the further manifestation of French colonialism; the economic domination that they have established. There is no doubt that they have established a system whereby the economies of both colonies are absolutely intertwined with French development and with the need to receive substantial grants of aid, money and infrastructure support from France. The threat always is that if the colonies become independent that will all be cut off and therefore the local people will not have the standard of living that they have been used to over the last 20-odd years of French development. In particular, this is used as a justification for the existing standard of living in Polynesia. I will return to that later on when concluding my remarks about how some Polynesian people see the economic domination of their country.

Of course, this leads to a further manifestation of French colonialism which is intertwined-one goes with the other-and that is nuclear testing. We have French colonialism in the South Pacific because of France's need for nuclear testing, and we have nuclear testing because we have French colonialism. They are one and the same thing, and until one goes the other will not. We have to aim to get rid of both. I believe that the Labor Party, both in Opposition and in Government since 1983, has been unequivocal in its commitment to end nuclear testing and its support for independence for both those French colonies.

A further variation of the French nuclear testing program is the absolute refusal of France to support the Treaty of Rarotonga-the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty-of which Australia was one of the sponsors. Again, I believe that the French should stand condemned for their refusal to support that Treaty. Of course, if they supported it, they would condemn their own nuclear testing program. There is in the French colonies, whether the French like it or not, an evergrowing and stronger independence movement which I believe all political parties in Australia should support without equivocation, as should the people of Australia. We have coming up in the next few days a rigged referendum-that is what it is-in New Caledonia. The FLNKS, on behalf of the Kanak people, has boycotted it, as it rightly should, because the qualifications to vote are loaded to ensure that the result can go only one way even if all the Kanak people vote.

The Australian Government has led the way by showing great leadership. I thank Senator Macklin and others for pointing out that our support for the inscription of New Caledonia on the United Nations decolonisation committee has been an excellent move. It has certainly created a leadership role for Australia, and one that we should welcome and continue. The French, irrespective of the coming presidential election, have to face the fact that sooner or later, unless they grant independence in New Caledonia, there will be further violence in that country. That would be abhorred by us all. But remember that the violence will come because of the intransigence of the French, not the other way round. All the violence that has gone on there so far is a result of the attitude of the caledoche, the white settlers, and the French administration. The people killed so far have been Kanaks, not the white settlers. The white settlers have all the guns, all the arms; the Kanaks do not. So the violence is against the Kanak people in their own homeland.

There have been a number of developments in Polynesia in the last three months which should be of encouragement to us all. Gaston Flosse's conservative territorial Government collapsed in December of last year, and for the first time independence supporters who are also opposed to nuclear testing are part of a new, vigorous territorial government. That should be some encouragement, as I say, to us all. We in Australia should make every effort to show our support for that new territorial government, which is under considerable pressure from conservative forces both in France and, still, in Polynesia.

The final point we should never forget is that the Australian people have always been opposed to colonial rule. Going right back to the 1940s, the Chifley Government supported the independence of Indonesia. The Australian Labor Party in particular and Labor governments have a long tradition, of which I think we can be proud, of supporting the right of people to free self-determination. We should not in any way be backward in supporting the continuing development of independence in the two French colonies of New Caledonia and Polynesia. Once those colonies become independent, as I am sure they will, we will have a region in the South Pacific in which we will play a role not as a dominating force but as a nation equal with the independent countries that can be an example to other areas of the world that there are democratic governments in this area, despite the problems in Fiji, and that it is an area where colonialism has been removed and where the culture of the Polynesian and Melanesian people can survive and thrive.

In conclusion, I wish to quote from a book written by Bengt and Marie-Therese Danielson, called Poison Reign. It is the history of colonialism in Polynesia, and I recommend it to anybody interested in these issues. It contains a quote from a speech made by Jacqui Drollet, the leader of the Ia Mana Te Nuhaa Party in Polynesia, supporting independence and the end of nuclear testing. In that speech, made to a public rally in February 1984-though it is over four years ago the remarks are still appropriate-she gave us, more eloquently than I could ever hope to give it, an understanding of the situation in Polynesia. She said:

The Polynesian land, our fenua maohi, has been defiled by man's apocalyptic folly, and not only has Mururoa been polluted by the fallout engendered by this monstrous undertaking, but the whole social, economic and cultural fabric of our Polynesian society has at the same time been destroyed.

We have heard much about the wonderful prosperity and progress allegedly resulting from this industry of death. But if we look back on what has happened during the past twenty years, we must ask these questions:

Does it really represent progress to have all these vast slums here in Tahiti, inhabited by Polynesian immigrants from the other islands? And what has happened to the 10 000 Polynesians employed on all sorts of heavy construction work by the CEP during the first years? Today 7 700 of them have been laid off and are unemployed.
And those Polynesians who were able to buy a car in the early days, do they still have it today? And the Polynesians who sold their land in the CEP heydays, are they wealthier today?
She ended on this sad note:
Our land has changed hands, we have sold it for a dream.
Our power of decision has been taken from us, and all we have got in exchange are a few social welfare benefits.
Our society has become tough, cruel, merciless, and we are dominated by a new desire to make individual profits.
To continue along this road is sheer nuclear prostitution.

I believe that those remarks from Jacqui Drollet best sum up why we as Australians should continue to support the independence movements in both New Caledonia and French Polynesia, and support the ending of French nuclear testing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak against this matter of public importance and to give support to my colleague Senator Hill, who added some constructive comments to the argument against it. The matter of public importance before the Senate today fails to understand the changing scene of the South Pacific and the fact that within that scene France is an ally and recognises itself as a member of the Western alliance. Although it has its own command structure and undertakes its own military manoeuvres, France nevertheless sees itself as an ally and as part of the Western alliance. In that context, so does Australia. Our relationship with France has, I admit, often been rocky, as has been pointed out by speakers from both sides of the House this afternoon. It has been a less than perfect relationship. More times than not it is France that has not met its responsibilities. All of the speakers this afternoon have acknowledged and would recognise that there is a list of actions which we would condemn outright, but at the end of the day France is Australia's ally. In many ways France has an historic link with Australia that rivals many of our other Western allies.

SPEECH.PARA: It is worthy to note, as we prepare for Anzac Day next Monday, an Anzac Day in our bicentennial year, that it was in the Great War, World War I, that the Australian Diggers went over to France and saved that country. That is something that the French recognise as a very important part of their history. The honourable senator who submitted this matter of public importance and those who have spoken in favour of it would show far more wisdom by recognising the historic bond that Australia has with France and using that bond to influence the French in the Pacific region, particularly in regard to nuclear testing.

It is true that the South Pacific is a region that is going through significant changes, both in its domestic politics and in its international relations. The two most dramatic events of late, of course, have involved Fiji and Papua New Guinea. Further, we have seen the demise of the longstanding and very important ANZUS Treaty. The dismantling of this Treaty quickly followed the election of the Lange Government in New Zealand. It is interesting and worthy to note that back in 1984 Moscow radio said that the Lange victory could set off a chain reaction leading to the collapse of the ANZUS bloc. That statement turned out to be hauntingly correct. Since the collapse of ANZUS we have had the predictable encroachment of the Soviet Union with its long term designs in the region. I say `predictable' in the sense of the famous Vladivostok speech by Mr Gorbachev, in which he clearly emphasised the growing role of the Soviet Union in the South Pacific. This statement since 1985 has led to a very strong commercial push by the Soviets, which no-one should doubt will be followed by a much stronger military push. Evidence of this is apparent already in the growing importance of Cam Ranh Bay to Soviet strategic plans for the Pacific.

It is known that the main power to be won in the Pacific is naval power. The importance of Cam Ranh Bay and Vietnam itself upon the South Pacific nations should not be underestimated. The precedent has been set. The pattern is quite clear. It has already been tried and has been relatively successful in the Indian Ocean. Today it is widely reported that the Soviets have a large military presence in the Seychelles. The Seychelles had originally set up communication with the Soviet Union by way of trade and aid. This country has many features similar to those of the South Pacific. Today it is Soviet dominated and Soviet troops are present on the island, so the comparison between the Indian and Pacific oceans is quite real.
I refer to a paper by Mr Dibb, who is currently employed as a consultant to the Minister for Defence. The paper highlights the comparison I have just made:

Thus far, the co-ordinated policies of the ANZUS partners and the countries of the South Pacific Forum have been successful in denying the Soviet Union a major political foothold in the region. They are anxious to avoid a situation arising in the South-West Pacific comparable to that in the Indian Ocean where Soviet offers of aid to the fishing industry and visits by hydrographic vessels . . . have developed into port calls by warships.

Further to this, it is known that Libya continues to run a large network throughout the South Pacific region, regardless of the expulsion of the People's Bureau from Canberra last year. Colonel Gaddafi's assistance spreads to certain independence movements in the region. It is doubtful that these particular so-called independence movements could be genuine about proper democratic and parliamentary reforms for all the people of the region, if they are willing to take their training from Libya and the madman, Colonel Gaddafi. It is then in Australia's interest to recognise its strongest allies. That is what the proposer of the matter must come to grips with-firstly, that the Soviet Union is not Australia's ally, whereas France and its people are. France, like all of the Western alliance countries, is contributing to our interests, and indeed to the existence of the Western alliance.

Why have Senator Wood and other honourable senators who have contributed to this matter of public importance debate not recognised the role of France in the Persian Gulf and its importance in that region? What would be the stance of those who speak in favour of this matter of public importance when addressing the war in Chad, a war where France stepped in to protect that country from invasion by Libya? Chad is a country with which France has had traditional ties. Would they condemn France for its protection of the people of Chad, and would they condemn France for the same action in the South Pacific if the same circumstances arose with respect to Libya? If they would condemn France for this I can only say that they would support every murderous act that Libya has ever perpetrated. What is needed is a much broader view of the politics and international relationships of this area, or we will simply see the intrusion of the Soviet Union and Libya, countries which stand condemned as the most destructive to world peace today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support this matter of public importance. I think it is very urgent that we look at the South Pacific and that we do, as Senator McGauran suggested, get international politics into perspective in this region. I challenge some of the remarks just made by Senator McGauran about the intrusion of the Soviet Union, for example, into the Pacific region. In fact, Soviet activity in the region has decreased, as evidenced in the following article about Mr Hayden in the Melbourne Herald.

SPEECH.PARA: `. . . the level of Soviet activity in the Pacific Ocean area has gone down markedly in the past 12 months.' He said Soviet naval deployment had gone down `by something like 50 per cent' . . . Mr Hayden emphasised also that the Soviets maintained only a defensive naval presence in the north-west Pacific while the US had a vastly superior `attack' capability.

I do not want to go into the argument of comparing the capacity of the Soviets in the Pacific with that of the Americans. I think it is very clear that the American Navy has an enormous superiority when compared with the Soviets.

Of course it must be acknowledged that the Soviet Union has taken up a base at Cam Ranh Bay. That is a concern, and I do not deny that, but let us not get it out of perspective, and let us not get the fishing agreements with Kiribati and Vanuatu out of perspective. The Soviets have been merely paying for the fish that American tuna boats have been stealing from these very small South Pacific nations for a number of years. So, as Senator McGauran suggested, we need to look at it in perspective. I do not think that we need to build up a lot of hysteria about the Soviet presence in the South Pacific. We need to acknowledge that it is there and we need to keep an eye on what is going on, but today we are debating the French colonisation, destabilisation and nuclear policies in the Pacific, which are of much greater importance to the people of the region than what the Soviet Union may be up to.

In face, the Kiste and Herr report, commissioned by the American State Department in 1984, came out with exactly this finding. I repeat that this was the United States Government and its own commission. The commission talked to numerous people in the South Pacific region in an attempt to assess the potential for Soviet penetration of South Pacific islands. The commission discovered, to its own surprise and dismay, that the French and Americans were seen as the problem-not the Soviets-as far as the South Pacific island states were concerned. I recommend that Senator McGauran have a good look at the Kiste and Herr report of 1984, which is the US Government's own document-a document which dobs it in along with the French as the problem in the region rather than the Soviet Union.

We need to look at the essence of the French position in the Pacific, which is basically that its territories there are part of France, that it needs Mururoa to test its nuclear weapons, which are necessary for the defence of France-which is questionable in itself-and that, if the people of the region want independence and enough vote in favour of it, France will leave the area. That is debatable. It is most necessary to examine the French position.

The commander of the French naval forces in the Pacific, Admiral Pierre Thireaut, spoke at the Red Orchestra Conference in Melbourne on 21 March this year. The theme of that conference was `Soviet ambitions in the Pacific: how Australia, the US and their allies should respond'. It was organised by the Institute of Public Affairs (IPA). Admiral Thireaut said that the Soviet Union had signed the Treaty of Rarotonga to drive a wedge between allies in the Pacific. He added that it was trying to weaken the French nuclear deterrent, which depended on continued testing in the Pacific.

In other words, according to the French, East-West issues are more important than North-South issues or the priorities of the indigenous people of the South Pacific. Although Admiral Thireaut confirmed that France would have a major role in Pacific affairs but would leave its Pacific territories at once if a majority of people said in a democratic vote that they wanted independence, this ignores the fact that the Kanaks are a minority in their own land and that French Polynesia has been made a nuclear colony-in effect, economically dependent upon the test program since it was moved there in 1963, and since testing began in 1966.

It seems that the superpowers, with France included, consider their own interests in the Pacific much more important than the interests of the indigenous peoples of the region, once again-and I think Australia is part of the problem to a certain degree-looking at the Pacific through East-West eyes rather than looking at the needs of the local people, whose pleas have been for economic independence. It seems very tragic that France has not learnt lessons from its former colonial mistakes in Algeria and Indo-China. Those countries were no more part of France than New Caledonia and Tahiti are, and France does not belong in the Pacific, either. The difference is that, because the islands are small and distant, it is harder for them to oppose the power of France, except with regional support-and that of course is what Australia should be giving.

It is also interesting to note that at the Red Orchestra Conference both Sir Julius Chan and Sir Ewan Jamieson, whilst saying that they had no objections to the French tests, subtly warned the conference that the French presence in the South Pacific was destabilising the region, with Sir Ewan hinting that, if possible, other alternatives for a test site should be explored, like the United States of America's underground test site in Nevada. Those comments are from people who are not necessarily opposing French colonialism but who see that the continued French presence there is destabilising, largely because of the testing programs.

The French motivation for being in the Pacific is largely to form a commercial base for themselves in the fast expanding Pacific economic basin. It has been acknowledged that the Pacific area, the Pacific Rim countries in particular, is the fastest growing economic region in the world, and even these tiny nations are seen as being important as part of that process. It is important to note that France on its own is not one of the world's largest countries, either in area or in terms of its economy, but with the 200-mile exclusive economic zone around its French Pacific island territories and other islands, in area it becomes the second largest country in the world. The French also consider the seabed mining potential in the South Pacific very important. So, they do see economic and political gains by having such a large area of the Pacific under control.

On 24 April, coming up soon and coinciding with the first round of the presidential elections in France, an election will take place in New Caledonia to ratify a new law already passed by the French Legislative Assembly. This is known in New Caledonia as the Pons law. It will effectively legislate the Kanak nation out of existence. Once implemented this law will, firstly, eliminate the status of Kanaks as indigenous people and redefine them as citizens of France. This will permanently deprive them of the right to independence. Secondly, it will abolish the traditional rights of Kanaks to their land by destroying the traditional land inheritance system. Thirdly, it will reclassify land presently defined as `reservations' into freehold title, thus enabling Kanak lands to be sold to anyone. Finally, it will abolish the legitimacy of Kanak culture under French law.

The Kanaki people are planning to boycott the French presidential elections as well as the local territorial elections and this Pons referendum. The Minister for Overseas Territories, Monsieur Bernard Pons, has ordered eight more squadrons of gendarmes to New Caledonia, taking the total to nearly 2,000-the largest number ever deployed there. When that 2,000 is added to the troops, the foreign legionnaires, the marines, the republican security companies, riot squads and other police already on the island, they will take the combined strength to about 8,500 men, or one for every seven Kanaks-that is, one to every two or three adult males. That is an enormous amount of militarisation in New Caledonia in preparation for this election.

The French seem to be determined to provoke the Kanaks into violence. This massive police and military presence will see to that. The population in New Caledonia is now 37.1 per cent French; that is, there are 20,000 metropolitan French people there-the civil servants and so on who are out there for a short term of duty and who return to France. There are 36,000 Caldoche people there-permanent white settlers, some of whom have come from other former French colonial territories in Algeria and Indo-China. There are also other groups, including the migrant workers brought in to work in the nickel mines, that is, Indonesians, Vanuatuans, Tahitians, Vietnamese, and other people-totalling 29,000 people. They are also pro-French because their jobs as migrant workers depend on the French presence remaining.

The situation now is that the Kanak people are now outnumbered in their own country-very purposefully. This has been a policy of the French, and relates to their strategy of nomadisation, which they have copied from Algeria and Indo-China; it was not very successful there, and I hope that it will not be successful in New Caledonia, either. What they have managed to do very successfully is to outnumber the Kanaki people in their own region, which probably means that they will get the vote to go the way they want it to. Then they can sit back and say, `Well, we gave the local people an opportunity to vote against the French presence there and they did not take the opportunity'. Under the kind of threat of repression that the people there are suffering, it will be little wonder.

I now want to talk a little bit about the French-Australian rapprochement that has been happening lately, and this is since Australia decided to resume uranium sales to France. It has been happening as part of the cheque book diplomacy that has occurred throughout the Pacific in the wake of the Fiji coup. I think it is quite a disgrace that the Minister of Defence, a Monsieur Andre Giraud, should use the opportunity of a bicentennial gift to Australia to tell Australia to mind its own business on the issues of New Caledonia and nuclear testing in the South Pacific. It is only the French who believe this ridiculous myth that Tahiti and Kanaki are part of France. The comments made in the Press give an indication of how much this rapprochement has been going on. `Canberra and Paris kiss and make up' is the headline of an article in the Canberra Times of 25 February this year. Incidentally, France has made greater gifts than has any other country to the bicentennial celebrations. It has donated $25m for 39 projects, more than any other country, and we have said thank you very much. So, Australia is being bought off like many of the other countries in the South Pacific.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's very cynical.

—Maybe it is very cynical, but I think it is rather distressing that we have these envoys of the French Government coming out here for the bicentennial telling Australia to mind its own business, that it is no business of Australia to be concerned with New Caledonia. We have also had Admiral Thireaut addressing the IPA seminar in Melbourne and then going on to a round of meetings with defence chiefs and planners during his Australian visit, as a guest of the Chief of Naval Staff, defending French nuclear tests in the Pacific, criticising Australia's disarmament policies and telling us to keep our noses clear of our neighbour's interest in New Caledonia.

SPEECH.PARA: To add insult to injury, the glossy publication handed out for the Canberra fireworks display in March-also paid for by the French Government as its Bicentenary gift-contained a full page advertisement for the giant French company, Cogema, a subsidiary of the government-owned Commissariat a l'Energie Atomique, which was responsible for the commercialisation of the nuclear fuel chain, from mining to reprocessing and packaging of wastes. It was as pretty a picture as one could produce of yellowcake.
