TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement relating to Australian nuclear safeguards. I also seek leave to move that the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The West German magazine Der Spiegel alleged, in its editions of 18 January, 15 and 22 February 1988, that the European Atomic Energy Community, Euratom, had circumvented conditions placed on Australian origin nuclear material by the Australia-Euratom safeguards agreement. Similar allegations were made concerning Canadian and United States origin nuclear material. These allegations were repeated by two members of the European Parliament, Mrs von Blottnitz and Mr Staes. Mrs von Blottnitz has written a letter to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on the allegations. The allegations have also been echoed by Senators Sanders, Mr Peter Milton and other Australian parliamentarians and have appeared in the Australian media.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government takes a serious view of any allegation concerning possible breaches of Australia's nuclear safeguards agreements. Consequently, we have conducted a thorough examination of the allegations which have been made:

When the first Der Spiegel articles appeared, initial inquiries were directed to Euratom through our embassy in Brussels. These were followed up by a number of specific questions relating to the allegations.

The Government has sought the views of the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) and has also consulted the authorities in the Federal Republic of Germany (FRG), Austria, Canada and the United States (US).
The Australian Safeguards Office (ASO), which is the Australian Government body responsible for accounting for Australian nuclear material overseas, has been closely involved in the investigations.

The Government has obtained from Der Spiegel and the European Parliament copies of the exchanges of correspondence between Euratom and the German nuclear firm, Nukem, on which the allegations of mishandling of Australian uranium are based.

More recently, Senator Sanders has provided copies of two documents on which Der Spiegel based some of its allegations. These are internal working documents from the Euratom Supply Agency, which is Euratom's uranium buying agency. The Supply Agency should not be confused with the Euratom Safeguards Directorate which is the body responsible for safeguards within the European Community.
In essence, the allegations which have been made, insofar as they relate to Australian uranium, are as follows:
Euratom has `swapped flags', denoting exchange of nuclear safeguards obligations, between quantities of Australian nuclear material and material of different national origin.

Euratom set out with Nukem, the German nuclear firm, to circumvent safeguards controls on Australian nuclear material, in particular the need to obtain Australian consent for enrichment above 20 per cent.
The Australian Government is opposed to the concept of `changing labels' and has a system of `special approvals' which has not been complied with.
Euratom is `laundering' South African uranium by swapping labels.
Euratom has swapped Australian nuclear material with `phantom' material, that is, material which no longer existed, or with nuclear `waste'.

In part, these allegations appear to flow from a lack of understanding of the complexities of international trade in nuclear material, confusion between internal and international flag swaps and, in particular, failure to understand the equivalence principle used in nuclear materials accounting. The equivalence principle ensures that at all times there is a known quantity of nuclear material identified as being subject to Australian safeguards obligations. This principle is integral to the operation of both Australia's network of bilateral nuclear safeguards agreements and the system of international safeguards applied by the IAEA.

Australia's safeguards agreements are the strictest in the world. They provide for the most stringent controls to ensure that Australian obligated uranium is used only for peaceful-that is, non-weapons-and non-explosive purposes. Australia's bilateral safeguards agreements-eleven of which are in force with the United States, the United Kingdom, France, Canada, Japan, the Republic of Korea, Philippines, Finland, Sweden, Euratom and IAEA-are binding international treaties and have been tabled in Parliament. They are public documents. The dates on which these agreements entered into force are set out in a table which I will table in due course.

The physical and chemical processes involved in making nuclear reactor fuel on a commercial scale involve very large plants and necessitate the comingling of material from several sources. In the first stage uranium oxide, or yellowcake, which is a dense powder, is converted to a gaseous form known as uranium hexafluoride. In the next stage-enrichment-the content of the isotope U235, which is the isotope of uranium which enables nuclear fission to take place, is increased from its naturally occurring level of 0.7 per cent to about 3 per cent. This process typically involves cycling the gas several thousand times through centrifuges or diffusion barriers. In the third stage, the gas is chemically processed to produce uranium dioxide, a powder which is compacted into fuel pellets which are loaded into tubes. A collection of tubes is then assembled into a fuel element. Nuclear material can undergo these various processing operations at plants in a number of different countries subject to the safeguards obligations which are attached to the material involved. These processes are described schematically in a diagram, which also will be tabled.

Continued identification of individual atoms is not possible in commercial operations of this type. Consequently, at the conclusion of each processing stage, it becomes necessary to allocate safeguards obligations to the product material in strict proportion to the input from each source. The basis of the measure of equivalence is the number of atoms of U235. In this way material is assigned as being of particular national origin and the safeguards obligations that each exporting country requires are applied to that material. In Australia's case this material becomes known as Australian origin nuclear material, or AONM. In other words, AONM is the label attached to nuclear material which is subject to Australian safeguards obligations.

From the point of view of international safeguards, the important thing is that a quantity of nuclear material equivalent to the amount originating in an exporting country remains subject to the safeguards obligations imposed by that country. As the nuclear material passes through the nuclear fuel cycle, an amount equivalent to the quantity of material originally exported will remain subject to the safeguards of the exporting country. That remains the situation, even though the volume of the material and its chemical composition will change according to the type of process to which the material is subjected. So, for every 50 tonnes of Australian material that enters the European system the equivalent of that 50 tonnes always carries safeguards obligations to Australia. These safeguards obligations ensure that the AONM is locked into the civil program and cannot be diverted from peaceful use without being detected.

The equivalence principle recognises that the individual atoms are indistinguishable from each other. A simple analogy would be that of a bank depositor who maintains control over a given sum of money. The depositor does not expect to withdraw precisely the same banknotes that were deposited with the bank, but only a sum of money equivalent to the amount deposited. In the same way, Australia does not seek to identify the individual atoms in uranium which is exported to a given country. This is consistent with international practice. But Australia does require, and obtain, an accounting for a quantity of nuclear material which is equivalent to the amount of uranium exported. At each stage of the processing chain an equivalent amount is identified as being subject to Australian safeguards obligations. No uranium exporting country applies safeguards on the basis of tracking individual atoms of material, nor could it. Neither does the International Atomic Energy Agency.

Under Australia's bilateral safeguards agreements, all of which provide for the use of the principle of equivalence, our bilateral partners enter into international legal commitments concerning the use of AONM subject to the agreements. The agreements provide that such AONM shall not be used for, or diverted to, the manufacture of nuclear weapons or other nuclear explosive devices, research on or development of such weapons or devices, or be used for any military purpose. Compliance with these provisions is ensured by a system of safeguards administered by the Australian Safeguards Office, the safeguards office of the country or group of countries concerned, and by the International Atomic Energy Agency through its inspections.

Under the administrative arrangements pursuant to Australia's bilateral safeguards agreements, a system of accounting and reporting has been established through which the Australian Safeguards Office is informed of the amounts of AONM, in its various forms, by bilateral treaty partner countries. This information provides the basis for reconciliation of accounts kept by the ASO with those kept by its counterpart organisations. The ASO conducts regular visits to our bilateral partner countries for this purpose and includes in its annual reports the results of these visits. These accounting procedures provide assurance that nuclear material subject to the agreement remains in exclusively peaceful use. Further assurances are provided by the safeguards which the IAEA applies. The IAEA carries out inspections, takes samples, makes measurements and carries out camera surveillance to detect any diversion of nuclear material from peaceful uses. The results of the IAEA inspections are reported each year to member states. They indicate that, in a quarter of a century of Agency operations, there has been no diversion of safeguarded nuclear material from peaceful use. In the case of the Australia-Euratom Safeguards Agreement, to which the abovementioned allegations refer, our bilateral partner is of course a group of countries: the members of the European Community. The agreement treats the Community as a single entity and the Community's safeguards office-the Euratom Safeguards Directorate-accounts for all AONM within the Community's boundaries.

The Australia-Euratom Agreement permits safeguards obligations to be exchanged between one quantity of nuclear material and another subject to the following conditions: the two quantities involved must be equivalent; there must be operational reasons for the exchange; both quantities must be located within Euratom's jurisdiction-that is, within the European Community; and the exchange must not result in reducing the quality of the material subject to Australian safeguards. For example, an exchange of high enriched uranium for an equivalent quantity of low enriched uranium or of low enriched uranium for natural uranium would constitute a reduction in quality. The approval of the Australian Safeguards Office would be required for any exception to this and no such approval has ever been either sought or given. The practice of exchanging safeguards obligations on equivalent quantities of low enriched uranium, to which the first allegation refers, does not therefore constitute a breach of the Australia-Euratom Safeguards Agreement provided the above conditions are met. In the example of an obligation exchange which has been brought to our attention by Der Spiegel and others there was no breach because these conditions were met.

The second allegation, that Euratom set out with Nukem to circumvent safeguards controls on Australian uranium, in particular the need for prior consent for enrichment beyond 20 per cent, is based on the particular transaction which is documented in correspondence between Nukem and Euratom. The evidence available to the Government indicates that Euratom's approval of this transaction was consistent with the terms of the Australia-Euratom Safeguards Agreement. Indeed, the correspondence between Euratom and Nukem indicates that the Euratom Safeguards Directorate, by insisting on Nukem submitting a full and formal application before an exchange of obligations could be considered for approval, was concerned to ensure that Euratom's safeguards obligations to its treaty partners were observed. The net result of the exchange was that, while an amount of nuclear material became subject to United States obligations and therefore did not require the consent of Australia for enrichment beyond 20 per cent, an equivalent amount of nuclear material remained subject to Australian safeguards obligations. Clearly, the Euratom Safeguards Directorate adopted a rigorous approach in dealing with the Nukem request. This contrasts with the reported attitude of the apparently ill-informed officer in the Euratom Supply Agency, the Community's uranium buying agency, who, having no responsibility or authority for safeguards implementation, is nevertheless quoted in one of the internal Nukem documents as having advised Nukem on how obligation exchanges could take place.

The third allegation, Der Spiegel's mention of Australia refusing to accept the concept of changing labels, refers not to obligation exchanges within the European Community-that is Euratom's jurisdiction-but to exchanges of obligations on equivalent quantities of nuclear material located in different countries with different safeguards jurisdictions. If Australian obligated uranium were to be involved in what are known as international flag swaps (IFS), this would amount to a transfer of AONM from Euratom's jurisdiction to another country. Australian consent would then be required. Australia has not given its consent for any international flag swaps and no AONM has been involved in any international flag swaps. The conditions under which Australian consent could be given are still the subject of discussion between Australia and Euratom.

In relation to the fourth allegation, South African-Namibian uranium is not under embargo in the European Community. Euratom can thus buy, process and use South African and Namibian uranium and, within its jurisdiction, it can exchange South African or Namibian obligations with other national obligations, provided this is done in accordance with the terms of the relevant bilateral safeguards agreements. It cannot however, as noted above, approve an exchange of obligations between jurisdictions-that is, an international flag swap-involving AONM without the consent of the Australian Government. The Government has long suspected, and the two Euratom Supply Agency documents lend credence to this view, that the promoters of international flag swapping are partly driven by a desire to circumvent restrictions on South African and Namibian uranium. This is not to deny that there can be sound commercial and non-proliferation reasons for an international flag swap. The Government has made it very clear to Euratom in discussions which have taken place on this issue that its consent would not be given to any international flag swap involving South African or Namibian nuclear material.

The final allegation that Euratom has swapped Australian nuclear material with `phantom' material has not been substantiated. We have raised this allegation with Nukem and have checked it with the Austrian authorities, who have assured us that the material in question was in no way fictitious. It was in the form of pieces of fuel pellets remaining after the fabrication of fuel for an Austrian reactor. This material was physically located in Hanau, Federal Republic of Germany, and was available for Austrian use until its sale to Nukem in 1986. It is misleading to describe this material as nuclear waste as some have done, because it was valuable nuclear material fully available for re-use as feed material for fuel fabrication and was equivalent to the other quantity of material involved in the obligation exchange.

In conclusion, on the basis of the investigations that have been made and the information available to the Government, there is no evidence that any material subject to Australia's bilateral safeguards agreements has been diverted from peaceful use, or that Australia's safeguards requirements have been breached. The Government will, of course, continue to monitor the operation of Australia's bilateral safeguards agreements, in light of commercial and inter- national developments in the nuclear fuel cycle, to ensure that Australian obligated nuclear material remains in peaceful use, and Australian safeguards conditions continue to be observed.

Last night we had a briefing by Senator Cook, Mr Kerin and Frank Betts of the Australian Safeguards Office. I appreciate the fact that we had the briefing. Mr Betts of the Safeguards Office repeated a comment that Senator Gareth Evans had made in the Senate chamber-that he was sure that the French were not misusing our uranium and were not using it for bombs because they told us that they were not using it for bombs. I trust the French just about as far as I can throw the Rainbow Warrior-and no further.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is probably reciprocated.

—They do not trust me at all and I do not trust them, because they have made so many statements that have been shown to be false. We are told that, because they say they do not use our uranium in bombs, they do not use our uranium in bombs. What happens when our yellowcake goes to France? It is processed in the Tricastin plant, in some instances. In its first stages there is no difference between military processing and civil processing of yellowcake. The first stage is to convert it into a gas called uranium hexaflouride. Once this is done, it may be streamed off later, but the first steps are exactly the same. The Tricastin plant is a joint military-civil facility. That is where our yellowcake goes. The French say, `No, we would not use that product for bombs; it goes only to the civil stream'. We are talking about a pool of uranium. No-one actually differentiates which uranium it is, where it came from or where it is going. Transactions take place on paper. The uranium itself may not even move in some instances. It is absolutely impossible for the Government or anybody else to say that our uranium does not end up in bombs.

SPEECH.PARA: We had a visitor from Europe, Mr Hans Blix. He is the head of the International Atomic Energy Agency, an agency which is charged with both the promotion and the control of nuclear energy. He was interviewed on 18 April 1988 on the World Today, that excellent Australian Broadcasting Corporation program. The interviewer, Martin Hurst, said:
Can you say with complete certainty, that that uranium can't be used for other purposes?

Hans Blix: Yes. All the uranium that we safeguard, that is the essence of safeguard, that we verify that it is used only for peaceful purposes. But whether it is the same atom or another one, doesn't bother us.
Martin Hurst: And you are completely satisfied that Australian uranium has not been diverted at all out of Europe?
Hans Blix: We are concerned that a kilogram of uranium that goes in, that remains a kilogram, but not the same atoms. If they swap, that's no problem of ours.
Unidentified: But it could be our uranium could be involved, that is what you are saying?
Hans Blix: I don't know. I don't know. Whether those atoms go somewhere else, we don't know.
This is the head of the Agency who is supposed to be monitoring all this. He does not know where they go.

TALK.START.PARA: —But that has always been the situation.

—As the honourable senator says, it has always been the situation, and that is the problem. The whole system, this whole bureaucracy of safeguards, is necessary to satisfy people's doubts, but it does not satisfy their doubts; all it shows is where the paper goes. There is no way to track where the actual uranium goes and that is why we should stop shipping it. If we have a moral responsibility, which we do, to ensure that our uranium is not used for warlike or military purposes, we must stop shipping it, because at the moment there is no way at all to say where it is going.

SPEECH.PARA: We have this idea of equivalency. What about our equivalency? The Government has often said, `It does not matter. We do not care about the molecules or the atoms. We are worried about the total amount of uranium'. The Government has often said `We don't care about the molecules or the atoms. What we are worried about is the total amount of uranium'. Take the hypothetical situation where one's grandfather has died. There is a funeral and we all attend and pay our last respects to our grandfather as he goes down that well-greased chute into the crematorium and eventually we are presented with an urn full of ashes. They are not just any old ashes, they did not come from the incinerator down at the tip, from the dog pound or from anywhere else, they are grandfather's ashes. We want to know that they are grandfather's ashes. It is no good their being somebody else's ashes. It is the same with uranium. We want to know that it is our uranium, but at the moment there is no way of knowing this, because all parties involved in this say they cannot tell where our uranium goes and they cannot say what it is used for.

What about flag swapping? The whole idea of flag swapping, which is so accepted by the Government, the Opposition, the European Atomic Energy Community, Euratom, and the International Atomic Energy Agency, is morally dishonest. The European Community's EC News, which is published in Australia by the Press and Information Service Delegation of the Commission of the European Communities, in March 1988 contained a long article headed ` ``Flagswaps'' of nuclear materials'; I will read only a small part. It gives an illustration of a flag swap, and it states:
Flagswaps can be explained and justified for economic and security reasons.
A simple example to illustrate a swap:

In the Community, an operator, eg manufacturer of fuel elements for nuclear power stations, has 80 per cent Canadian uranium and 20 per cent Australian uranium, these being required for the manufacture of the elements.

As he needs the full quantity which is subject to the safeguards obligations of two different countries (Canada and Australia), the situation can then become complicated for the end-user: the latter has to keep complex accounts when managing his fuel and runs the risk of his spent fuel being refused by the reprocessing plant on account of its dual origin.
It is refused by the reprocessing plant. The operator does not want this to happen, so:

The operator therefore wishes to have it officially certified, by Euratom, that the full quantity of uranium he requires is from the same ``origin''. This is when the swap takes place. Operator ``A'' approaches a second operator ``B'', in the Community, who accepts that ``A'''s 20 per cent uranium of Australian origin should be relabelled as being ``of Canadian origin'' and that, in exchange, 20 per cent of the Canadian uranium in his possession should become ``Australian''.
He can now reprocess it by getting around Australia's safeguards and Australia's wishes about reprocessing--

TALK.START.PARA: —Aren't you confusing international and internal flag swaps?

—No, I am explaining why flag swaps are done. They are done to avoid some restriction or other on the material. A country, such as Canada or the United States of America, might not want to use South African or Namibian uranium and therefore it gets a flag swap. It can get its flag swapped internally in Euratom. It can get it swapped externally. But the whole point of the flag swapping is to make material, which may be objectionable on political grounds, acceptable. It is a way of getting around other people's safeguards and wishes. As such, it is a subterfuge, it is not being honest.

SPEECH.PARA: What about the Euratom documents which just came through on flag swaps? What does Euratom want on this, and incidentally what will it get, because Australia is obviously not going to do anything about this situation? Euratom wants to weaken the safeguards conditions of Australia, the United States and Canada to win acceptance of international flag swaps. Euratom believes that Australia needs `education'. That was in its document. We must be educated to break down our resistance to international flag swaps. If Australia, the United States and Canada accept international flag swaps, Euratom does not want them to find out the other countries involved in individual swaps. European utilities have exchanged Australian uranium with South African-Namibian uranium.

This was in the documents. In fact it was included in the statement today. Euratom is promoting relabelling procedures, changes of origin and origin swaps to facilitate the entry of South African and Namibian origin uranium into the world market. Origin swaps between uranium shipments are already taking place in the US and possibly in Europe. They could involve Australian uranium without the knowledge of Euratom or the Australian Government. Euratom and the Australian Safeguards Office (ASO) cannot track the movement of Australian origin uranium through the European Economic Community (EEC). The ASO may be unable to fulfil its duty to report to Parliament. The Office cannot track the material. It has the duty to report to Parliament but it may not be able to fulfil its duty. The Australian Government would have to rely on private nuclear industry firms to respect voluntarily a ban on the export of Australian uranium to France. Even if we did ban the sale of our uranium to France, which I hope we will, flag swapping could get around the ban.

What are the implications for Australia? To summarise, the United States, one of the uranium customers, allows origin swaps. European firms may already be performing origin swaps and Euratom does not track the origin of nuclear material in the EEC. This means that a ban on Australian uranium shipments to France or any other country cannot be verified, because Australian origin material cannot be traced and could be origin swapped without the Government's knowledge. In order to track Australian uranium through the EEC, the ASO would have to get information from Euratom or private firms. But Euratom does not have that information and private firms refuse to divulge the origin of shipments held by them.

What is the obvious conclusion? It is that we must not ship our uranium, we must keep it in the ground in Australia, because once it leaves these shores there is absolutely no way of ensuring that it will not end up in the bombs that the French are exploding at Mururoa.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aulich Sen T.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the statement by the Minister for Resources, Senator Cook, in response to an allegation in the West German magazine Der Spiegel in its editions of 18 January and 15 and 22 February 1988 in relation to the so-called misuses of Australian nuclear energy material. But we are not talking about those particular allegations today, and I guess that is the major reason why the Australian Democrats have raised this particular issue. They are not talking about flag swaps or the allegations raised in the magazine Der Spiegel and repeated here by a number of their members. They are in fact talking about the whole principle of nuclear energy as an essential part of the creation and use of energy for industrial and civil purposes in our community.

SPEECH.PARA: We are talking about an industry on which many industrialised countries totally rely. If they are not totally reliant upon it, they are significantly reliant upon that energy for electricity generation. It is simply not possible for us in resource rich Australia to bury our heads in the sand and tell those countries to find some alternative source. What do we say to France, for example, which currently uses nuclear power to generate something like 70 per cent of its electricity requirements? What do we tell the Japanese, who currently use about 25 per cent of Japan's electricity grid through the nuclear area, more in fact than coal? What do we say to the other countries that I will presently talk about? Do we say to them `Look for some other alternative source', if they are resource poor? How do we change the economic infrastructure of countries that for years have relied upon nuclear energy generation for their electricity basis?

I wish to read to the Senate the figures relating to the major world users of nuclear energy for civil purposes, to give some indication to the Senate just how reliant those countries are on nuclear energy for electricity generation, and therefore for the proper and effective operation of their industrial processes. According to the `Nuclear Power Situation: OECD Countries' of 31 December 1986, 60 per cent of all of Belgium's electrical energy requirements is generated by nuclear power; in Canada, the figure is 15 per cent; in Finland 38 per cent; in France 69.8 per cent; in the Federal Republic of Germany, 29.6 per cent; in Japan 24.6 per cent; in the Netherlands 5.9 per cent; in Spain 28 per cent; and Sweden, the country that Senator Sanders talked about a while ago, is still reliant to a degree of 50 per cent on nuclear power to generate electrical energy. That country is not exactly turning its back on nuclear energy. The figure for Switzerland is 39 per cent; for the United Kingdom, 18.4 per cent; and for the United States, 16.6 per cent. This is irrefutable evidence that all of those developed countries, most of the developed countries in Europe, rely significantly on nuclear energy to provide their basic electrical energy to heat houses, run factories and base their industrial growth on.

Are Australians going to stand here and say that the use of nuclear power for peaceful purposes such as this is to be suddenly banned? Are we going to play God to those countries and say, `Look for other sources; go for coal and pollute your valleys, pollute your cities.'? Are we to say to Japan, `Look for other methods of supplying your energy, import more coal from around the world, lift the cost of your economic infrastructure and make yourself an inefficient, ineffective and uncompetitive exporter.'? Of course not. Australia cannot play God to those countries.

The Government recognises that nuclear energy is potentially dangerous. We recognise the danger to mankind of a proliferation of nuclear weapons, but we also realise that the rest of the world is dependent upon nuclear energy to generate the basis of its industrial growth. The Australian policy is quite clear. We say that no Australian uranium is to be exported or sold to any country which cannot guarantee that that uranium will not be used for research into or the development or manufacture of nuclear weapons. That is totally unequivocal. We say that Australian uranium can be sold to those countries which are prepared to enter into clear, legally binding bilateral agreements with us that they will use that uranium only for civil purposes. They must agree to inspectorates, inspections and a regime of control geared towards ensuring that there is no diversion of uranium from civil to military purposes. Those countries accept that regime which we write into the bilateral agreements.

We believe that the allegations raised in Der Spiegel, the allegations raised in this House, and those raised in the Press of this country by various politicians and journalists, ought to be raised if there is a genuine concern about breaches of those safeguards. This Government ought to be concerned if that is the case. The Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) is concerned. He took those allegations seriously. He knew that behind those allegations was probably a degree of political speculation and point-scoring on the part of, for example, the Australian Democrats or the Nuclear Disarmament Party, who are basically out to prove that the use of nuclear energy, full stop, ought to be banned. We know that that may have been their motivation, but we accept in good faith that some of those allegations do need looking at. We do not accept that they are facts, as Senator Sanders said. They are not facts; they are currently allegations.

The Government's response has been quick. Its response has been to go through all the processes that are set in train to check out allegations such as these. For example, by the time Parliament returned, I think on 22 February, Senator Cook was ready to respond to a question about this issue. The Der Spiegel article itself had been translated and double checked, and a response obtained. That was less than one month after the first allegation appeared in Der Spiegel. Senator Cook did not sit on his backside, nor did the Australian Safeguards Office. The Government would be concerned if these allegations were true but we are simply not going to say in this House for the sake of political expediency, as Senator Sanders has done, that these are facts. It is precisely that type of irresponsible rabblerousing that not only gives the nuclear industry a bad name-and that is deliberate on the part of some groups in the community-but also ensures that no Government will ever confidently be able to set up a regime which it can sell to the community, which it can convince the community is an acceptable way of responsibly controlling the growth of the nuclear power around the world. As I indicated before, we cannot turn our backs on the reliance on nuclear energy in this world. It is an irrelevance and socially irresponsible to do so.

There has been a certain degree of changing of horses in mid-stream by the Democrats over this issue, and that concerns me. Originally the allegations were lifted from Der Spiegel in relation to flag swapping. Initially there was an attempt to show that flag swapping, particularly internal flag swapping, was deliberately intended to breach the safeguards that apply in a number of those bilateral agreements, that in fact there was some sort of conspiracy to defraud. Flag swapping is now under attack as a principle of operation. The Democrats have moved from saying that these are allegations about corruption and deceit to pushing the view that flag swapping, per se, is unethical and probably an ineffective way of covering the possible abuses of nuclear power, particularly nuclear material that could be diverted for military purposes.

We have to ask a simple question. We can do the bookkeeping, the auditing, the swapping through the written material, as Senator Sanders indicated, which is basically the way in which flag swapping is done, or we have the alternative of physically transporting the material from A to B, from buyer to seller, from user to processor and from producer to processor. Let us look at the consequences of that. In that situation we would have nuclear material moving around Europe, being transferred between countries. There would be no paperwork, as there is with flag swapping, but the physical movement of nuclear material by rail or by ship around the world. Consider the possibilities of increasing the movement of that sort of material around Europe. We would increase, for example, the possibilities for terrorism and the possibilities for accidents in the transport system, on the highways and railways and in the shipping lanes. We would have the whole problem of ensuring that we had security tight enough to protect the movement of that material, but it might well be security so tight that there was an invasion of the civil liberties of citizens who live near or have any contact with that particular transport system.

If one disagrees with that viewpoint one should look very closely at what happened with the cruise missiles stationed in Britain. There is simply a blocking off of highways for significant periods. There is a takeover of the roadside control points and there is no travel by private individuals on the highways designated for the conveyance of these cruise missiles. The simple fact is that the need to secure those missiles has taken over the rights of individuals in the British community. Amplify that to moving nuclear material around Europe in the way that has presumably been proposed by Senator Sanders in opposition to the concept of flag swapping, and one can quite easily see the danger not only to safety but also to people's civil liberties, particularly in Europe.
I indicate once again the Government's concern in regard to these allegations-not the allegations per se but the motivation behind them being raised and the way in which the debate has been changed.

The Minister for Resources had the article of 15 January translated and, as I indicated, when he was asked a question in the Senate on this matter on 22 February he said that by that time his officers had already translated the article and had set in train an examination of the allegations. The Minister's answer certainly indicates that he intends to take action in regard to this matter. However, it is important that the Senate maintain the debate at a level of credibility, that we look at ways of improving Australia's safeguards for the overseas sale of Australian nuclear material. We should not attack the nuclear energy industry per se, but we should work together responsibly to ensure that Australia sets the appropriate pattern for the transmission, sale and processing of uranium throughout the world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening we are debating a statement by the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) on Australian nuclear safeguards. In addressing this matter I will dwell particularly on the word `safeguards' because I have always regarded that term and everything that it implies as a euphemism behind which governments, commercial nuclear establishments, government and semi-government interests-such as the Australian Atomic Energy Commission, the British Atomic Energy Authority, and the Department of Energy and the Nuclear Regulatory Commission in the United States-hide, because there are no such things as safeguards. No reliance can be placed on safeguards whatsoever. The process is a lie behind which the civil and military nuclear programs have become established and are maintained. That is the point that I really wish to make.

SPEECH.PARA: I pick up a statement made by the Minister for Resources and see attached to it a diagram entitled `Major Steps in the Uranium Fuel Cycle'. I do not know how many times I have seen diagrams such as this. It is not possible to illustrate it so I simply point out that it shows a completed cycle which begins with mining, then goes on to the conversion of yellowcake to uranium hexafluoride, enrichment, fuel fabrication, its placement in a nuclear power station, the storage of spent fuel, reprocessing, and then turning it back into uranium hexafluoride and completing the cycle.

One of the nations that Senator Aulich mentioned, the United States-until quite recently the nation with the largest total commitment to nuclear power-has no commercial reprocessing whatsoever. The only reprocessing in that country at the present time, with very few exceptions, is for the extraction of plutonium for the manufacture of weapons. There is no such thing as a nuclear fuel cycle. That cycle has not been closed for the very good reason that it is very expensive indeed-in terms of both human health and money associated with reprocessing.

In this place not so long ago I gave the example of a nuclear reprocessing plant which operated in West Valley just outside New York between 1967 and 1971. During that time the plant employed 10 temporary workers for every permanent worker, because it could operate only by exposing workers up to the allowable limit of radiation. Workers were employed for as little as three minutes in some cases and were then given half a day's pay and dismissed. In other words, workers were employed for the ability of their bodies to absorb radiation-not because they had any particular skills. That poses very serious moral questions for all those who support nuclear power because they present reprocessing as an implicit and necessary part of the nuclear fuel cycle, and it has been presented to us in that way this afternoon.

Recent recalculation of the Hiroshima-Nagasaki data strongly suggests that the allowable radiation limits now in place in this country and in most other countries around the world, with the exception of the United Kingdom, are between five and 15 times too high. Recently the United Kingdom reduced its allowable levels of radiation by a factor of three. If reprocessing could not continue under the old standards, I wonder how it will proceed under the new standards. What has been presented to us this afternoon, on its own evidence, bears a very considerable lie.

Safeguards as such are essentially impossible. The whole nuclear fuel process is essentially identical for military and civil purposes. The same sort of hardware is involved and plutonium for military purposes is created in reactors which are essentially no different from civil reactors. In fact, the Calder Hall reactor, which manufactures the plutonium from Australian uranium which was exploded at Maralinga, was the first civil nuclear power station to come on line in the UK. Some of that plutonium it manufactured is still in Australia. I note that Senator Collins is present in the chamber. I point out that that plutonium is still seriously contaminating areas now being offered back to the Aboriginal community for occupation. Right from the beginning there has been an inextricable mixing of the civil and military nuclear programs, and there is no way that they can be kept separate.

It was mentioned earlier this afternoon that many countries have made a commitment to nuclear power. Looking at the history, one finds abundant evidence in the literature that it began in the US as a purely civil process under President Eisenhower and the Atoms for Peace program in, I believe, about 1953. Looking at the history, one finds that at that time the Americans spent $4.7 billion-and I think that figure is correct; I have not been able to find it in my papers-promoting the civil use of nuclear power to large organisations such as Westinghouse and others which went on to develop nuclear power.

One can find from then on over many decades declarations from pro-nuclear people within the nuclear power industry to the effect that nuclear power would never have become established had it been left to normal commercial or market forces. It was only because the Government weighed in to such a massive extent and got organisations such as Westinghouse, General Electric and other large multinational organisations to invest large amounts of money in the development of this program that it ever made it off the ground.

Senator Lewis said jokingly that there were no alternatives. As recently as a couple of weeks ago our newspapers quoted the cost of the latest nuclear plant to come on line just outside New York. It is, I think, a 1,080 megawatt station and it cost $8.6 billion-$8.60 per watt. In Australia one can buy retail small solar power units for $10 a watt or even less, and with large units one can do considerably better than that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you got one installed?
—This is a rapidly moving technology, Senator Collins, and indeed I do have a solar panel which I use, as a matter of fact.
—For hot water; I have one of those.
—It is a solar panel which I use for electricity generation.
—I have a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President: it relates to the amount of interjection on and harassment of Senator Coulter.
—I have called senators on my left to order and I hope that they will adhere to that.

—France was mentioned as an example. France has gone into considerable international debt, a substantial portion of which is borne by Electricite de France because of its commitment to building nuclear power stations. While it is true that the percentage of electricity derived from nuclear sources in France is high, for a number of years France has continued to build nuclear power stations simply to keep its nuclear power station building industry alive, not because it needs more nuclear power. Having made that very considerable capital investment, it now has to generate cash flow from that. Of course, it uses those reactors to generate electricity and, in fact, it is exporting electricity from France to other European countries at below cost to generate the cash flow, to help to repay that very large capital indebtedness.

SPEECH.PARA: Sweden was mentioned: it is true that a large proportion of Sweden's electricity is derived from nuclear sources. I point out in passing here that the total percentage of energy which a country uses as electricity is quite small, so even if it is only 50 per cent, perhaps only 8 or 10 per cent of total energy is being derived from nuclear sources. Nonetheless, despite that dependency, through a referendum several years ago Sweden decided to phase out its nuclear power stations. Following the Chernobyl disaster a further referendum was held, and the Swedish people have decided to speed up that phase-out. In terms of the cost of nuclear power, I mention in passing here that even the Russians have estimated the incidence of up to 40,000 cancers in western Russian alone as a consequence of that single reactor accident at Chernobyl. One must ask the question: How does one estimate costs of renewables vis-a-vis nuclear power?

The principal point I want to make this evening concerns the record of what was actually happening with one of our nuclear trading partners in 1983, at the time the Labor Government came into office and at the conclusion of a number of years of Liberal Party government. There was abundant evidence at that time that the United Kingdom was supplying and had supplied civil plutonium to the United States of America military program. Part of the reason that this came about was that the Americans were politically embarrassed about taking their own plutonium from their civil program into their military program and sought to buy UK plutonium instead. A pro-nuclear worker in the Central Electricity Generating Board who had always defended civil nuclear power-as Liberal Party and National Party members are doing here this afternoon-on the grounds that there was a distinct and identifiable difference between the civil and military programs and one could separate the two, suddenly discovered that civil plutonium from the UK was going into the US military program and went public on it. The officer was sacked and, in the process of reinstatement, this story came out. I now refer to an article published in a 1983 edition of the New Scientist. The article is sub-headed:
Britain's civil nuclear power program is said to have produced a stockpile of plutonium big enough to make 14,000 nuclear warheads. No one is accountable for the destination and use of this material.
Britain is a country with which we have regularly traded and to which we have supplied uranium. The article continues:
As well as generating electricity, Magnox reactors-
which are the oxide based reactors which have been commonly used in the United Kingdom-

are particularly efficient at producing plutonium . . . Past links between the civil use of nuclear power and its military application are clearly documented, giving the lie to government blandishments that there are no connections. The UK's first so-called commercial nuclear reactor, the Calder Hall Magnox, Cumbria, began operating in 1956. It was designed, and that particular type of reactor developed, with a dual purpose in mind: to produce plutonium for the military with 50 megawatts of electricity as a byproduct.

Calder Hall's four reactors and the quartet at Chapel Cross, Dumfriesshire, now run by British Nuclear Fuels Ltd, produce plutonium for the Ministry of Defence. Britain's civil nuclear power stations also produce plutonium. The official stance is that none of this plutonium is destined for anything other than non-military purposes . . . Among a bundle of parliamentary answers on the topic submitted-
this is the topic of diversion-

by Priddle are extracts from Hansard of 9 March this year [that is, 1983]. They include a written exchange involving Under Secretary John Moore. He explained that plutonium derived from the Central Electricity Generating Board and South of Scotland Electricity Board Magnox power stations was exported to the US before 1971.

Moore said that the plutonium was used for civil purposes in the US. In return, under a barter arrangement, a quantity of highly enriched uranium for the UK defence programme was obtained. The export of plutonium has therefore benefited the UK defence programme . . . There have been other developments which point to an overlap between civil and military use of nuclear power. In the late 1950s the government asked the CEGB to modify the design of a number of advanced gas-cooled reactors. This involved changes in the refuelling system; it was a bid to make it easier to obtain weapons-grade plutonium.

Then, in 1985-well within the time of this Labor Government's time in office-there appeared in the journal Nature, a well-respected scientific journal, a paper on an estimation of the total production of plutonium in the British civil nuclear power system. This is a detailed assessment, looking at each individual power station and, given the amount of power produced, the amount of plutonium that it would generate. The article states:

We conclude that 6.3 plus or minus 0.8 tons of civil plutonium, approximately one sixth of the total civil stockpile, are currently missing. We believe that there is at least 2 tons of UK civil plutonium in destinations other than those admitted in parliamentary answers. Until this is clarified the suspicion will exist that these destinations could be military.

It then pointed out that this was a most unsatisfactory situation. It is pointed out that, very cleverly, the Central Electricity Generating Board never published the figures for the plutonium production for individual power stations. The Central Electricity Generating Board answered that article but it did not reveal the actual figures for plutonium production. The authors of the article subsequently answered that correspondence and pointed out that the Central Electricity Generating Board could easily have disposed of this question of the diversion by simply revealing the figures but had chosen not to do that. Finally, the gentleman who had been a long term employee of the Central Electricity Generating Board and who had been sacked wrote a letter and pointed out a number of rather disturbing factors. He said:
First, CEGB-
the Central Electricity Generating Board-

is party to a statement that `` . . . approximately four tonnes . . . '' of such plutonium has been exported to the United States under the provisions of the 1958 Mutual Defence Agreement and its 1959 Amendment, Cmnd 859 (The Electrical Power Engineer, page 163, August/September 1984).
Second, Paragraph C of Article V of Cmnd 859 specifies an exclusive use of this plutonium: ``the preparation or implementation of defence plans'' . . .

Third, and setting the issue beyond reasonable doubt, a spokesman for the US government has recently stated that `` . . . the Mutual Defence Agreement actually requires the United States to use all plutonium obtained from the United Kingdom under the Agreement for military purposes . . .'' (The Electrical Power Engineer, February 1985, page 38 . . .
The apparent material inaccuracy-
which has been picked up in estimating the missing plutonium from the inventory-

is very considerable. Approximately 4,000 kg of plutonium is enough for a thousand bombs, perhaps two thousand if the design is sophisticated, more than enough to devastate the whole of Europe, or the whole of the Soviet Union, or both. Thus the apparent involvement of the UK ``civil'' nuclear power programme in weapons production is on a very large scale indeed.
Here we are talking about something far, far bigger than the flag swaps which have been talked about in recent days in the Senate. The letter continues:
A similar, apparently false statement occurs in a written Parliamentary Answer published in the first weeks of the Sizewell Inquiry-
Sizewell at that stage was a proposed nuclear power station which was under the process of public inquiry-
`` . . . no plutonium from the CEGB nuclear programme has ever been exported for use in weapons . . . '' (Hansard, Commons, 4 February 1983 . . .

There was abundant evidence at the time this Labor Government came into office and the former Liberal Government left office that one of our major trading partners for uranium exports was engaged in the transference of plutonium derived from its civil program into the American military program. That evidence is unequivocal, it is well documented. The claims that there are safeguards are nothing more than a charade or a euphemistic term behind which this Government and governments in the United Kingdom and other countries have hidden for a long time, a charade behind which the public is denied real knowledge of what is going on. The sooner that charade is torn away the better. Far from the Australian Democrats, Senator Wood and Senator Vallentine behaving irresponsibly in revealing these facts, we believe that the world will be a much better place if we do not use a source of power which is not only dangerous because of its connections with military uses but also is totally unnecessary: there are indeed other ways to go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe the statement of the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) on Australian nuclear safeguards is not reassuring. The Government cannot prove what the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has often claimed, that no Australian uranium ends up in nuclear weapons. The statement does not prove it and I think many people around the country will remain unconvinced by the statement which has been made in the House of Representatives and in the Senate today.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand the Government's argument about the amount of uranium that goes in and can be accounted for on paper but I remain totally unconvinced by that as an argument that no Australian uranium ends up in nuclear weapons. The safeguards remain a paper shuffling exercise. They are not worth the paper they are written on. As Senator Sanders said, probably the only thing that we can be sure of is that no Australian paper ends up in nuclear weapons programs. However, for the first time the Government has been forced to admit publicly that once Australian yellowcake enters the nuclear fuel cycle it cannot be traced. So the debate has been very useful as an educational exercise in letting Australian people know something about the progress of what actually happens to Australian uranium in the nuclear fuel cycle.

The Government has actually had to admit the flag swapping, making an absolute farce of the Prime Minister's often repeated claim that no Australian uranium enters the nuclear weapons cycle. I ask the Government to prove that claim. The onus is on the Government to do that and I believe it cannot do it. It has not done it in this statement. Dr Hans Blix, the Director-General of the International Atomic Energy Agency, stated earlier this week in Sydney: `It is impossible to know whether or not Australian uranium is used in nuclear weapons'. He is a person who should really know about these things, as the Director-General of the IAEA. He also admitted this week that the IAEA, the agency which has international responsibility for both promoting and monitoring the nuclear industry, is understaffed. Having the IAEA in that position is a bit like putting the fox in charge of the chicken house. The IAEA has 200 inspectors who go to various nuclear establishments to ensure that no diversion from nuclear energy production to nuclear weapons production takes place. But it does not have enough inspectors to get around all of the nuclear establishments-that is, in countries which allow full and open inspection-and in some countries they are invited to inspect only certain establishments and not others. So this is not an adequate method of monitoring the nuclear industry.

The IAEA is on its collective back foot at the moment trying to promote an industry trying to survive against a better informed public justifiably very cautious about nuclear power following the disastrous accident at Chernobyl. The long-lasting effects of that accident are of course still to be identified but very few countries are proceeding as they had intended with their nuclear power plans. Many countries-this was detailed in the debate we had in the Senate a few weeks ago so I will not go through it again-have scaled down their plans for nuclear energy and many plants have been cancelled in various countries. I believe only the Soviet Union and Japan are proceeding with their original plans despite the accidents and the justifiable fears of the world's citizens as they become more concerned about this very dangerous form of technology which, once it is out of hand, has been proven to be totally uncontrollable.

Let us get back to the Australian uranium question. The Australian Safeguards Office (ASO) is very unhappy about the safeguards process. The ASO is the Government agency which is meant to monitor the safeguards from the Australian point of view. In its 1986-87 annual report it says in paragraph 53:
This reported method does not evaluate the possibility that undetected diversion might occur or identify the most probable ways in which attempts at diversion would be made.
Later it says:
. . . the IAEA decided to investigate alternative methods of assessment.
In paragraph 54 it says that a:
proposed new method of probabilistic assessment of safeguards effectiveness (PASE) . . . promises to overcome some of the conceptual problems encountered by the IAEA and its consultants in this work.

That is an admission that all is not well, that the safeguards are not working, when it talks about conceptual problems which have been identified. It is an enormous problem at the moment to make sure that these safeguards are actually working.

The Labor Government made two promises on the uranium question. One was that Australian uranium would not end up in nuclear weapons. It cannot prove that. The second was that it would not sell uranium to France while it was testing weapons in the South Pacific. Both of those promises have been broken and each breach reinforces the other. By selling to France, where the Government controls both the nuclear power and the nuclear weapons industries, there is an overlap of facilities. This is despite what the Government might say about a clear delineation between the two. It is impossible to establish a clear delineation between nuclear power for civil purposes and the production of material for the nuclear weapons industry in France. Possibly this happens in other countries, too, but in France it is particularly clear. I quote from a document prepared by Senator Sanders's office last year, called `France: The Nuclear Renegade', which clearly shows the links between the military and civilian nuclear programs in that country. It states:

David Albright, a researcher with the Federation of American Scientists, has written that [t]he French government does not generally distinguish between civilian and military nuclear installations, for `economic' reasons. Albright cites a 1973 CEA activity report: `The CEA must . . . adapt the production of military nuclear material . . . by taking advantage of . . . civilian programs (which have themselves greatly benefited from military programs) in order to limit the costs'.

The lack of separation is obvious from the role of the CEA, which oversees both the military and civilian programs, and its subsidiary, Cogema, which produces fuel for power reactors as well as for warheads. It is also obvious when the roles of specific nuclear facilities are considered.

There is a whole list of them but I will mention just three. The Pierrelatte uranium enrichment plant is mainly for the production of weapons-grade uranium, but has also produced the first core of the Phenix fast breeder reactor, which was initially a pilot plant for the Superphenix. The Tricastin uranium enrichment plant is mainly for the production of fuel for civilian plants, but also does low and medium level enrichment for the Pierrelatte plant, which further enriches the uranium to weapons-grade material. So the stuff goes from one plant to another and finally ends up in nuclear weapons. The Phenix fast breeder reactor was built as a pilot plant for the much larger Superphenix, which is intended for commercial operation. However, the Phenix also produces weapons-grade plutonium which, according to Nucleaonics Week, `has provided plutonium to the military branch of the CEA'. A CEA spokesman has said that Phenix `is not accessible to international safeguards since it is susceptible to working for defence needs'.

France is not even a signatory to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty. The job which the IAEA prides itself on doing is making sure that the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty is adhered to. As France is not even a signatory to the Treaty, it is outside the regulations. Its plants are not open for general inspection.

Let us consider Euratom, the European Economic Community's nuclear regulatory agency, which is, in turn, overseen by the IAEA. Euratom is delegated by the IAEA to supervise safeguards on the movement and use of nuclear materials in Europe. Documents from a meeting, of Euratom on 3 December 1987 reveal that Euratom has tried to find ways to help its clients get round international safeguards. Flag swapping is part of that process. The Government argued in its statement today that flag swapping is okay if it is within certain guidelines, such as the prohibition of international flag swaps and the prohibition of enrichment beyond 20 per cent without the Australian Government's approval. That I acknowledge. However, minutes from a meeting of Euratom reveal that the agency has considered a new reflagging system under which enriched uranium could change its nominal country of origin. This point about the country of origin of the material is most important.

Euratom officials also stated that a consider- able education effort had been made to force a decision on flag swapping by Australian authorities, but the minutes said that the Australian authorities had refused to take a decision, which is to their credit. However, Mr Kerin, when asked about this matter, said that the Australian Government preferred to rely on the International Atomic Energy Agency to monitor the fate of Australian uranium once it left our shores because Euratom was `biased'. A spokesperson for the Minister said that nevertheless the Australian Government maintained full confidence in Euratom. Why on earth would the Government have full confidence in Euratom if minutes of Euratom's own meeting show that clearly it is trying to help the companies it supplies to get round the safeguards? It is trying to put in place a new method of safeguarding so that it can change the country of origin. In other words, then it would be able to do what it liked with uranium coming from any country. So why on earth the Government is confident in Euratom, I do not know.

Let us look at some of the companies that have been involved in the scandals in Western Europe lately and which were involved in plans to reflag Australian uranium with US uranium, which would have been an international flag swap. I quote from a document put out by the World Information Service on Energy and produced in the Netherlands about Nukem and Transnuklear, two of the companies which have been identified and referred to in the documents presented to the Australian Government in the last few weeks. The document states:

West German authorities, after closing down Nukem's daughter factory, Transnuklear (TN) in December 1987, have now also taken away Nukem's operating licence. Federal German Environmental Minister Topfer is denying any relation between closing down Nukem and an assumed delivery of plutonium to Pakistan.
That is another issue, which I will not go into. The document continues:
Indeed there were enough reasons to close down Nukem even without the assumed `plutonium-connection'.
Some of the reasons given were as follows:
Nukem had known about the Transnuklear bribe affair . . . for a long time, but had not informed officials.

Its daughter company had been closed down earlier because it had been accused of bribery and corruption. Nukem knew about that but did not inform Euratom, which is meant to be the watchdog agency. The document continues:

Radiated waste had been illegally manipulated at Nukem. During a transport from the Belgium nuclear research centre to the Nukem factory in Hanau, FRG two barrels of highly radioactive uranium disappeared. Nukem is unable to explain how they disappeared and where they are now. After Transnuklear and Nukem had been found to be much involved in a system of `bribes driven by criminal energy' it has to be closed. The prominent Green member of West German Parliament Otto Schily stated: `It has obviously already come so far that we have to be thankful to our government because they finally did what is right'. According to the German news magazine `Der Spiegel', state officials had known about this affair several months ago and should have ordered Nukem closed down earlier.

Why on earth we should believe either Euratom or the companies with which it deals I cannot imagine. It is a foolish government that would continue to trust such companies when their track records are so abysmal.

I turn to the analogy about banking used in the Minister's statement earlier this afternoon. The Minister talked about depositing $50 in the bank, saying that when one wants to withdraw one's $50 one does not expect to get exactly the same $50 back. Of course not. What a ridiculous notion! The point is that if one does not feel confident about the end use to which one's $50 will be put by a particular bank one does not deposit it in the first place. One does not put one's money into a questionable organisation. The reason why I chose to remove my personal accounts from the Westpac Banking Corporation was that Westpac was involved in promoting uranium mining. I chose a building society which builds houses in which people can live, something which is socially useful, as opposed to allowing banks to use one's money to do something which one believes is morally reprehensible. If the Government is not confident that Australian uranium-molecule for molecule, atom for atom-cannot be used for nuclear weapons it should not be engaged in the process in the first place. My analogy proves the point precisely in regard to the opponents of the Government's policy and to the whole question of flag swapping. If we cannot trace Australian uranium, which the Government has now admitted to, we should not be involved in selling it in the first place.

As Senator Coulter has explained, there is no clear delineation between civil and military uses of nuclear technology. He showed the inextricable links between the civilian and military aspects. This is the premise on which the Government rests its case-that there is a distinction between the two. It is a false premise. The Government's case cannot be proved. The onus is on the Government to prove its claim, but it cannot do it.

Nor has the Government said that the documents from Euratom are false or that the information about Nukem and Transnuklear and their plans for sidestepping guidelines is untrue. The Government has not disproved the documents which have been presented to it. It has merely tried to explain them away by lots of talk about paper shuffling. We know about the paper shuffling. It is exactly the point the peace movement has been making for years. Australian uranium can be accounted for on paper, but not in fact. Accounting for it on paper is beside the point. The only way to be sure that Australian uranium does not end up in nuclear weapons is to leave it in the ground so that it does not get into the nuclear cycle in the first place.

No doubt we will hear from Senator MacGibbon in this debate that we should be producing fuel rods here in Australia to eliminate the need for worry about diversion or inadequate safeguards. He and others like him will say that that will be a great economic boon to Australia. It must be pointed out that there are many examples of the dangers of the nuclear fuel cycle at every stage-environmental and health hazards-and the end problem of waste disposal has not been canvassed and, I believe, is not even seriously considered by proponents of the industry. No amount of dollars can compensate for environmental and health hazards, and we should be looking much further than at a dollar's reward for involvement in what must be a very dangerous industry. The Australian Labor Party Conference that is coming up in Hobart in June no doubt will be debating this issue, and I hope that it will be a lively debate. Many people who support the Labor Party are extremely dismayed that the two promises made by the Labor Party about uranium have been broken. Finally, I repeat that the onus is on the Government to prove its claim that no Australian uranium enters the nuclear weapons fuel cycle. It has not proved that claim with this document; it cannot prove it at all. Therefore, the export of Australian uranium must stop.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is tonight debating a statement made by the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) on Australian nuclear safeguards. It is an excellent statement that stands secure against any attack from any quarter. We have to waste time on what should be a quite unnecessary exercise because of a series of allegations in a German sensationalist magazine. It was, in the terms of trade of the journalist, a beat-up. It was shamelessly misrepresented by the nuclear disarmers and that other far Left party, the Australian Democrats. They preyed, as they always do, on the basest of human emotions-the emotion of fear. Never for the Democrats, never for the disarmers, the nobility of reason-just the basest of fear. They say, `Hide in the corner or under the bed; do not cope with the problems of life'.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is, as the ministerial statement says, that no Australian uranium is going into nuclear weapons. It is a deliberate misrepresentation by the proponents of this story to create a fear that somehow or other Australian uranium is going into the nuclear weapon stockpiles of the world. As Senator Lewis said, the safeguards Australia has on the peaceful uses of nuclear energy are the strongest in the world. Those safeguards were introduced by previous Liberal-National Party governments and are so strong that they have not been improved or modified by the present Government. The analogy used by the Minister was that of a bank, despite Senator Vallentine's ridicule. I am delighted that she has taken her account away from Westpac. Having been a lifetime customer of the Wales, as it was, I would not like to have my account rubbing shoulders with Senator Vallentine's-I have more pride than that. Be that as it may, whether the uranium oxide is pooled in Europe before it is processed and the same amount is taken out for civil uses as goes in, is the auditing test that is applied.

Senator Aulich made a very good point when he said that the argument had now taken a very sinister turn. Originally the nuclear disarmament people were saying that we were faced with corruption and deceit by the agencies in Europe handling Australian uranium, but the argument has now changed to one that is very much against flag swapping. The fact that if we put uranium in we do not know that we get precisely the same uranium atoms out is irrelevant, because we get out precisely the same amount of uranium as we put in for civil uses. The point raised by Senator Aulich was that, if one destroys the complex systems that are in place, one is left with a free-for-all. Senator Wood and Senator Vallentine have no concept of the massive volume of uranium that is being traded around the world. It runs into thousands of tonnes. At present it is all very carefully controlled and audited. If one breaks the system at present, instead of working intelligently to improve it and finetune it, there will be chaos. The international traffic in uranium will be completely out of control, a bit like the drug traffic-and we certainly do not want to see that happen.

The world, as I have said before in this place, cannot unlearn nuclear physics. Nuclear physics gives humanity many benefits. It carries with it great risks when used in the armaments field, but in the civil field it has enormous benefits. At present one can say, without fear of challenge, that it is the only way that we are to lift the standard of living of the human race in the Third World countries to the standards that we take as normal. One cannot control the spread of nuclear technology to nuclear weapons just by putting a prohibition on the technology or the uranium involved. Uranium can be got from seawater. It occurs naturally in many countries. It might not occur in the richness of the ore bodies that we have in Australia, as we have the richest in the world, but most countries have some uranium. If one wants it, one can get it if one pays enough money. Similarly, all countries today have the intellectual resources in some of their people, with the expenditure of enough money, to develop nuclear weapons. So a prohibition on technology does not work. We have to look for other resources.

In the last 20 or 30 years the world has developed three very good systems to control the spread of nuclear weapons and those techniques have been effective. The first and the most important is the political integrity of the individual countries and their governments-the will not to acquire nuclear weapons. That is the most important factor of all. The second important factor is the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty (NPT) to which there are now 134 signatory countries. This is the greatest treaty in the world today in the field of arms control. It can be claimed that the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty has stopped the horizontal spread of nuclear weapons in the world. I and probably most honourable senators in this chamber remember the time in the early 1960s when President Kennedy in the United States of America forecast that within 10 to 12 years 22 to 25 countries in the world would possess nuclear weapons. That has not happened. We still have the same five countries that officially possess nuclear weapons that existed when President Kennedy made that statement. We suspect that there are another five nuclear-armed powers in the world, but, if those suspicions are borne out, that takes us to 10. It is less than half the projection that was made in the early 1960s. The proof that those countries have not acquired weapons lies in the existence of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty.

The third great safeguard that we have against the spread of nuclear technology to nuclear weapons is the safeguards systems of the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA), a body derived by the disarmers and the Democrats as being utterly worthless. The IAEA is a very professional scientific body set up to control the nuclear industry. Ninety-five per cent-the overwhelming majority of signatories to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty-some 134 nations, have their peaceful nuclear facilities investigated by the IAEA. This is carried out on a very small budget for an international body-$150m in total, $50m for the safeguards. That need is expanding all the time because the use of nuclear power for generation is expanding, despite what the doomsday people say. In 25 years of careful scientific investigation not one case of cheating has been detected by the IAEA.

That leads me to the first point that I made about the political integrity of those countries that have signed the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty. The nuclear generating world is very big. If one listened to some of the people who speak in this chamber, one would think that nuclear powerhouses were closing down all over the world. The truth is that in the last year alone 23 new stations were commissioned. There is a total of 417 stations operating around the world in at least 26 different countries, supplying about 16 per cent of all world power. In some highly developed countries, between 50 per cent and 70 per cent of electrical energy is being generated from nuclear generating sources.

If there is one country that should be sensitive about nuclear power it is Japan. It is the only country in the world that has been subjected to the use of nuclear weapons. But Japan is a most enthusiastic and expanding user of nuclear energy, despite the cost to it. It is cheaper for it to buy oil or coal, particularly at the rate it is paying for coal from Australia. Even having regard to the environmental problems of being in an earthquake belt and the cost that that imposes on the building of generating stations, Japan is building more and more nuclear power stations.

The misrepresentation that takes place in this chamber that nuclear power is going out of fashion fundamentally has its source in the fact that the world economies have faced a downturn in the last 10 to 12 years. It has been for that reason, and that reason alone, that new orders for nuclear powerhouses have not been signed. Demand for nuclear power has not increased. We do not need to go very far from Canberra to find, in my State of Queensland, a surfeit of electrical generating power. It has a thermal, coal fired generation system. The expectation 10 to 15 years ago when those orders were placed was that world economies were expanding at such a rate that there should be a great movement to build more electrical power stations.

Electrical power is the heart and soul of an industrialised society. With the economic downturns that we have had since the early to mid-1970s the need has not increased. The prime basic reason that the world has to have nuclear power-and there are some very good reasons for it-of course, is the environmental argument. I find it amazing that people in this chamber who are so opposed to nuclear power talk about environmental issues in relation to rainforests, rock wallabies or things like that. The biggest environmental issue is the survival of the human race. The human race simply cannot survive if we go on burning fossil fuels. I will come back to that point in a moment.

The other reason for nuclear power is that a lot of countries simply do not have the option of using their own fossil fuels. They have to import either oil or coal at great cost. They may as well pay a little extra if they can to get the self-sufficiency that nuclear generation brings.
