That leads me to one of the eternal problems of the Democrats and the nuclear disarmers-the sheer immorality of their argument; an argument that is based on selfishness and greed. So long as they are warm in their beds at night and well fed they do not give a damn about anyone else in the world.

People like Senator Wood do not give a damn about the 100 million poor and starving in Bangladesh. Bangladesh, with its 100 million people, has an electrical generating capability of 1,000 megawatts. Sweden, with eight million people, has a generating capacity of 35,000 megawatts. Why can the people in Bangladesh not enjoy the standard of living that we enjoy in Australia? Why can they not have the standard of living that is enjoyed in Europe? They are entitled to that. If they are to get that standard of living they must have the ability to generate electrical power because without it there are no factories, no consumer goods, no lighting or heating for the homes and nothing to cook with.

We simply have to recognise the need for power around the world if we are to lift the standard of living. The antagonists of nuclear power are prepared to see people in countries such as Bangladesh languish and die in poverty for generation after generation. Even in the developed world the effects of generating power from thermal sources are enormous. Acid rain has destroyed the lakes in the western part of the Scandinavian peninsula. Acid rain has destroyed huge tracts of forest in eastern Europe and in West Germany-all because people are burning coal or oil and producing sulphur dioxide which turns into sulphurous acid and precipitates with rain. Sulphur dioxide can be controlled if one is prepared to spend enough money by putting scrubbers in the exhaust systems in the stacks of the furnaces of thermal generating stations. But one cannot control carbon dioxide.

It is very interesting to hear someone like Senator Coulter rattle off formulae concerning fluorocarbons that he has memorised before coming into the chamber. He talked about the way in which fluorocarbons diminish 1 or 2 per cent of the ozone layer. Why does he not deal honestly with the question? The honest approach to the greenhouse effect is that 50 per cent of the problems arise from carbon dioxide. There is no way of stopping the production of carbon dioxide when one burns oil or coal. The human race is choking to death because of the suffocation and pollution of the atmosphere from thermal stations. If honourable senators think it is bad at the moment they should look ahead another 10 years. By the turn of the century China has a proposition to increase its electrical generating capacity by 100,000 megawatts. Seventy per cent of that generation will be from coal fired and dirty coal fired sources. The effects of that Chinese expansion in electrical generating capacity will have a devastating effect on the quality of life of people in that country and in neighbouring countries.

Not many people have died as a consequence of working in nuclear powerhouses. I cannot think of any. But in the mining of coal and in the drilling for oil there is a death penalty which runs into thousands a year. There is a death penalty amongst the citizens of the country from lung cancer, from the carcinogens and from the products of combustion. There is a thousand-fold increase in morbidity due to respiratory complaints such as asthma, of people who have to breath the air that is polluted by burning products such as hydrocarbons in the form of liquid-oil-or as coal.

Looking ahead, the world cannot go on generating the power that it does from thermal sources. Nuclear energy is an inevitable part of it. What can we do about it in Australia? We can get back to those three things that I talked about. We should work constructively to develop the political will in countries not to use nuclear power for weapon sources. We can finetune and improve the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty. While it is an excellent treaty it is nowhere near its full development. It requires the constant vigilance of all of us to develop it. We can increase the safeguards of the IAEA. I am very disappointed to learn that Australia-although it can find as much money as it wants for bodies such as the International Labour Organisation, the United Nations Educational Scientific and Cultural Organisation, and other bodies that really do not help the Australian people much in any way-is paying only 65 per cent of what it should be paying towards the $50m which is allocated from the $150m IAEA budget to safeguards developments.

Above all, we should embark on a public education campaign by pointing out the environmental disaster that is facing us as a world if we go on burning fuel willy nilly to run our factories and maintain our standards of living. Despite what the Democrats and the nuclear disarmers think, none of us want to go back to the caves and none of us are going back to the caves. We are going to maintain the standards of living we have, and therefore the obligation is inevitably upon us to find a way of doing it safely and cleanly without damage to the environment or to our health.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The uranium debate in Australia has been going for a long time now and no doubt will continue for many years to come. It is a debate that I am very familiar with because I have been on both sides of it. I started off in the uranium debate a decade ago being very prominently anti-uranium. The reason for that was quite simple: the constituents in my electorate in those days, 100 per cent of them, did not want any kind of mining on their land, but uranium happened to be found and so it was mined. My constituents elected me to represent them and I did so forcefully. Over 10 years the views of the constituents in my electorate have changed substantially, and so have mine, not in any knee-jerk way but in the course of examining the world situation rather than my own situation in the Northern Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: One problem that I would have in being anti-uranium now is that I have to concede that I am simply not selfish enough, exclusive enough or elitist enough to be anti-uranium. That typifies for me these days, without any personal reflections, most of the people in Australia who are so virulently anti-uranium. The difficulty is that most modern economies are fuelled by electricity. Electricity would have to be rated-and I am sure that Senator Coulter would agree with this-as one of the most fundamental historical discoveries ever made by mankind for providing the energy which is in so much demand around the world. I am not a gung ho advocate of uranium; I never have been. I am in pretty much the same position as the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on uranium. Bob Hawke has said, not in recent years but certainly many times publicly-and he has been very consistent on uranium for many years now-that he wished uranium had never been found. That is pretty much where I am at on uranium: I wish that it had never been found. I am happy to acknowledge, however, the historical fact that it was found and that it is used for the generation of electricity.

I think that this has been a fairly uninspiring debate this afternoon in terms of the contributions from the people who have raised the subject of the so-called flag swapping. I thought the key speaker would arguably have been Senator Sanders. I thought his contribution was very light on indeed. There is a reason for that, and Senator MacGibbon has canvassed it. The reason is very simple: the debate has changed. It changed very rapidly in 24 hours. I think it has probably changed as a result of Senator Sanders finding out that most of his arguments had run out of steam. As Senator MacGibbon pointed out quite accurately, the debate did not start simply on flag swapping; it started on allegations that Australian uranium had been diverted into nuclear weapons. I saw Senator Sanders on television with his little dummies, his plastic bags, his flags and the paraphernalia that he set himself up with on television.

The second stage of the allegations was that it had been swapped for `scrap', which was the word used. It had not been swapped for other uranium of equal quality; it had been swapped for worthless scrap. In fact, on television Senator Sanders had his plastic garbage pail full of garbage with the United States flag stuck in it. As we now know, these myths have been exploded very rapidly indeed. As always happens, those opposite rapidly did another side step and we have had a debate all afternoon on whether we can track individual atoms of Australian uranium through the system. As I and other senators pointed out to Senator Sanders, there is nothing new about that. That has been an integral part of the safeguards arrangements since they were first introduced into this Parliament many years ago. Why have we not heard about it before? Why has it suddenly arisen today? It has suddenly arisen today because the original allegations that were raised were not the allegations that were canvassed in debate here today. I waited in vain to hear Senator Sanders canvass the arguments about Australian uranium being swapped for scrap. That was his original performance. We never heard it today. I waited in vain.

Senator Coulter was remarkably private about what he used his solar panel for. He kept on saying that he had a solar panel in South Australia which was an alternative source of energy and that we can close down nuclear power. He said half a dozen times, `I have a solar panel'; but, despite constant interjections, he refused to disclose what he used his solar panel for.

TALK.START.PARA: —I use it for light and radio.

—Fine. I suggest to the honourable senator, with respect, that he contact the Japanese Government and suggest that it run a landline to South Australia and plug it into his solar panel, because 25 per cent of the entire Japanese generating capacity is in nuclear power. I hate referring to Senator MacGibbon's speech three times in one debate, but I am forced to. Senator MacGibbon has again canvassed the argument-and I make the point just as emphatically-that if there is one country on earth which has less reason to use nuclear fuel, it is Japan. If there is one country on earth which is technologically innovative, it is Japan. It is a good country to look at in terms of our selfish, arrogant, elitist attitude that people should not use nuclear power. When we are sitting in a temperate country with blue skies and sunshine every day and with 400 years of coal reserves in the ground, that is a very convenient argument for Australians to run! Japan is a good country to look at because it had two atomic bombs dropped on it not so long ago and undeniably is the most technically innovative country in the world; and it also just happens to be Australia's biggest customer.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to take a little more detailed look at Japan. As I said before, Japan generates from nuclear power 25 per cent of the electricity that fuels that giant economy. Nuclear power is important to Japan because the Japanese are energy import dependent, and the Japanese Ministry of International Trade and Industry produced a major report entitled Nuclear Energy Vision-Perspectives of Nuclear Energy for the 21st Century, a report commissioned by the Japanese Government which was brought down in September 1986. In my view, it is required reading for any Australian seriously interested in uranium. Although it is a little presumptuous, I will quote from an unpublished paper on uranium mining, that I have written with particular reference to markets. It has not been published yet. I have written this paper in response to another paper which has been produced by my good friend, comrade and philosophical soul buddy, Peter Milton, over in the little green room! My paper, referring to the report commissioned by the Japanese Government, said:

The Report is required reading for anyone with a serious interest in the nuclear energy debate. This is particularly so for Australians interested in gaining the perspective of a modern democratic economy in our own region; which is import dependant, without indigenous energy resources, and into the bargain is our most important customer for export commodities, (including uranium). As the relevance of the Report extends beyond Japan, a number of references from it are included below . . .

There are other speakers who wish to contribute to this debate and I am anxious that they do so. I will ask leave of the Senate shortly to incorporate into Hansard what I originally was going to quote from more extensively. I will quote briefly from this report from Japan. The reason I do so is this: it annoys and infuriates me considerably when I hear people who are engaged in the uranium debate saying, as they constantly do, that we should not mine Australian uranium because it is bad for the Aboriginal people. That infuriates me because the Aboriginal people have signed two substantive agreements for major uranium mines on their land in the Northern Territory. Prior to the last Australian Labor Party National Conference, arguably the most prominent Aboriginal person in this country, Galarrwuy Yunupingu, Chairman of the Northern Lands Council, said in a public statement that the Northern Lands Council was considering taking the Labor Party to court to fight the decision of the Labor Party not to allow Koongarra and Jabiluka to proceed. It infuriates me to still hear people say `We know what is best for the Aboriginals'. As the case of the Japanese has been raised in the debate this afternoon, and as we have been told by honourable senators that nuclear power is no good for the Japanese, I thought it only fair that the Japanese should themselves be permitted to speak. I quote from the foreword of this document, which states:

. . . the share of nuclear power in the nation's total electricity supply rose to 26% for the first time exceeding oil-fired thermal generation, which stood at . . . 25% . . . The development of electric power generation has ushered in an era of `Nuclear First, Oil Second'. In displacing oil as the primary energy source, nuclear power stands shoulder to shoulder with coal and natural gas in the generation of electricity. . . . Nuclear energy, as a quasi-domestic energy, is superior in both energy security and economy.
A further paragraph states:

. . . Nuclear power now provides one fourth of total generated electricity, exceeding that of oil-fired thermal generation, thus bringing Japan into the ``Nuclear First, Oil Second' era in electricity production. Nuclear power is now the principal energy alternative to oil in Japan . . .

I do not think I can place it much more categorically myself. I seek leave of the Senate to incorporate in the Hansard that short extract from the report entitled Nuclear Energy Vision-Perspectives of Nuclear Energy for the 21st Century.
Leave granted.
The article read as follows-
FOREWORD
WHY SET OUT THE ``NUCLEAR ENERGY VISION'' NOW?
1. The general trend in setting perspectives

(1) Japan established two records in fiscal 1985 which added an important page to Japanese nuclear history. First, the nuclear power plants registered a 76% capacity factor, the highest on record in this country. If Japan's periodic inspections are taken into consideration, this is close to 100 percent. Second, the share of nuclear power in the nation's total electricity supply rose to 26% for the first time exceeding oil-fired thermal generation, which stood at the equivalent of 25%. Taken together, these records show that Japanese nuclear power has now attained a stable position. It now ranks with coal and natural gas as a primary source in place of oil. The development of electric power generation has ushered in an era of ``Nuclear First, Oil Second.'' In displacing oil as the primary energy source, nuclear power stands shoulder to shoulder with coal and natural gas in the generation of electricity.
3. The significance of nuclear energy
Nuclear energy, as a quasi-domestic energy, is superior in both energy security and economy.
(1) Energy Security

There is still a possibility that the international supply and demand for oil could again tighten in the mid- and long-term. Japan, being poor in domestic energy resources, has set its sights on nuclear power as a kernel energy source among oil alternatives. Compared with fossil fuel, it can produce higher energy per unit weight by the use of uranium fuel. Not only is it easy to transport and store this fuel, but a nuclear reactor can operate for at least a year on one fuel loading. Taking into consideration the time required for fuel fabrication, the fuel needed for a few years of operation is normally stored domestically. (Operating a 1,000 MW generating plant for one year requires 30 tons [3 trucks] of nuclear fuel, 1.3 million tons [7 large tankers] of oil, 2.2 million tons [22 large freighters] of coal and 1 million tons [16 large tankers] of natural gas.)
(2) Economy

Comparisons of generating costs differ from changes in oil prices and international exchange rates, but in the current situation, nuclear power is more economical than oil, natural gas and coal thermal generation. In addition, comparisons of generating costs throughout plant life show nuclear to be even more economical.
(4.1) Nuclear power entering era of full-fledged commercial use

. . . Nuclear power now provides one fourth of total generated electricity, exceeding that of oil-fired thermal generation, thus bringing Japan into the ``Nuclear First, Oil Second'' era in electricity production. Nuclear power is now the principal energy alternative to oil in Japan . . .
CHAPTER 2
(3.2) Uranium Production, Supply and Demand
(1) At present, the international supply and demand position of uranium is in a relaxed state. Barring a major supply disruption, the demand will be met until 2000.

(2) It will be necessary, however, to develop new mines to meet the demand after 2000. Since uranium mines require a lead time of at least 10 years from the start of exploration to the start of production, exploration and development will need to begin fairly soon to ensure that future demand can be met.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The subject has already been canvassed at length by other senators of the current place in the world of nuclear power generation in terms of its acceptance. It has been said, rightly, that it currently produces 16 per cent of the total world production of electricity, and that capacity is growing at an average rate of 5 per cent per year. There are currently 417 operating nuclear reactors, as has been said quite accurately.
—It is still less than firewood.

—Well, well! The protectors of the forests speak! That is where the debate falls down. I must say, through the Acting Deputy President, that I am desperate for someone to show me a realistic alternative to uranium, because I would like to see the industry closed down. Most of us would, I think, like to see an alternative source. But I point out the obvious thing to Senator Coulter. In the United States of America and in other countries around the world enormous sums of money have been expended by companies such as Westinghouse and General Electric, because they are not idiots, looking for alternatives. As I am sure Senator Coulter knows, they have built enormous solar complexes in California and wind generating capacities have been built around the world. But, unfortunately, they do not provide an economic substitute. One of the problems with Senator Coulter's solar panel is: what do we do when the sun don't shine! That would be a good song title, actually! That is the problem. It is easy in Australia, with our blue skies and sunshine, to talk about solar power. In the Northern Territory we make extensive use of it. One hotel-I stress one hotel-even experimented with solar powered air-conditioning. That is as far as it went. I commend the hotel for trying it, but it was not an economic success. In the Northern Territory we use solar panels as a source of domestic heating for water, which is highly successful, because we have a very high incidence of sunshine. But what do they do in the Northern Hemisphere, Senator?
—What would you do in Melbourne?

—I do not know what people would do in Melbourne. I think Ava Gardner had it right when she made On the Beach and said that Melbourne was a great place for a film about the end of the world. But in the Northern Hemisphere-and I have been there occasionally-the sun is not shining for most of the time. That is the great difficulty in applying the arrogant Southern Hemisphere attitude of some Australians to the Northern Hemisphere. They are entitled to their energy sources. Senator Coulter, Senator Wood and others who have contributed to this debate want them to freeze in the dark. We live in relative comfort but we want to impose that condition on a great many other people who have very little alternative. Many other countries do not have the extensive indigenous energy resources of this country, and they have to import most of their resources. Uranium provides an extraordinarily good alternative for them, and I will tell the honourable senator why. A 1,000-megawatt power station consumes three truck loads of nuclear fuel a year to run it. I am quoting again from my unpublished paper. That same power station requires 1.3 million tonnes of oil to produce the same amount of electricity, that is seven large tankers; 2.2 million tonnes of coal, that is 22 shipping freighters full; and one million tonnes, 16 tankers, of natural gas. Those are very relevant figures when we are talking about importing most of our energy resources per year.

SPEECH.PARA: Another problem with this debate is that the people who advocate shutting down nuclear energy plants-and I wish we could-do not seem to have the slightest difficulty in promoting an endless expansion of thermal coal-fired power stations. I will tell honourable senators what that same 1,000-megawatt coal-fired power station does for our environment every year. One coal-fired power station pumps into our atmosphere every year 7,800,000 tonnes of CO2, 40,000 tonnes of SO2, 9,500 tonnes of NO2 and 6,000 tonnes of dust. Let us have a debate in here one day, and I challenge Senator Wood and Senator Coulter to bring it on, about coal-fired power stations, and we will debate an alternative to them. I can tell Senator Coulter, with the greatest of respect, that it is not solar panels. One day it may be, but not yet. That is the problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —With pleasure.

—Fine. I challenge the honourable senator to do so, and I will look forward to the debate, because I have been begging people to show me a viable alternative for the countries who use nuclear power. There is not one at the present time. The Northern Territory, with its tiny little Government and tiny little Budget, has to its credit carried out its own experimentation into alternative energy sources and we have in fact imported hybrid rigs using both solar and wind-powered electricity generation in an attempt to provide a very real solution to the problems of the provision of power for many isolated communities in the Northern Territory, which is currently provided by burning diesel oil. That must be the most tragic waste of diesel fuel one could possibly imagine. We burnt it in the Stokes Hill power station in Darwin for 20 years to produce power for the city of Darwin. What a tragedy, hundreds of thousands of tonnes of diesel fuel went up the spout. Fortunately the Northern Territory is lucky enough to have huge supplies of natural gas, and because of the vision of a former Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, Ian Tuxworth, instead of a coal-fired power station, which was intended as an alternative for Stokes Hill, he stuck to his gas pipeline and we have got 1,500 kilometres of gas pipeline from Palm Valley providing Alice Springs, Tennant Creek, Katherine and Darwin with an indigenous energy source. That is wonderful. We do not use nuclear power in the Northern Territory, we do not need to. But many other countries do, and we have not got the right to tell them that they cannot.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Labor Party has commissioned two major reports into the uranium mining industry. Unfortunately, they have been almost forgotten. They have now got the status of being historical documents. The Labor Government of Gough Whitlam commissioned the Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry, the Fox Report, which produced 15,000 pages of transcript and examined hundreds of witnesses. It sat for ages and I did not think it was ever going to complete its work. I was involved in that exercise.

TALK.START.PARA: —So was I.

—I am sure the honourable senator was. Many of us were. Despite the fact that it took all that evidence, let me tell honourable senators-and I knew those commissioners; it was a very caring and very exhaustive exercise on their part-that they finally came down with the decision that uranium mining should proceed in Australia. It was on the basis of the recommendations of the Fox report, commissioned by a Labor government, that it did.

SPEECH.PARA: The second report into the uranium mining industry, entitled Australia's Role in the Nuclear Fuel Cycle was commissioned by the Hawke Labor Government. What did it say? It is worth having a look at it. I am sure Senator Coulter has read it. I will quote just briefly from the summary and recommendations of the Slatyer report, as it has become known. Paragraph 2.1.2 states:

In most countries several primary energy sources are used for electricity generation, with fossil fuels, mainly coal, being the main component. However, the fraction of electricity generated by nuclear energy is growing rapidly in most countries which have nuclear power programs, as stations now under construction are completed and commissioned. Altogether, some thirty countries now have nuclear power stations in operation or under construction.
The report goes on, in paragraph 2.1.5, to say:

There have also been increasing concerns about the environmental effects of coal-fired power plants in particular and fossil-fuel fired plants in general. These concerns have focused particularly on the effects of acid rain caused by chimney emissions. This is now having serious biological and environmental repercussions. In the long term, the possibility of global climatic change caused by the increasing carbon dioxide concentration of the atmosphere resulting from fossil-fuel combustion could be an even more serious effect.

I point out to Senator Coulter that a 1,000-megawatt nuclear power station produces none of the emissions I cited earlier. The report goes on, and I would like the honourable senator to listen to this:

If international tensions are to be reduced and the prospects of a peaceful global environment enhanced, the importance of national and international energy security cannot be over-emphasised. It is widely recognised that disruptions in the supply of resources of any sort have been a cause of international tension and, through human history, have led to war. For a modern society, no resources are more important than energy resources. Indeed the concern about the reliability of oil supplies, already referred to, was a major factor in the decision of many countries to turn to nuclear energy.

I have much more to say, and I daresay there will be many more opportunities for the Senate to debate this matter. However, there are other speakers and I will finish in deference to them, to give them at least a few minutes. I conclude by saying that this debate has once again been a sham. It has had nothing whatever to do with flag swapping, and Senator Sanders was kind enough to tell the Senate that. It was simply another attempt to argue that Australia should close down its uranium industry. We are not in a position to do that. We are not in a position to preach to the rest of the world. We are not in a position, in my view, being just a little bit venal about it, to hand too many more bouquets to some of our major competitors, such as Canada. If we applied that same stupid logic to wheat, wool, beef, coal, zinc, copper, iron ore and a lot of our other export commodities that are also in plentiful supply around the world the country would be bankrupt in 24 hours. The debate this afternoon has, in fact, been a bankrupt debate. I hope the next time it is brought on there will be a little more substance to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President. I think we ought to have a debate on the issues and not have the participants in the debate insulted.

SPEECH.PARA: In the Northern Territory we have the resources, we have the deposits and we have the support of probably 90 or 95 per cent of the Territory's population. The Northern Territory Government has indicated its support by approaching the Federal Government, offering to become involved in all aspects of the nuclear processing industry, including reprocessing and nuclear waste disposal. —One certainly cannot eat it but one cannot live without it. In today's modern world, the only hope for the underprivileged and undernourished in Third World areas lies in electricity, and electricity can be properly and economically generated to provide them with food, to provide them with resources and to provide them with a standard of living that is compatible with that of a more affluent society, only by the full development of the nuclear cycle, properly controlled and with safeguards fully in place. TALK.START.PARA: —The response from the Minister-Counsellor, Mr Zemskov, makes three key points. Indeed, firstly, he says that our letter was forwarded to Mr Gorbachev. Secondly, he says that `we'-presumably the Soviet Embassy-asked parliamentarians in Estonia and Lithuania to answer the message. He also states:

SPEECH.PARA: All three Baltic Soviet Socialist Republics . . . sovereign republics within the USSR and joined the Soviet Union in accordance with the wishes of their people . . . take an equal and active part in the formulation and conduct of the Soviet Union's domestic and foreign policies and their citizens exercise equal rights together with all other Soviet people that are guaranteed by the constitution of the USSR and of each republic.
The third point made by Mr Zemskov in response to our letter is that all concerns expressed in our letter are `unfounded and contradict present day realities'.

On the first point, let there be no doubts at all about the misuse of the language by Mr Zemskov. There are no real parliamentarians in the Soviet Union. How could there be when opposition parties are outlawed and when there are no genuine elections? Mr Zemskov's claim that our concerns contradict present day realities is contemptuous. What are the present day realities in the Baltic states? Recently I-and other members of this Parliament-were fortunate to meet and have frank discussions with a young Latvian freedom fighter who was expelled from the Soviet Union in July last year after spending 12 months in a labour camp. His crime was `anti Soviet activities'; that is, he was involved in peaceful demonstrations for Latvian independences. His story is one that must be told because it is a first hand account of the contemporary situation in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR).

Mr Silaraups, who had just turned 23 and had been involved in freedom fighting and fighting for the independence and basic human rights in Latvia since the age of 15, painted a graphic picture of how in 1987 Soviet authorities continued to stifle Latvia's identity by suppressing its culture and wiping out its history. It is still the case that the Soviet authorities in Latvia insist that Russian be the official language of Latvia. Despite this, native Latvians still speak Latvian amongst themselves. Indeed, a number of Latvians, particularly the young, have refused to speak any Russian at all.

In education as well there is discrimination and suppression. In Latvian schools, Russian is the first language taught. Whilst Latvians must learn Russian, Russians in Latvia need not learn Latvian. At the tertiary level, degrees or diplomas may be obtained only if exams are taken in Russian. This blatant discrimination against the Latvian people is aimed at undermining opposition to Russian ideology. It allows for no freedom of thought or expression. Mr Silaraups indicated that glasnost, to date, had not brought any real changes within the system. Whilst authorities have ceased the longstanding and notorious practice of imprisoning political dissidents, and people are in general allowed to speak more openly, they are in fact keeping a detailed record of who is saying what and of their movements. Recent reports of Soviet police and militia wielding rubber truncheons breaking up a demonstration in Kaunas, Lithuania's second largest city, give the impression that the situation has worsened since Silaraups was expelled later last year.

Other recent reports of the suppression of demonstrations, and violent threats of intimidation in Tartu, Estonia's university city, and in Tallinn, Estonia, are further evidence that promises of democratisation have been forgotten. The notorious camp 36-1 where several Ukrainian Helsinki monitors have died has been replaced by a new compound, camp 35. But nothing has really changed, only the camp's location. The guards, inmates and personnel remain the same. In the words of Nadia Svitlychna, head of the Ukrainian Helsinki Groups External Representation, in her letter to New York Times reporter A. M. Rosenthal earlier this year:

As before, Mart Niklus and Ivan Sokulsky sit in solitary confinement cells, Petro Ruban, Hryhoriy Prykhodko, Boris Romashov and Mikhail Alekseye sit together in one cell. I should also mention here that his illness-virulent tuberculosis-endangers the lives of his cell mates.

Given the facts surrounding the notorious camp 36-1, Mr Rosenthal's observation that, rather than represent any genuine reform, the closure of the camp may have more to do with the prospect of a visiting Western delegation to inspect the camp four weeks later `so Moscow can keep its ban on foreigners inspection; there's nothing left to inspect' has much logic.

Next year it will be 50 years since nazi Germany and the Soviet Union signed the infamous Molotov-Ribbentrop Pact, whereby the two powers, then allies, agreed to divide the Baltic states between them in the approaching European war. This was done without the knowledge of the Baltic people themselves. Despite treaties to the contrary, in 1940 the Soviet tanks moved into the Baltic states. In 1940-41 was to be a reign of terror for the Baltic peoples. The mass deportations began during the night of 14 June 1941 in appalling conditions. The human beings involved were officially regarded as merchandise.

It is estimated that in the first year alone of Soviet occupation, 1940-41, about 60,000 Estonians, 34,000 Latvians and 75,000 Lithuanians were deported to Siberia or killed, especially the intelligentsia. Australia, Britain, the United States of America and most other Western countries have not recognised the illegal annexation, or de jure incorporation, of the Baltic states by the Soviet Union. This is not a case of anti-Sovietism; it is a case of international law. The Soviet annexation of the Baltic states was then, and remains today, a violation of the rights of sovereign states.

The Baltic nationalists base their case for independence not only on the illegality of Soviet occupation but also on the issue of basic human rights. At least 10 per cent of the population of the Baltic states-more than 600,000 people-perished during the brutal annexation, and ever since the Baltic peoples have suffered under the totalitarian and authoritarian Soviet regime. Their nationalistic feeling was first expressed publicly in 1979 when a group of 45 Lithuanians, Latvians and Estonians signed a declaration on the fortieth anniversary of the Hitler-Stalin pact, demanding independence for their republics. Many of those 45 signatories went to gaol, and at least one, Juri Kukk, subsequently died from force-feeding during a hunger strike.

The extent of the Soviet effort to expunge languages, traditions and cultures in the Baltic states has been phenomenal. This process of Russification was described by former English diplomat Kenneth Benton, at the tribunal organised by the Baltic World Conference in 1985, in the following way:

There was to be no semblance of real autonomy for the Baltic peoples; even their Communist Party officials are now in many cases Russians who do not speak the local language. Education has been to a large extent Sovietised, including enforced membership of the Octobrist and Komsomol organisations and subsequent military training; the teaching of Baltic languages is being gradually eliminated and Baltic literature is harshly censored or banned altogether. There is widespread religious persecution. Russians have been brought in to occupy all the important positions in industry and government. In agriculture, where collectivisation was imposed with total disregard for national traditions, tens of thousands of small farmers have been deported . . .
This is what the coordinated demonstrations last year in Riga, Vitrius and Tallinn were about-namely, a deep commitment to the restoration of independence and human rights in the Baltic states.

On 17 March there was in the House of Representatives an important debate on the Helsinki Accord, an international agreement aimed at guaranteeing human rights and signed by some 33 European states, together with Canada and the United States. In the course of this debate, the House honoured Mrs Oskana Meschko, a very brave lady in her eighties who has dedicated her life to the pursuit of human rights in the Soviet Union.

Last year, on the twentieth anniversary of the formation of the Helsinki Monitor Group, Senator Harradine and I put on the Notice Paper a notice of motion in relation to the Helsinki Accord. I hope that the Senate will soon have the opportunity to debate the Accord when considering that motion.

Mrs Meschko is now visiting Australia. A few weeks ago several of us had the pleasure of meeting her and of welcoming her to our country. We applaud in great admiration her example in fighting for human rights in the Soviet Union. She is one of two human rights workers from countries under Soviet rule to have visited Australia in recent months.

The public image that the Soviet Union has been working at since Mr Gorbachev was elected by the party-not, of course, by the Russian people-is one of openness, communism with a human face-glasnost. Such propaganda has evidently been successful. Western media has reported very positively on the policy of glasnost. However, eyewitness accounts of the situation in Latvia like those of Roland Silaraups, official lies from the Soviet Embassy here in Canberra in response to 31 senators of this Parliament, and recent reports of brutal suppression of nationalist demonstrations made me less than optimistic about any genuine improvements in the USSR. Glasnost may turn out to be no more than a propaganda stunt to impress the West and, thereby, gain the fruits of the West's magnificent economic performance relative to the Soviets, rather than genuine reform. I fear that it may be more in accord with Lenin's recipe in his book Useful Fools, for disarming the enemy-in this case the West and what we understand by freedom and liberty. In that book Lenin wrote:

When a country is selected for attack, we must first set up before the youth of that land a mental barrage which will forever prohibit the possibility of that youth being moulded into an armed force to oppose our invading armies. This can most successfully be done through creating `war horror' thought and by teaching pacifism and non-resistance. It will be found that powerful organisations of non-communists can be created for this purpose, particularly with the aid of liberal-minded ministers, professors, and lecturers.

The message for those of us lucky enough to live in a country such as Australia, where our basic human rights are guaranteed, is clear. It is our duty, by virtue of our sense of humanity, to fight on behalf of those who live under repressive communist regimes-for the sake of those people, and indeed for our sake and the sake of all people in the free world.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 7.47 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 16 December 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Do the guidelines for National Estate Grants require an equal distribution amongst built, natural and Aboriginal projects.
(2) What are the proportions actually granted in each of the last 10 years, and what are the reasons for any major discrepancies from an equal distribution.
(3) Are any changes contemplated in this aspect of the guidelines or in the actual distribution of grants.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) While an equal distribution of funds between the built, natural and Aboriginal cultural components is the objective of the National Estate Grants Program, it is not a formal requirement. Under the guidelines for the Scheme the criteria specify inter alia that `a reasonable proportion of grants' is to be distributed between these elements. The final distribution of funds within a State is a product of the range, quality and total quantum of applications received for that year.

(2) Over the past ten years, the annual allocation for the ``built'' component has varied between 65% and 80% of funds under the program, the ``natural'' component between 10% and 22%, and the ``Aboriginal'' component between 6% and 18%. The trend in recent years has been towards more funding for ``natural'' and ``Aboriginal'' projects and less for the ``built'' component.

The reasons for the variation from an equal distribution are that approximately 80% of all applications are for ``built'' projects, 12% for ``natural'' projects and 8% for ``Aboriginal'' projects. The final selection of projects is based on the quality of the applications, rather than selecting projects simply to achieve an equal distribution between the three components. As 80% of all applications are for ``built'' projects, it is inevitable that there have been a greater percentage of ``built'' projects funded under the program.

(3) A review of the National Estate Grants Program has recently been undertaken by my Department. It is possible that as a result of this review changes may be made to the guidelines and the procedures for assessment of applications.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 18 December 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Why did the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests Commission of Inquiry hold a secret meeting with counsel of the Tasmanian Forestry Commission (TFC) on Wednesday 9 December 1987.
(2) Is it appropriate that the Commission of Inquiry should privately negotiate the release of data from the TFC in exchange for an early report on qualifying areas by the Commission.
(3) When did these negotiations begin.

(4) Why did a member of the Commission's legal staff, who with Commissioner Helsham was present at the meeting with counsel of the TFC, later deny any knowledge of that meeting when questioned by conservationists.

(5) Was it appropriate for the Commission to offer the Combined Environment Groups (CEG) a private meeting with the Commissioners after the Commission became aware that the CEG had found out about the meeting referred to in (1).

(6) Is it appropriate for the Commission to engage a former Chief Commissioner of the TFC as a private consultant to prepare a secret report on the reservation of tall eucalypt forests for the Commission.
(7) Have the Commissioners held private meetings or discussions with representatives of Tasmania's forest industries.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's questions is as follows:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment and the Arts, upon notice, on 18 December 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware of a report in the Age of 3 December 1987, entitled ``BHP attacked over Kakadu mineral search''.

(2) Has the Minister ordered an inspection of the Coronation Hill site in response to Wilderness Society statements that BHP exploration activities at the site have caused significant environmental damage; if so, what damage did that inspection reveal.
(3) What action has the Minister taken to stop further environmental damage at Coronation Hill.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) and (3) I visited the Conservation Zone on 21 January 1988 and inspected activities at Coronation Hill.

Two access authorities have been issued by the Minister for Administrative Services to BHP Gold Mines Ltd., concerning its operations at Coronation Hill. The issue of the authorities removes any doubts as to the legality of the work being undertaken at Coronation Hill.

One of the authorities will allow exploration work to continue on pre-existing leases held by BHP. The other will permit access to those parts of the Kakadu Conservation Zone outside the leases so that work can be undertaken for the preparation of an Environmental Impact Statement for the Coronation Hill project. Both authorities are subject to stringent environmental terms and conditions to ensure protection of the natural and cultural values of the area.

BHP's activities in the Kakadu Conservation Zone are being monitored to ensure that they are not affecting the water quality of the South Alligator River or the nearby Kakadu National Park. The Supervising Scientist has commenced a program of water quality and aquatic fauna sampling along the South Alligator River and officers of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service patrol both the Park and the Conservation Zone. The Government will ensure that the environmental conditions attached to the access authorities are enforced.
